Staff members often had only a partial understanding of health literacy, and were unaware of system strategies to address health literacy or provision of health information. © 2016, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Health information; health literacy; public health; public libraries

Title: Prejudices Unshelved: Variation in Attitudes toward Controversial Public Library Materials in the General Social Survey, 1972–2014
Affiliations: Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brett, J., Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, United States; Campbell, M.E., Texas A&M University, College Station, TX, United States
Abstract: Using the General Social Survey from 1972–2014, we examine variation in attitudes toward retaining controversial materials in libraries. Previously controversial topics have become much more widely accepted. We find that other controversies remain, showing how global conflicts become intertwined in local cultural controversies, and how the perceived threat from particular groups informs public concern with disseminating information from those groups. We find that more frequent library users are somewhat less likely to want to remove controversial books from the shelves, although some of these relationships are explained by variation in the respondent’s age, race, and other characteristics. © 2016, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: attitudes; censorship; controversy; General Social Survey; Public libraries

Authors: Warraich N.F., Haq I., Ameen K.
Title: Status of Public Libraries in Rawalpindi District, Pakistan
Affiliations: University of the Punjab, Lahore, Pakistan; Armed Forces Post Graduate Medical Institute, Rawalpindi, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Warraich, N.F., University of the Punjab, Lahore, Pakistan; Haq, I., Armed Forces Post Graduate Medical Institute, Rawalpindi, Pakistan; Ameen, K., University of the Punjab, Lahore, Pakistan
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to assess the status of public libraries located in Rawalpindi District, Pakistan, in terms of administrative setup, collection, staff, resources, and services. The article is derived from evidence obtained through a questionnaire-based survey carried out in December 2013. This survey was conducted for the preparation of “Directory of Public Library Project” a joint venture of Punjab Library Foundation and Department of Library and Information Science, University of the Punjab. The survey found eleven public libraries in the District of Rawalpindi. Only three of these have professional staff. Overall, libraries have poor and outdated book collections that are not properly classified and cataloged. Information Communication Technology infrastructure exists in libraries with some exceptions. Most of the libraries are facing constraints (e.g., low number of hours, too small in size, and too many users for size of collections) that result in inadequate services. Most of the libraries are facing similar problems, which are being faced by other public libraries of Pakistan (e.g., shortage of professional staff, lack of modern facilities, and insufficient funds). Practical recommendations are made at the end of study. © 2016, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Pakistan; public libraries; Rawalpindi; survey

Authors: Bishop B.W., Mehra B., Partee R.P., II
Title: The Role of Rural Public Libraries in Small Business Development
Affiliations: University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bishop, B.W., University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, United States; Mehra, B., University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, United States; Partee, R.P., II, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, United States
Abstract: Like all public libraries, rural public libraries in the Appalachian region can play a significant role in the economic development of their communities. Economic development in rural communities potentially benefit from many of the same resources and services all enjoy at public libraries, including free and public Internet access, space, education, question answering, and materials on many business-related subjects. This article reports survey findings of current activities that rural public libraries perform in one state, namely the state of Tennessee, as a case study to apply the lessons and insights to other parts of the United States. The discussion includes assessment of activities and some recommendations to streamline and stimulate all public libraries in conducting this assistance efficiently. © 2016, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Economic development; public libraries; rural libraries; small business

Authors: Friedman D.B., Kornegay V., Tanner A., Bergeron C.D., Sisson D.C., Weis M.A., Patterson L.L.
Title: Partnering with the Public Library for Health Care Education: An Evaluation of Affordable Care Act Messages
Affiliations: University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, United States; Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States; South Carolina Institute of Medicine and Public Health, Columbia, SC, United States; Richland Library, Columbia, SC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Friedman, D.B., University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, United States; Kornegay, V., University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, United States; Tanner, A., University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, United States; Bergeron, C.D., University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, United States; Sisson, D.C., Auburn University, Auburn, AL, United States; Weis, M.A., South Carolina Institute of Medicine and Public Health, Columbia, SC, United States; Patterson, L.L., Richland Library, Columbia, SC, United States
Abstract: Despite implementation of most of the provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) by 2014, the public still has questions about the health care law. To assess the potential of using the library as a hub for ACA education, we tested existing and new culturally relevant messages about the health care law with twenty-seven community members. Participants discussed the message prototypes, including the visual components and promotional content, and provided advice to modify content and design to best reach target audiences. Future research can follow this example to engage libraries and community members in developing and evaluating culturally relevant health messages. © 2016, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Advertisements; focus groups; health care law; health communication; public library; qualitative research

Title: From Knowledge Keepers to Knowledge Creators
Affiliations: University of the Sunshine Coast, Sippy Downs, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Inayatullah, S., University of the Sunshine Coast, Sippy Downs, Australia
Abstract: As the location and creation of knowledge become democratized and decentralized, libraries and librarians are rethinking their relationships with the communities they serve and the knowledge they help preserve and produce. This article is about the implications of that transformation. © Sohail Inayatullah.
Author Keywords: Causal Layered Analysis; futures studies; library futures; narrative foresight; scenarios

Authors: Agosto D.E., Purcell M., Magee R.M., Forte A.
Title: Teens, Libraries, and Social Media: Myths and Reality
Affiliations: Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, United States; University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Agosto, D.E., Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, United States; Purcell, M., Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, United States; Magee, R.M., University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, IL, United States; Forte, A., Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, United States
Abstract: This article presents a brief overview of research relating to teens, libraries, and social media. It also summarizes a recent multimethod study of how public and school libraries fit into U.S. teens’ increasingly online information lives. The study results debunk five popular myths about teens and social media and reveal many positive ways that teens are using social media to connect with peers and adults and to seek and share information. The article concludes with a discussion of the role that libraries can play in designing services and programs to encourage teens to engage in positive social media use. © Denise E. Agosto, Michelle Purcell, Rachel M. Magee, and Andrea Forte.
Author Keywords: adolescents; libraries; social media; social network sites; teens

Title: Rural and Small Town Library Management Challenges
Affiliations: YBP Library Services, Contoocook, NH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, R.K., YBP Library Services, Contoocook, NH, United States
Abstract: This article reports the results of a survey conducted in 2015 of librarians who work for small town and rural public libraries throughout the United States. Questions were asked about personnel statistics, budget, community involvement, programs, technology, managerial challenges, and how to solve the organization’s problems. The purpose of this research was to ascertain if conditions have improved for libraries in areas of low population and what managerial challenges these librarians faced. The survey found that financial conditions had improved or will improve in the future and that the most challenging managerial issue was staffing. © Rachel K. Fischer.
Author Keywords: economics of small libraries; library management; library personnel; problem solving in small libraries; rural libraries; small libraries; staff in small libraries

Title: Understanding Your Library’s Financial Audit
Affiliations: University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carrigan, D., University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, United States
Abstract: This article is intended to help libraries face routine financial audits. Public libraries fall into three categories: departments of local government, nonprofits, and “special district governments” (U.S. Census Bureau 2012). When libraries that are “special district governments” undergo financial audit, they are subject to rigorous standards, known as generally accepted accounting principles, of the Governmental Accounting Standards Board. The independent auditors who perform financial audits are also subject to standards, known as generally accepted government auditing standards, of the Government Accountability Office. The author shows librarians how to use the audit to promote their reputation as first-rate public library money managers. © Dennis Carrigan.
Author Keywords: financial audit; generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP); generally accepted government auditing standards (GAGAS); Government Accountability Office; Governmental Accounting Standards Board

Title: Consumer Health Reference Interview: Ideas for Public Librarians
Affiliations: San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Luo, L., San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States
Abstract: This two-stage study seeks to help public librarians become better prepared, and more confident and competent, when answering medical/health questions. At the first stage, eleven barriers that public librarians often encounter in the consumer health reference interview were identified through a comprehensive literature review, and at the second stage, input from professional consumer health librarians on how to overcome the barriers was gathered via a qualitative survey. Findings of the study provide concrete and practical strategies that will help public librarians more successfully conduct the reference interview to assist library users in their health information-seeking journey. © Lili Luo.
Author Keywords: health information service; health reference service; public library; reference interview

Title: How the Los Angeles Public Library Responded to Budget Cuts
Affiliations: University of South Australia, Mawson Lakes, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Velasquez, D.L., University of South Australia, Mawson Lakes, Australia
Abstract: This article provides an overview of how Los Angeles Public Library, its community, and elected officials responded to reductions mandated by its funding agencies. The Los Angeles Public Library (LAPL) and its communities faced and are still facing recessionary budget pressures that started in 2007. In recent decades the mayor and City Council of Los Angeles have supported the libraries that have come to define the great cultural heritage and a significant landmark in the heart of the city. The most recent budget shortfall—that which began in 2007—was brought on by huge, mandated increases in pension payments due to city workers’ funds, particularly in the police and fire departments. At LAPL the budget shortfall created severe personnel, material, and service cuts. This case study describes what happened when the budget crises occurred and how the library department, citizens, and elected city officials dealt with them. © Diane Velasquez.
Author Keywords: advocacy; budget reduction; Los Angeles Public Library; public libraries; recession response

Title: Choosing the Right Scanners for Your Library
Affiliations: Plustek Technology, Santa Fe Springs, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fuchs, R., Plustek Technology, Santa Fe Springs, CA, United States
Abstract: This article is written as a primer for librarians on how to buy a scanner. It covers nearly every type of scanner used by patrons in a library (flatbed, document, overhead, photo, film, microfiche, and scanners to help the low sighted, and sets out criteria for selecting the best scanner to execute the scanning tasks that library planners want carried out in their institutions. © Robert Fuchs.
Author Keywords: disabled scanner services; document scanning; primer of scanner selection; scanner selection criteria; special collections scanning

Title: Big Changes Needed: Where to Find the Money?
Affiliations: University of Oklahoma Libraries, Norman, OK, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grant, C., University of Oklahoma Libraries, Norman, OK, United States
Abstract: This article discusses ways that librarians can find the money to make big changes within their organizations. The article discusses strategic planning, metrics, and greater operating efficiencies as sound management methods to obtain the funding to make important changes in tight financial times. The piece has a practical tone addressed to library leaders and to practitioners who are asked to make significant changes in a lean economy. © Carl Grant.
Author Keywords: collaborative workspaces; entrepreneurial centers; innovation centers; knowledge creation platforms; metrics; strategic planning; ubiquitous information funding

Title: Public Libraries, Dual Constituencies, and Marketing
Affiliations: University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carrigan, D., University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, United States
Abstract: Marketing can be a powerful tool for public libraries. However, to realize marketing’s potential, it must be understood. Unfortunately, “Marketing is a term used by librarians to mean many different things and therefore has become confusing” (Doucett 2008, 1). Replacing confusion with clarity, which is especially important if the goal of marketing is to elicit financial and other support, requires answering two questions: What is marketing, and what is required for marketing to deliver the benefits it is capable of? Answers are sought before when marketing came “to mean many different things and … become confusing.” © Dennis Carrigan.
Author Keywords: public libraries, marketing, constituencies, exchange, segments

Title: Learning Sites, References, and Notes: Compiled by the Editors
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Library Card Campaigns and Sustaining Service: How Do Public Libraries Best Serve Poor Children?
Affiliations: St. Louis Public Library, United States; ALSC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Holt, G.E., St. Louis Public Library, United States; Holt, L.E., ALSC, United States
Abstract: This article functions as a research critique of a short, recent IMLS report that tied early childhood success to library card holding. The authors invite a more comprehensive and evidence-based examination of the ties between library card holding, the successes of poor children in school, and the significance of sustained library services to keep kids interested in their own educational success. The article also suggests how youth use of libraries is tied to the realities of local politics, gangs, and crime. © Glen Holt and Leslie Edmonds Holt.
Author Keywords: card campaigns; Casey Foundation youth studies; illiteracy; IMLS; library cards; poverty and library use; youth library cards

Title: Digital Storytelling Based on the Association for Library Service to Children Competencies: A Learning Activity to Promote Values Associated with Social Justice
Affiliations: Texas Woman’s University, Denton, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moreillon, J., Texas Woman’s University, Denton, TX, United States
Abstract: Social justice is a thread that is woven into the values of librarians. Concepts such as equal access, diversity, and inclusion are central tenets of librarianship. The Association for Library Service to Children (ALSC) competencies (2009) strengthen the social justice fabric of the profession. In the Art of Storytelling, eighteen graduate students used digital tools to create and disseminate advocacy stories. A content analysis of the ALSC competencies and graduate students’ data shows that, although the term “social justice” is not used in those competencies, these professional standards provide support for aligning preservice education with concepts related to social justice. © Judi Moreillon.
Author Keywords: advocacy; competencies; digital storytelling; LIS education; social justice

Title: Invisible Debility: Attitudes toward the Underrepresented in Library Workplaces
Affiliations: Southern Connecticut State University, New Haven, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, M.E., Southern Connecticut State University, New Haven, CT, United States
Abstract: The American Library Association is committed to recruiting persons of color and those with disabilities to the profession, yet these groups are underrepresented among librarians. While intentional discrimination was the impetus for the Civil Rights Act of 1964, empirical studies in the workplace have exposed continued discrimination through unconscious bias. Extending such research to the library profession raises the question: How do librarians perceive the underrepresented as potential fellow library staff? In my recently conducted study of public library staff and future librarians, participants agreed that library staff should represent the diversity of the communities served; there was little support, however, for actively attempting to advance proportional representation through education or hiring. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: employment discrimination; hiring bias; underrepresentation of minorities in library employment

Title: Facebooking It: Promoting Library Services to Young Adults through Social Media
Affiliations: Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, A.L., Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, United States
Abstract: With social media a normal part of the daily lives of young adults, librarians are using these sites to promote library services. This article investigates the perceptions and attitudes of librarians toward social media as a tool for libraries and explores the way librarians utilize social media to portray professional roles and responsibilities to young patrons. This author focuses on the pastoral role of librarians and discusses possibilities for performing this role through social media. Although presently under-researched, social media provides librarians with one more avenue to advocate for, engage with, and support young adults. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: advocacy through YA social media; pastoral role of librarians; promotion to YA users; social media

Title: It’s Time to Define a New Brand for Libraries. Let’s Make Sure It Leaves People Soaring, Not Snoring.
Affiliations: University of Oklahoma Libraries, Norman, OK, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grant, C., University of Oklahoma Libraries, Norman, OK, United States
Abstract: Librarians can benefit from studying the history of other professions in order to learn from mistakes others have made. One place librarians need to be concerned about today is the library brand, which defines for user communities what libraries are all about and what kind of experience users will have in libraries. Recent research reports show the library brand as “books” and suggest an equally uninspiring new branding. This article examines some compelling brand examples from other professions and suggests some other options for librarianship. ©, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: library brand; library branding; library marketing; library promotion; library slogans; library tag lines

Title: Public Library Evaluation: A Retrospective on the Evolution of Measurement Systems
Affiliations: Rutgers University–Camden, United States
Authors with affiliations: Closter, M., Rutgers University–Camden, United States
Abstract: This article aims to provide a historical and contemporary perspective on how public libraries establish indicators for measuring success, using the Free Library of Philadelphia as a focus of analysis. From the 1970s though the late 1980s, libraries focused on measuring internal statistics, such as bibliographic resources, to communicate the strength of their collection. Within the past twenty years, libraries have shifted their measurement structures toward outward performance in the communities they serve. The challenge today for libraries such as the Free Library is to establish structured formats for guiding community plans for their particular library and establishing agreed-on measures. Simultaneously, these structures need to incorporate ongoing evaluation methods. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: civic librarianship; library evaluation; library greatness; strategic planning

Title: A Design Analysis of Indiana Public Library Homepages
Affiliations: Indiana University Kokomo, Kokomo, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thorpe, A., Indiana University Kokomo, Kokomo, IN, United States; Lukes, R., Indiana University Kokomo, Kokomo, IN, United States
Abstract: This article describes the results of an analysis of 430 Indiana public library homepages. The authors examined each homepage for 129 total elements, such as navigation, search, content, and Web 2.0 features. Our findings reveal common trends in public library homepage design, including twenty-one elements that appear on at least half of the surveyed homepages. The results of this study provide a profile of public library homepage design in Indiana. Additionally, this study blends two preexisting library content checklists in order to provide a replicable methodology for additional libraries to apply to their homepages or websites. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: design elements; homepage design; Indiana libraries; library websites; public libraries; social media; Web 2.0; website design; World Wide Web

Title: Public Library History on the Lewis and Clark Trail
Affiliations: Simmons College, Boston, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jordan, M.W., Simmons College, Boston, MA, United States
Abstract: The history of public libraries in the United States is not long. But what do current libraries know about their own history? To find out I drove the Lewis and Clark Trail to visit public libraries between St. Louis and the Pacific Ocean. The purpose of the research trip was to discover the historical knowledge that public libraries along the trail were able to share about themselves. Local history and genealogy proved to be very important in public libraries, while knowledge of their own history was less so. The libraries, however, did manage to blend their institutional histories with their current services. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: genealogy; Lewis and Clark Trail libraries; local history; public library history; small and rural libraries; survey research; western U.S. libraries

Authors: Real B., McDermott A.J., Bertot J.C., Jaeger P.T.
Title: Digital Inclusion and the Affordable Care Act: Public Libraries, Politics, Policy, and Enrollment in “Obamacare”
Affiliations: University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Real, B., University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States; McDermott, A.J., University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States; Bertot, J.C., University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States; Jaeger, P.T., University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States
Abstract: The period of enrollment in the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as “Obamacare,” positioned public libraries as a primary place for enrollment for individuals lacking sufficient levels of access or literacy to enroll on their own. Inclusion also thrust public libraries into the middle of a significant political and policy fray about the appropriateness and content of the law that encompassed national, state, and local politics. Building on the data from a national survey of the digital inclusion roles of public libraries, this article examines the health literacy and inclusion roles and initiatives of public libraries within the highly politicized context of health care following the passage of the ACA. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Affordable Care Act; digital divide; digital inclusion; government information; health information

Title: Additional Information on Drugs and Hearing Loss
Authors with affiliations: Holt, G.E.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Collection Development Policies in Public Libraries in Australia: A Qualitative Content Analysis
Affiliations: Curtin University, Perth, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Kelly, M., Curtin University, Perth, Australia
Abstract: The role that public library collection development policies play in guiding selectors and informing users has been promoted as a pillar of good professional practice. While these policies purport to open up the methods and the criteria used in selection so as to promote transparency and a sense of professional objectivity, how they actually are developed and put into practice has remained largely implicit in the research literature. This analysis revealed that policies tended to focus on local issues and remained heavily materials focused. How collections are developed to support user’s information needs and substantive issues associated with topicality are largely unarticulated. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: adult nonfiction materials; Australian public libraries; collection development policies; selection and evaluation methods

Title: Transition from Camel Libraries to Digital Technologies in Kenya Public Libraries
Affiliations: Kenya National Library Service, Nairobi, Kenya
Authors with affiliations: Pingo, Z.B., Kenya National Library Service, Nairobi, Kenya
Abstract: Public libraries in Kenya were established with the aim of providing information services to the general public. The Kenya National Library Service (KNLS) is responsible for providing services through its library network across the country. In the past, to combat illiteracy, the library launched various initiatives, including mobile services and community libraries. The public libraries are in a transition period of moving from paper library services to incorporate modern digital technologies for information access. This article addresses the progress from predigital to the present, examining difficulties and challenges faced in adopting new technologies in the modern information age. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: digital divide; information access; Kenyan libraries; mobile libraries; public libraries

Title: An Assessment of the University of Washington’s Chat Reference Services
Affiliations: University of Washington Libraries, Seattle, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cabaniss, J., University of Washington Libraries, Seattle, WA, United States
Abstract: This project assesses the chat reference service of the University of Washington (UW) Libraries. First, I conducted a literature review to examine the evolution of virtual reference services. Then, through OCLC’s Question Point, I examined chats that occurred during weeks 1, 5, and 10 of Winter Quarter 2014. Chats were coded according to pre-set conditions (category of questions, READ Level, time of day, and session time). An analysis showed that the majority of questions were either General Information or Known Item Lookups, the lowest level of difficulty for the answering librarian. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: assessment; chat reference; reference survey; University of Washington Library

Authors: Agosto D.E., Bell J.P., Bernier A., Kuhlmann M.
Title: “This Is Our Library, and It’s a Pretty Cool Place”: A User-Centered Study of Public Library YA Spaces
Affiliations: Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, United States; San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Agosto, D.E., Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, United States; Bell, J.P., San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States; Bernier, A., San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States; Kuhlmann, M., San Jose State University, San Jose, CA, United States
Abstract: This study sought to collect data from teens and librarians about their preferences and recommendations for the effective design of physical library spaces for teens. Librarians and teens at twenty-two U.S. public libraries filmed narrated video tours of their young adult (YA) public library spaces. The researchers used qualitative content analysis techniques to analyze the video data and to develop a framework for guiding the design of effective YA public library spaces. In addition to providing specific recommendations for user-centered YA library space design, this study highlights the need for continued user input into the design and maintenance of YA public library spaces as teens’ needs evolve and vary across time and from community to community. © , Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: film as research tool; research on YAs; space planning for YAs; young adults (YA)

Title: An Evaluation of Young Adult Web Pages in Public Library Websites in Japan
Affiliations: Toyo Eiwa University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kanazawa, M., Toyo Eiwa University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: This study is the first investigation into the types of contents in young adult (YA) web pages in public library websites in Japan. The study reveals that YA web pages, in general, place more emphasis on providing guidance on YA services, on helping young adults with regular learning, on the use of information resources for reference services, and on improving the communication abilities for young adults, rather than on providing research assistance to adults on YA services. Furthermore, an IRIS (Information Reference Instructional Sharing) Contents Model is proposed for YA web pages, whereas an IRIR (Information Reference Instructional Research) Contents Model is presented for children’s web pages, based on the differences between the contents of YA web pages and those of children’s web pages. ©, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: information literacy; IRIR Contents Model; IRIS Contents Model; Japanese public library websites; web pages for young adults; young adult services

Title: When Disaster Strikes: Opportunities for Community and Institutional Renewal at Elliot Lake Public Library
Affiliations: American Theological Library Association, Chicago, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart, A., American Theological Library Association, Chicago, IL, United States
Abstract: On June 23, 2012, the Algo Centre Mall in Elliot Lake, Ontario, collapsed suddenly, killing two people, injuring many more, and destroying many of the community’s services, including the public library. After describing the events leading up to, during, and following the destruction of Elliot Lake Public Library, I discuss five opportunities for community and institutional renewal that are not currently being realized by the library. The destruction of the library need not be an entirely negative experience but, rather, a catalyst for refocusing the library’s role and improving its services and facilities in order to better meet the changing information needs of the community. ©, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Canada; disaster management; disaster recovery; library governance; public libraries

Title: “I’m a Library Hugger!”: Public Libraries as Valued Community Assets
Affiliations: University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Oliphant, T., University of Alberta, Edmonton, Canada
Abstract: Public library value is often ascertained by outlining the economic, social, and cultural benefits public libraries generate for the greater community. While researchers have focused on the concepts of social capital, civic engagement, and the role of libraries in promoting democracy, fewer studies have explored the public’s perceptions of libraries in an effort to determine library value. Furthermore, library nonusers are rarely included in these studies. In Alberta, Canada, 1,201 Albertans from across the province, including both urban and rural areas, were asked a series of questions about their perceptions of public libraries and library use. Findings reveal characteristics of library users and nonusers, what services and resources are used most often at public libraries, what value the public places on public libraries, and the role that libraries play in supporting communities. ©, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Alberta library users; Canadian libraries; survey; uses of the library; value of libraries

Title: The Role of Public Librarians in Disseminating Information for True Democracy
Affiliations: University of Sierra Leone, Freetown, Sierra Leone
Authors with affiliations: Kargbo, J.A., University of Sierra Leone, Freetown, Sierra Leone
Abstract: Disseminating information should be the business of public librarians. In a democracy, public librarians are expected to play a leading role in acquiring, processing, interpreting, repackaging, and disseminating relevant, up-to-date, and timely information and knowledge resources both from within and beyond their localities. Public librarians should serve as catalysts for the effective dissemination of information to promote true democracy. They are expected to explore channels of communication for the practice of true democracy. An emphasis on democratic ideals raises awareness of democratic tenets among the populace and also facilitates the holding of free, fair, and peaceful elections. This article examines the concept of democratic governance, the link between democratic governance and information, public libraries, and what public librarians should do to ensure the promotion of democracy. ©, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: democracy; democratic governance; governance; information and democracy; information dissemination; information institutions; information professionals; public librarians

Authors: Brady T., Salas C., Nuriddin A., Rodgers W., Subramaniam M.
Title: MakeAbility: Creating Accessible Makerspace Events in a Public Library
Affiliations: University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brady, T., University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, United States; Salas, C., University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, United States; Nuriddin, A., University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, United States; Rodgers, W., University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, United States; Subramaniam, M., University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland, United States
Abstract: This exploratory article describes the planning and execution of an accessible library makerspace event for people with disabilities (specifically, patrons with cognitive and visual impairments). We begin with a literature review on the maker movement and a description of makerspaces in libraries. We highlight the insufficient focus on making these makerspaces accessible for people with all abilities. Next, we describe the design of the makerspace event that we implemented at a local public library and extrapolate the on-the-go modifications that we made for patrons with cognitive and visual impairment who attended the event. Based on the lessons learned through the implementation of this event, we provide suggestions for creating accessible makerspace events in libraries, including concrete recommendations on the design of the stations. ©, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: accessibility; disability access; diversity; DIY; inclusion; makerspaces

Title: Statewide Initiative to Embed Consumer Health Librarians in Public Libraries: A Case Study
Affiliations: University of North Carolina–Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, United States; University of Maryland Health Sciences and Human Services Library, Baltimore, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Flaherty, M.G., University of North Carolina–Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, United States; Grier, P.L., Jr., University of Maryland Health Sciences and Human Services Library, Baltimore, MD, United States
Abstract: In 2004 a collaborative, statewide outreach project in Delaware was undertaken where consumer health librarians were embedded in public libraries. In order to explore the effect of the embedded librarians on the quality of health information provision, unobtrusive reference visits were made to half of the public libraries in the state. The query “Do vaccines cause autism?” was posed to library staff; resources provided were recorded. In 67 percent of visits, public library staff provided authoritative health information resources. It appears the embedded librarians had a positive residual effect on the provision of authoritative health resources for addressing an ambiguous query. ©, Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: consumer health; health information; public libraries

Title: Learning Sites, References, and Notes
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Web Accessibility Assessment of Urban Public Library Websites
Affiliations: Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maatta Smith, S.L., Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, United States
Abstract: In an age of ubiquitous information and communication technologies, urban public libraries are some of the only places to provide free Internet access for all members of the community regardless of ability or disability. This study provides a website accessibility assessment of the 127 U.S. public library members of the Urban Library Council, using the World Wide Web Consortium's Web Content Accessibility Guidelines to establish the level of Web readiness of urban public libraries to meet the needs of individuals with disabilities. Findings suggest these libraries require additional and ongoing maintenance to be digitally inclusive. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: accessibility; digital inclusion; disability access; Urban Libraries Council; urban public libraries

Title: NYPL: Service Successes and Financial Struggles as Branches Meet Neighborhood Needs
Affiliations: c/o Jarrett Murphy, City Limits, 31 E. 32nd Street, 3rd floor, New York, NY 10016, United States
Authors with affiliations: Travers, S., c/o Jarrett Murphy, City Limits, 31 E. 32nd Street, 3rd floor, New York, NY 10016, United States
Abstract: Free access to technology, help for immigrants, a safe space for kids-NYPL Branch libraries play an increasingly important role. But funding hasn't kept up. Will the lack of support undermine a critical civic resource? This publication is based on an ongoing project looking at the potential for New York's libraries to fill a critical gap in New York City's civic infrastructure, as well as the challenges and difficult choices the library systems face. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: branch libraries; Brooklyn; budget cuts; civic agency; community development; education; financial issues; literacy; New York City; public technology dependents; technology needs of community

Title: Systematic Marketing Facilitates Optimal Customer Service: The Marketing Audit of a Rural Public Library System
Affiliations: Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, A.L., Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, United States
Abstract: This article presents a case study of a marketing audit of the Lee County Library System, a rural public library system located in southwest Georgia. Marketing audits are an underutilized but needed tool for public libraries. In this audit, the library system's mission, goals, environments, community and employee demographics, and a strengths/weakness/opportunities/threats (SWOT) analysis were evaluated, resulting in several recommendations. These recommendations include a new mission statement, regular SWOT analyses, and potential market segments for targeted library services. Through this case study, the complexities, challenges, and opportunities unique to rural public libraries can be understood. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Lee County (GA) Library System; marketing audit; rural library analysis; small library marketing

Title: A Mother-Daughter Book Club: A Search for Intimacy
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Henderson, L., University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI, United States
Abstract: This study examines the nature of group interaction and response to texts in an African American, mother-daughter literature discussion group in a predominately White, Midwestern college town. The implications of this research for teachers and librarians include a discussion about the value of community and intergenerational literacy and adolescents' need to share literacy events with adults from their own racialized group. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: book clubs; community literacy; family literacy; mother/daughter relationships

Title: Public Library Websites and Adherence to Senior-Friendly Guidelines
Affiliations: Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Charbonneau, D.H., Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, United States
Abstract: This article reports on the results of a study that examined public library website adherence to senior-friendly website guidelines. A total of 104 public library websites (N = 104) were analyzed. Compliance with Internet design accessibility principles recommended for older adult Internet users was analyzed, and the findings suggest that current public library website practices may be problematic. As a result, public library websites offering resources and services may present potential accessibility challenges to older adults. Recommendations relevant to public libraries for enhancing library websites and online content are presented. © The Author(s).
Author Keywords: accessibility; aging; older adults; public libraries; United States; website design

Title: The Rural Library Project: Building Libraries, Building Community
Affiliations: The Rural Library Project, Inc., Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: White, D., The Rural Library Project, Inc., Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: Just like urban residents, rural citizens want educational, cultural, and technological resources delivered in an affordable manner appropriate to their locale. Rural communities and elected officials strive to leverage their limited resources to meet critical needs, provide services, and improve their quality of life. The Rural Library Project, a small nonprofit in Georgia, is working with rural communities to organize and engage talent, gather resources, and value the public library as a center for lifelong learning and community development. © The Author(s).
Author Keywords: building and design of library buildings; cooperation; funding libraries; library development; rural libraries; Rural Library Project; small libraries; volunteers

Authors: Gordon M., Haack A., Vernon R., Saulter T., Shaw D.
Title: Multiple Copies of Bestsellers in Public Libraries: How Much Is Enough?
Affiliations: Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gordon, M., Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, United States; Haack, A., Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, United States; Vernon, R., Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, United States; Saulter, T., Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, United States; Shaw, D., Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, United States
Abstract: How do public libraries develop their collections of high-demand materials for the "I want it now" generation? Ten public libraries' holdings of fiction and nonfiction bestseller titles were observed over a four-week period. The number of copies rose fairly consistently, with the five fiction titles having roughly about twice the number of copies as the five nonfiction titles. The ratio of holds to copies averaged 2.7:1 and ranged from 0.8:1 to 6.5:1. Demand for e-books was consistently higher than the number of copies available, averaging more than 4:1 across all libraries. © The Author(s).
Author Keywords: best sellers; circulation policy; collections policy; e-books; fiction; nonfiction; patron demand

Title: What Library Managers Should Know about Emotional Labor
Affiliations: Kent State University School of Library and Information Science, Columbus, OH, United States; Ohionet, Columbus, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Matteson, M.L., Kent State University School of Library and Information Science, Columbus, OH, United States; Miller, S.S., Kent State University School of Library and Information Science, Columbus, OH, United States, Ohionet, Columbus, OH, United States
Abstract: This article presents emotional labor in a library context and offers library managers strategies to minimize the negative effects of emotional labor on both staff and users. The components of emotional labor are explained and a framework of response levels is presented with strategies targeted to each response level: incident, training, supervision, human resources, and organizational culture. The strategies offer library managers some ideas for effectively managing emotional labor in their organizations. Understanding the effects of emotional labor and developing the tools that can offset potential negative outcomes can create a more positive work climate and better customer service. © The Author(s).
Author Keywords: customer service climate; emotional labor; improvement of library services; service climate; training; work climate; work in libraries

Title: Using New Technology to Comply with ADA Assistive Listening Requirements
Affiliations: Listen Technologies, Bluffdale, UT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schaeffer, C., Listen Technologies, Bluffdale, UT, United States
Abstract: Hearing loss impacts 17 percent of the U.S. population. Recent changes to the Americans with Disabilities Act may require updates to how libraries accommodate people with hearing loss. Assistive listening technologies, such as Hearing Loop, open up more opportunities for libraries to engage with and better serve individuals with hearing loss. © The Author(s).
Author Keywords: Americans with Disabilities Act hearing requirements; deafness; hearing loss; hearing technologies; invisible disability; listening technology; meeting room hearing requirements; noise ratios in meetings

Title: "Look for the Union Label": Exploring the Contradictions and Complications in LGBT Terminology
Affiliations: University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Duxbury, A., University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, United States
Abstract: This article is an exploration of the implications of the gay label applied to LGBT persons and how that label surpasses all others in its implications. The author's particular focus is on the decades since World War II, where religious, legal, and political definitions all got mixed together into a mélange of cleavages affecting everything from the most definitive national and international proclamations to the personal behavior and beliefs of gay and straight individuals. © The Author(s).
Author Keywords: gay label; LGBT label; politics of the personal

Title: Connected Learning in the Public Library: An Evaluative Framework for Developing Virtual Learning Spaces for Youth
Affiliations: University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Valdivia, C., University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States; Subramaniam, M., University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States
Abstract: This article presents an evaluative framework to aid public libraries in achieving a mission of providing informal learning opportunities through virtual spaces. Existing literature on assessments and evaluation is used to build the basic framework; the experiences of 21st Century Learning Labs in Libraries and Museum grant recipients are used to develop evaluative tools and examples for library practitioners to use in planning their own virtual spaces. This article serves as the first evaluative approach to the development of informal virtual learning spaces in public libraries. © The Author(s).
Author Keywords: cyberlearning for youth; digital youth; evaluation of youth services; youth services

Title: Cyberorganizing Everyday Heritage in and around Public Libraries: An Exploratory Study in Illinois
Affiliations: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Champaign, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lenstra, N., University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Champaign, IL, United States
Abstract: Trends from both within and without public librarianship create new opportunities for libraries to serve the public's interest in heritage information. Based on a workshop series in Illinois, this article presents exploratory findings on existing public library heritage services and how cyberorganizing can enhance these services. Public libraries offer heterogeneous heritage services in local contexts composed of multiple actors and institutions. Improving this service area involves organizing within libraries, across local institutions, and among individuals with diverse interests. Part of this organizational work involves digital technologies, but people are the core element in organizing everyday heritage services. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: community building; community informatics; digital literacy; local and family history; public libraries

Title: Implementing VuFind: A Public Library Improves Electronic Search Quality and Saves Searcher Time
Affiliations: Schlow Centre Region Library, State College, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burchill, M.K., Schlow Centre Region Library, State College, PA, United States; Rasmussen, N., Schlow Centre Region Library, State College, PA, United States
Abstract: Web-scale discovery services (WSDs) are a widespread phenomenon sweeping university libraries across the world. In this article the authors discuss this trend and their experience working on a test server with the open source discovery layer VuFind. Developed by Demian Katz of Villanova University, VuFind's potential to index not only the library's catalog but also proprietary databases through the integration of application program interfaces (APIs) offers public libraries the opportunity to develop a seamless website-to-catalog experience, thereby building a true virtual branch for their patrons. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: discovery layers; open source; virtual branch; VuFind; Web-scale discovery services; website development

Title: Books (and DVDs) Are Alive!
Affiliations: Mount Pleasant Public Library, Mount Pleasant, IA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, J., Mount Pleasant Public Library, Mount Pleasant, IA, United States
Abstract: Public library patrons in 2013 demand the same materials they demanded in 1993: print books and physical-media movies. Public libraries have nothing to fear about the "digital future," which is actually in fruition right now, because books and DVDs are still in high demand. After a decade of Internet domination, books and DVDs are alive and well. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: circulation of books; future of books; trends for book circulation

Authors: Parikh N., Jo C., Lomax G., Smith S.P.
Title: Making the Case for Budget Reductions: Pierce County Library's FY2013 Budget
Affiliations: Pierce County Library, Tacoma, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Parikh, N., Pierce County Library, Tacoma, WA, United States; Jo, C., Pierce County Library, Tacoma, WA, United States; Lomax, G., Pierce County Library, Tacoma, WA, United States; Smith, S.P., Pierce County Library, Tacoma, WA, United States
Abstract: This article features a discussion about how Pierce County (Washington) Library's 2013 budgeting process and budget document explain budget cuts and service changes to users and taxpayers within the context of the library's continuing effort to improve operational efficiency and maintain valued core, customer, and community services. Pierce County Library is an independent municipal corporation established by state law and is funded from a separate property tax levy as a junior taxing district. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: budget cuts; budgeting; efficiencies; Pierce County (WA); strategy

Title: Library Page Services: An Overview
Affiliations: Shaker Heights Public Library, Shaker Heights, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nedlina, Y.G., Shaker Heights Public Library, Shaker Heights, OH, United States
Abstract: This article examines the role of library pages as opposed to library shelvers. The piece draws on the author's personal experience as a Page II at the Bertram-Woods Branch Library, part of the Shaker Heights, Ohio, Public Library System, where paging was broadened to include library functions not previously covered by the work of shelvers. This shift is a manifestation of library changes that involve new work roles for pages. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: future of library pages; improved customer service; page services; shelving services; staff development; staffing; training; work of pages

Title: The Future of Small Rural Public Libraries in America: A Report Prepared for the Board of the Langlois Public Library
Affiliations: Langlois Public Library, Langlois, OR, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, S.A., Langlois Public Library, Langlois, OR, United States
Abstract: This report by the director of a small public library examines multiple issues that face small and rural libraries in the age of big data, high expenses, and limited revenues. The author concludes that small libraries often have quite individual needs that must be met if the library is to be successful in its service mission, especially in this time of rapidly changing technology and a shifting demographic profile. Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Curry County Library Network; future of public libraries; Langlois Public Library; small library future

Title: Louisville Free Public Library Leads Community, Increases ADA-Compliance with Hearing Loop Assistive Listening System
Affiliations: Listen Technologies, Bluffdale, UT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schaeffer, C., Listen Technologies, Bluffdale, UT, United States
Abstract: This article tells how Louisville Public Library created an assistive listening system for telecoil-equipped hearing aids in the auditorium of its main library. It is intended as an article that will help other libraries meet ADA standards for those with low hearing capacity. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: ADA hearing requirements; assistive listening system; deafness; hearing problems; Louisville Free Public Library; telecoil-equipped hearing aids

Title: A Strategic Plan for Russell Library, Middletown, 2013-2017
Affiliations: Darien Library, Darien, CT, United States; Russell Library, Middletown, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gray, A.K., Darien Library, Darien, CT, United States; Meyers, A., Russell Library, Middletown, CT, United States
Abstract: This article presents a five-year strategic plan for Russell Library, the principal public library for Middletown, Connecticut. The goal of the plan is to make Russell Library "the Bridge to the Future of Middletown and its citizens." To accomplish that large goal, the planners focus on three service areas: a broad range of resources, including books, electronic items, and databases; an engaged and supportive staff; and many varied and enlightening experiences for Middletown citizens of all ages. The first quarterly report to Middletown residents is included to demonstrate how the library is following its plan. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: constituent communication; Middletown (CT); planning; relationship building; Russell Library; strategic plan

Title: Public Libraries as Rhetorical Devices: Reimagining Print, Dewey, and Memory as Invention in the Digital Age
Affiliations: Miami University of Ohio, Oxford, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ireland, R., Miami University of Ohio, Oxford, OH, United States
Abstract: This article frames the public library and its system of organization as rhetorical tools. By providing an historic overview of libraries and their formation, the author recognizes the severed connection between library systems and the field of rhetoric, specifically the rhetorical canon of memoria. He seeks to reconnect memoria to the public library by recognizing the place-based nature of both classical memoria and library classification systems. The implications, he contends, run deep in libraries as seemingly neutral entities shape collective memory and education. Finally, the author provides a section that focuses on how digital-age libraries could be shaped, maintained, and managed in a way that recognizes memory as a rhetorical tool that aids in knowledge formation. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: content management systems (CMS); Dewey Decimal System (DDC); invention; loci mnemonics; memory; process; rhetoric

Title: Can I Bring My Gun? A Fifty-State Survey of Firearm Laws Impacting Policies Prohibiting Handguns in Public Libraries
Affiliations: University of Idaho College of Law, Moscow, ID, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gleason, D., University of Idaho College of Law, Moscow, ID, United States
Abstract: In Capital Area District Library v. Michigan Open Carry, 826 N.W. 2d 736 (2012), the Michigan Court of Appeals concluded that state law preempted the library's weapons policy prohibiting firearms in the library. This survey asks how laws in each state impact similar policies prohibiting handguns in public libraries. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: firearms; laws; policies; public libraries; states

Title: Writing for Librarians about E-Book Technology
Affiliations: Forest Hills, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roncevic, M., Forest Hills, NY, United States
Abstract: The author of ALA's Library Technology Report, E-Book Platforms for Libraries, shares her thoughts about some of the issues she faced as she wrote about this still very complex subject, which all public librarians need to know about in order to develop good business positions for their organizations. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: directory of e-book platforms; e-books; e-content in libraries; future of e-books; Library Technology Report; market for e-books; technology of e-books; user feedback

Authors: Hancock Q., Jolls T., Jolls P.
Title: Racism and Stereotypes in Electronic Media
Affiliations: Consortium for Media Literacy, Malibu, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hancock, Q., Consortium for Media Literacy, Malibu, CA, United States; Jolls, T., Consortium for Media Literacy, Malibu, CA, United States; Jolls, P., Consortium for Media Literacy, Malibu, CA, United States
Abstract: This article discusses how racial, ethnic, and sexual stereotypes find their way into electronic media, both television and games. This article is presented here to help librarians understand the ethnic, racial, and sexual biases that are built into electronic communication and the importance of thoughtful media literacy analysis in watching over the electronic media that come into their collections and programs. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Consortium for Media Literacy; K-12 education; technology's impact on education

Authors: Lambert F.P., Panchyshyn R.S., McCutcheon S.
Title: Resource Description and Access and Ohio Public Libraries
Affiliations: Kent State University, Kent, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lambert, F.P., Kent State University, Kent, OH, United States; Panchyshyn, R.S., Kent State University, Kent, OH, United States; McCutcheon, S., Kent State University, Kent, OH, United States
Abstract: This study examines the current state of knowledge about Resource Description and Access (RDA), the new cataloging standard, among Ohio public library catalogers. Data were collected through an online survey from a representative sample of these catalogers. While a majority of catalogers know about RDA, their working knowledge about it is minimal. There are major differences in this knowledge based on geographic location of Ohio catalogers and educational attainment. The authors propose further training and education opportunities for Ohio catalogers. Further similar research is needed to determine if this lack of knowledge of the new descriptive standard among public library catalogers is a national challenge. © Frank P. Lambert, Roman S. Panchyshyn, and Sevim McCutcheon.
Author Keywords: cataloging standards; Ohio public libraries; RDA; Resource Description and Access; training catalogers

Title: Inclusive Information for Trans* Persons
Affiliations: University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jardine, F.M., University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States
Abstract: This article articulates the numerous barriers that limit library use by trans* persons and explains practical ways these barriers can be eliminated so that trans* patrons can get the information and insights they want and need. The article also includes worksheets that library professionals can use to address trans* patrons' information issues and provide inclusive information services. © Fiona M. Jardine.
Author Keywords: defining trans* terminology; gender information issues; inclusive information; trans* person information needs; transsexual information issues

Title: Collaborative Libraries: Can We Do and Measure "Things" Differently?
Affiliations: Library and Community Information Services, Rockdale City, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Norman, M., Library and Community Information Services, Rockdale City, Australia
Abstract: This article explores library collaboration and how we measure our collaborative successes. Collaboration is a way to do library work differently in order to do more for a library's communities. Collaboration requires institutional effort, but it benefits constituents, participating organizations, and their staff. When we undertake collaboration, we must measure our work differently. Such measurement helps us know that we are making a positive difference in the lives of our constituents. © Mark Norman.
Author Keywords: collaboration; community benefit; cooperation; library budgets; library suppliers; Maker Spaces; outsourcing; public libraries; shelf-ready

Title: Older Adults and the Public Library: The Impact of the Boomer Generation
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bennett-Kapusniak, R., University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI, United States
Abstract: This article reports an investigation of older-adult services at fifty public libraries to determine if public libraries are providing services to the growing older-adult population and if any are guided by the American Library Association Guidelines for Older Adults 2008 and Institute of Museum and Library Services 2008 strategies for lifelong learning. The results indicate that few programs target older adults, although 74 percent offered lifelong learning opportunities. Thirty-two percent offered basic computer programs and less than 50 percent of the libraries provided assistive technologies. Future research should determine if other libraries provide for this diversified age group. © Renee Bennett-Kapusniak.
Author Keywords: American Library Association; boomer generation; Institute of Museum and Library Services; older-adult services and programming; survey of boomer services

Title: Knowing Communities: A Review of Community Assessment Literature
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI, United States
Authors with affiliations: McCleer, A., University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Milwaukee, WI, United States
Abstract: Since the late 1800s library and information science (LIS) publications have discussed community assessment as a process for librarians to acknowledge the distinct needs and interests of their communities and respond by meeting those needs. The varied publications on the topic do not authorize any community assessment model or conceptual framework as the professional standard. This literature review examines community assessment publications, primarily in LIS. Instructional resources and publications provide a variety of suggestions for methods of conducting community assessments, while case studies illustrate the successes and challenges of various methods. Librarians must continue community engagement and advance cultural awareness in community assessment © Adriana McCleer.
Author Keywords: analysis; assessment of communities; community assessment; cultural awareness; engagement; survey

Title: Impact of the Public Library District Model on Local Funding of Public Libraries in New York State
Affiliations: Department of Information Studies, College of Computing and Information, University at Albany, State University of New York, 135 Western Avenue, Albany, NY 12222, United States
Authors with affiliations: Elliott, M., Department of Information Studies, College of Computing and Information, University at Albany, State University of New York, 135 Western Avenue, Albany, NY 12222, United States
Abstract: For more than a decade the Regents of the State of New York have recommended that public and association libraries in the state become public library districts with independent taxing authority. The Regents contend that such districts are preferable for several reasons, in particular for more reliable and higher per capita funding for library services. This study, using data provided by the New York State Education Department, examined the funding of all public libraries in New York during a ten-year period. The study found that while public library districts did demonstrate more reliable funding over time, they did not see improved per capita funding as compared to other library types found in the state. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: library districts; library funding; New York libraries; public libraries; taxes

Title: Volunteer Utilization Report Prepared for Future of the Library Task Force of the Charlotte Mecklenburg Library, 2010
Affiliations: Charlotte Mecklenburg Library, 310 N. Tryon Street, Charlotte, NC 28202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Beach, K., Charlotte Mecklenburg Library, 310 N. Tryon Street, Charlotte, NC 28202, United States
Abstract: The author has prepared a planning document on how her library system can use volunteers as one strategy for keeping libraries open in the face of severe budget cuts by the county government that provides most of the library's funding. The document is addressed to the Future of the Library Task Force, the planning group that makes policy recommendations to governance officials. The author also estimates the number of volunteers and the number of hours they will contribute as Charlotte Mecklenburg Library works to implement the plan. These calculations generate several tables with information about volunteer activities within the system to provide the planners with sufficient information to make appropriate decisions. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: budget cuts; planning; service reductions; staff utilization; volunteer utilization

Title: Free to Learn: Helping Ex-Offenders with Reentry
Affiliations: Denver Public Library, 10 W. 14th Avenue Parkway, Denver, CO 80204, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morris, J., Denver Public Library, 10 W. 14th Avenue Parkway, Denver, CO 80204, United States
Abstract: Denver Public Library has taken an active role in providing services for people who have served time in prison or jail. The program Free to Learn focuses on providing resources and training to help ex-offenders with entering or reentering the workforce. Educating library staff on how to help felons also plays a critical role in the success of the program. This article provides information on how Denver Public Library helps ex-offenders apply for a job and respond to "the felony question.". © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Denver Public Library; employment assistance; ex-offenders; felons; Free to Learn; jail; job hunting; prison

Title: Free Public Libraries Charging for Survival
Affiliations: James Solomon Russell Memorial Library, Saint Paul's College, 115 College Drive, Lawrenceville, VA 23868, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alexander, O.D., James Solomon Russell Memorial Library, Saint Paul's College, 115 College Drive, Lawrenceville, VA 23868, United States
Abstract: This article is introduced with a brief account of the historical development of free public libraries in the United States. This is necessary to set the stage for sound reasoning for charging for products and services in today's vanishing public library systems. To be sure, these libraries are closing everywhere because of the lack of proper funding for survival, and charging a small fee has been debated continuously for the survival of these cultural, social, and informational centers. This is not only a problem throughout the United States but also globally. There are a few public libraries that are investigating this strategy to further serve library customers. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: economic infrastructure; entrepreneurship; free public libraries; public funding

Title: Learning Sites, References, and Notes: Compiled By The Editors
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: New York State Public Library Systems and Their Services
Affiliations: University at Albany, Albany, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ren, X., University at Albany, Albany, NY, United States
Abstract: This research revisited the conditions for establishing and funding public library systems in New York State Education Law and the Regulations of the Commissioner of Education, examined public library systems' organizational mission statements, and analyzed the public library systems' 2007-2011 five-year Plans of Service and 2008-2009 annual reports. The study found that public library systems in New York State generally provide services following the instructions in the state law and regulations and in their mission statements, although there are wide-ranging variations of actual service activities among public library systems based on their organizational and demographic characteristics. © 2013 Copyright Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: laws affecting public libraries; library cooperation; New York State public library systems; public library systems; resource sharing

Title: A Future-Oriented Budget Narrative for the King County Library System: A Presentation and an Analysis
Authors with affiliations: Holt, G.E.
Abstract: This article is a presentation and analysis of the 2012 budget narrative of the King County (Washington) Library System, the winner of LJ/Cengage's 2011 Library of the Year Award. The author's narrative analyzes both the language and character of this important budget document, demonstrating its place in the appropriate library function of building its relationship with its various constituencies. © 2013 Copyright Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: budget analysis; budgeting; King County (WA) Library System; outcomes

Title: Public Libraries as Post-Crisis Information Hubs
Affiliations: University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bishop, B.W., University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, United States; Veil, S.R., University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, United States
Abstract: Like the crisis responses to hurricanes, after a tornadic event public libraries play emergency roles both in the short and long term. Community members rely on public libraries for Internet access to request aid, to help find missing family and friends, to file Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and insurance claims, and, in general, to begin rebuilding their lives. This article reports the quality of services and activities public libraries performed in response and recovery in twelve different communities impacted by tornadoes. The discussion includes an evaluation of the quality of the responses and some recommendations to improve preparedness and response. © 2013 Copyright Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: community preparedness; crisis; disaster; emergency management; public libraries

Title: Public Libraries and PBS Partnering to Enhance Civic Engagement: A Study of a Nationwide Initiative
Affiliations: Pratt Institute School of Information and Library Science, 144 W. 14th Street, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10011, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cocciolo, A., Pratt Institute School of Information and Library Science, 144 W. 14th Street, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10011, United States
Abstract: This project asks the question: Can libraries act as places for promoting civic engagement through the use of socially and culturally significant documentaries? In this initiative, documentaries are screened at public libraries throughout the United States and are followed by post-screening discussions. Coordinating librarians and audience attendees are surveyed to uncover the outcomes of each event's civic engagement. Results indicate that the screening of socially and cultural significant documentaries at public libraries, combined with post-screening discussions, can positively impact library patrons' interest in becoming more civically engaged and foster a greater understanding of the issues raised by the films. © 2013 Copyright Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: civic engagement; documentary film; public libraries; public television

Title: Value-Added Librarianship: Creating It in Our Services and in the Infrastructure upon Which We Rely
Affiliations: CARE Affiliates, Blacksburg, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grant, C., CARE Affiliates, Blacksburg, VA, United States
Abstract: Librarianship is facing big challenges. Technology and, in particular, cloud computing are making the role of librarians as information intermediaries more transparent to the point that we risk vanishing from the process. This article examines what the mission of librarianship should be in this environment, how we differentiate ourselves from other information suppliers, and how we ensure that the values of librarianship are embedded and preserved when using technology. © 2013 Copyright Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: analytics; cloud computing; discovery platforms; librarianship; library services platforms

Title: Rainy Day Statistics: U.S. Public Libraries and the Great Recession
Affiliations: not available, 4195 W. 59th Street, Cleveland, OH 44144, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lyons, R., not available, 4195 W. 59th Street, Cleveland, OH 44144, United States
Abstract: During and after the Great Recession, U.S. public library advocacy messages focused on cuts in funding and significantly increased utilization of services, particularly technology services. This article analyzes quantitative evidence appearing in advocacy materials and offers alternative data for evaluating the validity of claims made in such materials. For the most part, summary statistical accounts of the experiences of public libraries during the recession paint an incomplete picture. It is suggested that portraying U.S. libraries in general as "doing more with less" is a considerable overstatement since the majority of libraries had funding increases in the aftermath of the recession. Only 23 percent of all U.S. public libraries delivered more services while simultaneously experiencing funding decreases. The article recommends that library advocacy campaigns strive to present accurate, balanced, and complete information in their promotional materials. © 2013 Copyright Published with license by Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: data variation; data visualization; economic effects on library utilization; histograms; libraries and recessions; library advocacy; library funding cuts; library utilization; quantitative evidence; scatter plots; statistical graphs; summary statistics

Title: Frail, Fatal, Fundamental: The Future of Public Libraries
Affiliations: Library and Community Information Services, Rockdale City, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Norman, M., Library and Community Information Services, Rockdale City, Australia
Abstract: Public libraries will survive and thrive by recognizing their changing roles. With the digital world of content, the role is shifting to that of content aggregators, access managers, and educators in digital literacy.
