Title: Public libraries and internet public access models: Describing possible approaches
Affiliations: Information Use Management and Policy Institute, School of Information Studies, Department of Communication, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, 32306-1531, United States; Information Use Management and Policy Institute, School of Information Studies, Florida State University, Louis Shores Building, Room 226, Tallahassee, FL, 32306-2100, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tomasello, T.K., Information Use Management and Policy Institute, School of Information Studies, Department of Communication, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, 32306-1531, United States; McClure, C.R., Information Use Management and Policy Institute, School of Information Studies, Florida State University, Louis Shores Building, Room 226, Tallahassee, FL, 32306-2100, United States
Abstract: Numerous approaches to providing Internet access to the general public are currently being implemented in the United States in an attempt to increase access to and use of networked services; however, research presenting an overview of these approaches is scarce. This article presents eight models in use–public schools, public libraries, cybermobiles, public housing, community technology centers, community networks, kiosks, and cyber cafés–and analyzes them using a common set of criteria to better illustrate the strengths and limitations of each. The article concludes by suggesting that public libraries may wish to develop collaborative strategies working with other organizations to increase Internet public access for disadvantaged groups. © 2002 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Community networks; Community technology centers; Cyber cafés; Cybermobiles; Digital divide; Internet public access; Kiosks; Public housing; Public libraries; Public schools

Title: The library in 2100
Affiliations: Robert Van Houten Library, New Jersey Institute of Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sweeney, R.T., Robert Van Houten Library, New Jersey Institute of Technology, United States
Abstract: Richard Sweeney is an active member of the Information Futures Institute, a group of librarians and persons interested in libraries and information that meet twice a year in different parts of the country. At a meeting in the Spring of 2002, a question was posed to Mr. Sweeney and others: Does library have a place in 2100? Richard Sweeney has peered into his crystal ball, and offers his view of the world of libraries when we next celebrate a new millennium. © 2002 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: 3-D virtual environments; Artificial intelligence; Books; Community centers; Future; Human intelligence; Robots

Title: Building a statewide digital public library: A case study
Affiliations: Information Use Management and Policy Institute, School of Information Studies, Florida State University, Bertot Information Management Consultant Services, Inc, Shores Building, Tallahassee, FL, 32306, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bertot, J.C., Information Use Management and Policy Institute, School of Information Studies, Florida State University, Bertot Information Management Consultant Services, Inc, Shores Building, Tallahassee, FL, 32306, United States
Abstract: This article presents the results of a study undertaken for the state library of Maryland to develop a process, identify approaches, and identify considerations for the development of a Maryland Digital Public Library (MDPL). The article provides insights into the planning, management, and implementation requirements for such an undertaking that can apply to both individual public library digitization projects as well as regional and statewide digitization efforts. The article offers a framework for creating a statewide digital public library, identifies issues, and makes recommendations that public libraries, state library agencies, and others should consider when considering the development of digital public library content and services. © 2002 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: A comparative examination of public library fundraising

Authors with affiliations: Ashman, A.B., Kentucky Union List of Serials, Ekstom Library, University of Louisville, LL57, Louisville, KY, 40292, United States
Abstract: This study compares the results of three national surveys of fundraising in public libraries with the results of a survey done of public libraries in Kentucky. This comparison is placed within the context of the library literature. Results show that libraries are increasingly conducting fundraising activities and that in spite of reservations raised in the literature, Friends groups often perform these efforts. Library foundations and Friends groups are most prevalent in large library systems and these systems are also the most likely to raise funds. Obstacles identified by library directors are noted as are their experiences with the relationship between private and public dollars. © 2002 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: First in a series: A review of books and newsletters on the art of getting money from others
Affiliations: Providence Associates Inc., Library Planners Consultants, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waters, R.L., Providence Associates Inc., Library Planners Consultants, United States
Abstract: There are now dozens, perhaps hundreds, of books and newsletters published every year that are about fund-raising, grantsmanship, non-profit management, and the like. An organization could easily spend several hundred dollars acquiring all of the available literature. This article is not an “all inclusive” review of the fund-raising literature, but rather a survey of some of the better writings–including a few of the di-rectories–on a most important topic. If you acquire all, or many, of the titles listed–and then keep current with the new editions as appropriate–you will have yourself and your library a very good collection from which to draw upon as you pursue moneys from the private sector to supplement your tax-supported budget. Part I reviews books; Part II takes a look at newsletters and Websites. © 2002 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: America’s front porch–the public library

Abstract: The public library is more important than ever before as a centering institution, as a place of gathering, and as an equalizer, but the public library cannot build community by itself. The problems are simply too great. The library needs partners and it needs a place at the community planning, policy making, and development table. There needs to be collaborating and forming partnerships and alliances. If public libraries really want to have effective partnerships and make a difference in their communities they have to be part of the decision-making process in those communities. They have to be at the table with other organizations and government agencies. They have to be involved in giving and getting assets for the common good of the community. © 2002 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

It also analyzes the extent of integration between websites and print advertisements in six major U.S. magazines. The findings suggest that marketers are not using all possible benefits of their websites. Furthermore, the study reveals a lack of integration between print and online advertising. Many of the identified weaknesses seem to be influenced by applying traditional advertising strategies to the dynamic web environment, while ignoring the unique features of the medium’s interactive nature. © 2001 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Title: Users and uses of the public library reading rooms
Affiliations: Department of Information Science, Bar-Ilan University, 5901 NW 63rd, Ramat-Gan, 52900, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shoham, S., Department of Information Science, Bar-Ilan University, 5901 NW 63rd, Ramat-Gan, 52900, Israel
Abstract: The study examines the demographic profile of reading-room users in urban public libraries in Israel, as well as their patterns of use. The primary purpose of use of the reading rooms is study, whereas the library plays almost no role in the locating of job-related information. The largest group of users consists of high school students; the second largest is made up of college and university students. Reading-room users in public libraries are either high school students (in the course of obtaining a high school education) or people with postsecondary education. Most of the reading-room users were not subscribers to the library's lending service; that is, the reading rooms serve a different clientele. Browsing and consulting the librarians are the main channels for locating library materials, whereas very little use is made of the catalog. © 2001 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Browsing; College and university students; Consulting librarians; Demographics; High school students; Reading rooms; Urban public libraries; Users

Title: Moving a library collection

Authors with affiliations: Cash, D., Warr Acres Public Library, 5901 NW 63rd, Warr Acres, OK, 73132, United States
Abstract: The key to a smooth library relocation is planning. Experts in moving library collections recommend when and which items to move, determining collection size for proper shelving, the personnel, library services during the move, handling and transporting the collection, and communication. In its recent move, the Fort Smith Public Library had a serious breach with the experts and moved when the new building was not finished. There were other less serious problems with inter-building communication and shelf measurements. These incidents should serve as a wake-up call for libraries planning a move. © 2001 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Collection measurement; Collection relocation; Collection transportation; Inter-library communication; Moving a collection

Title: Marketing practical information
Affiliations: Tacoma Public Library, Tacoma, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pankl, R.R., Tacoma Public Library, Tacoma, WA, United States
Abstract: Providing practical information, which can be valued monetarily and enhances the economic well being of those who use it, is an important function of the public library. Most public libraries, however, do not aggressively market this niche. Precedence is given to marketing the library as an educational and cultural institution. This role has had a long and dominant history. Traditionally, public perceptions of the library and other factors have made it difficult to broaden library marketing to focus on other information segments. Over time, this bias erodes the viability and relevance of the public library since other organizations usurp the niche. Methods for broadening the library's marketing focus to include practical information are outlined. © 2001 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cultural; Do-it-yourself; Economic; Educational; Librarians; Marketing; Measurable; Niche; Promotions; Public libraries; Reading; Segment

Title: Informational picture books in the library: Do young children find them?
Affiliations: Master of Library and Information Studies, University of Alberta, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Larkin-Lieffers, P.A., Master of Library and Information Studies, University of Alberta, Canada
Abstract: Ten public libraries were surveyed to evaluate access for young children, aged 4 ½ to 6 years, to age appropriate informational picture books. Location of books, types of shelving, and displays were noted for both fiction and informational books, and unobtrusive observations of young children browsing were conducted in three of the libraries. The findings confirmed children's preference for books in eye level face front shelving in high traffic areas especially near the children's area seating; most children did not explore far from parents. Visits by children to hardcover fiction, paperback fiction, and paperback informational picture books, were balanced. However, hardcover informational picture books were missed due to less accessible locations, oversize shelving, and fewer displays. The role of accompanying parents in finding materials was pivotal. Improving access for young children to a wide variety of books in their public libraries supports both recreational and educational needs, and needs to be considered in library layout. © 2001 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Book access; Fiction; Five year olds; Kindergarten; Library design; Nonfiction; Public library

Title: Identification of competencies for professional staff of public libraries
Affiliations: School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore; National Library Board of Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Chaudhry, A.S., School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore; Yeen, L., National Library Board of Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: This study identified and validated competencies required for public library professionals by seeking the views of public librarians themselves. Competencies relating to management and customer service received high ratings, while traditional competencies related to reference service and collection management seemed much lower in importance. In addition, technological competencies also did not seem to be a priority among public library staff in Singapore. Experienced public librarians who had formal library education and were in managerial positions required significantly different sets of competencies as compared with inexperienced librarians who had no formal library qualifications, particularly those who were not holding management positions at the time of the study. These differing competencies were usually those required for higher level management and planning work. © 2001 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Competencies; Modern library professional; Public librarian

Abstract: More than two years ago a controversy developed over planned murals on the downtown Albuquerque Public Library. The issue was finally resolved when artists, the architect and city officials compromised: the murals were painted on panels that were attached to the walls of the library building. Title: Public library records: Issues of accountability and access
Affiliations: University of Pittsburgh, School of Information Sciences, United States; University of Pittsburgh Digital Research Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yakel, E., University of Pittsburgh, School of Information Sciences, United States; Colligan, C.A., University of Pittsburgh Digital Research Library, United States
Abstract: Recordkeeping is a main form of institutional accountability. As municipal institutions, public libraries have a special need to be accountable to the public. Twenty-six public libraries participated in a survey of their recordkeeping practices. The authors found a wide variety of extant paper and electronic records. However, libraries reported few policies governing the management of or access to records. Librarians responding to the survey indicated an overall lack of knowledge concerning records-related legislation, such as the Right-to-Know legislation, that is increasingly being used by citizens to request public library records. These findings indicate that public libraries need to better understand best practices for recordkeeping. © 2001 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Accountability; Electronic records; Freedom of information; Public libraries; Recordkeeping; Right-to-know legislation

Title: Public libraries facilities in Pakistan
Affiliations: Department of L I S, University of Karachi, 75270, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Haider, S.J., Department of L I S, University of Karachi, 75270, Pakistan
Abstract: Pakistan is in dire need of a functioning public library system. A profile of the country of Pakistan, and a history of the library in Pakistan, is offered. Pakistan’s literacy rate is one of the lowest in the world: 37 percent. In rural areas, it is 27 percent; in urban areas, 58 percent. Literacy is defined by the government as the ability to write one’s name in any one of Pakistan's languages or in English. The general library history is short-lived. The current system needs much improvement. The author identifies five major factors responsible for the unsatisfactory state of affairs of Pakistan’s public libraries. © 2001 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: General library history; Lack of progression; Literacy rate; No library of significance

Case studies of LSTA program implementation through state library agencies were conducted in four states. These states chose to implement several different types of programs. The results of these case studies, comparison of state programs, and evaluation of the states’ LSTA plans and projects are presented. © 2001 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Rural libraries— a comparative study in four states of India
Affiliations: Centre on Rural Documentation, National Institute of Rural Development, Rajendranagar, Hyderabad, 500 030, India
Authors with affiliations: Takalkar, A., Centre on Rural Documentation, National Institute of Rural Development, Rajendranagar, Hyderabad, 500 030, India; Devi, T.R., Centre on Rural Documentation, National Institute of Rural Development, Rajendranagar, Hyderabad, 500 030, India
Abstract: The role information plays in socio-economic development can not be over-emphasized. People need different types of information in their day-to-day life and their information seeking behaviour also differs from person to person. In India, 70 percent of the population lives in rural areas. The access the rural population has to information sources is very limited. Libraries, in addition to other sources, form a major source of information. However, the libraries in rural areas, as observed from earlier studies, are traditional in nature and not well equipped to effectively cater to the information needs of the rural people. Non-existence of library legislation in various states of India is one of the factors which adversely affected the development of a library system. This present study examines the status of rural libraries in four states of India, the information needs of the people in the study area, and their information seeking behaviour. The study also examines the role of the latest IT techniques in improving the present status of rural libraries. This study concludes that the libraries existing presently in rural areas are in a poor state of affairs. Lack of adequate resources, financial and human, is identified as the major reason for the present status of rural libraries. As far as information needs, a majority of respondents look for information relating to development schemes, employment opportunities, education, health, etc. Mass media including newspaper, TV, and radio are the major sources of information, followed by relatives/friends, and government officials. This study suggests the transformation of existing libraries or establishing a new set up of dynamic information centres with the help of the latest IT to effectively cater to the information needs of the rural people. © 2001 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Andhra pradesh; Case study; India; Information needs; Information sources; Information use behaviour; Kerala; Madhya pradesh; Orissa; Public libraries; Rural libraries

Abstract: What role does participation in leadership development programs have on involvement in leadership activities for public librarians? In order to begin to address this issue, participants in the Snowbird Leadership Institute were surveyed regarding their involvement in leadership activities and about their perceptions regarding the impact of the leadership development experience on their careers. While it is difficult to identify a direct relationship between participation in a leadership development program and greater participation in leadership activities, the respondents report increased levels of the types of leadership activity that are described in the literature as important for public libraries. © 2001 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Leadership; Leadership development; Public libraries

Title: Take me out to the ball game: A compendium of books about America's pastime
Authors with affiliations: Waters, B.
Abstract: Judging from the ratings for the 2000 World Series between the Yankees (they won again) and the Mets, one could question the premise that baseball is “America's Pastime.” If you look at the publishing of sports books, there is no question that there are a dozen or more books published about one aspect or another of baseball compared to any other sport -perhaps all other sports combined. Here is a compendium of 28 books about baseball, plus two others that feature baseball players and others associated with the game. This article is intended to prick your interest in the game, to perhaps re-kindle a passion you have lost, and to look forward every spring to “Play Ball!” © 2001 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Children's Librarians: A Research Study of Diversity and Leadership
Affiliations: School of Communication, Information, and Library Studies, Rutgers University, 4 Huntington Street, New Brunswick, NJ, 08901, United States; School of Communication, Information, and Library Studies, Rutgers University, 4 Huntington Street, New Brunswick, NJ, 08901, United States

Abstract: Leadership and diversity are two of the most important and perplexing issues facing those in public libraries. While the literature related to public libraries addresses these issues to a limited extent, this article considers the issues in the context of the specialty of children's librarianship. Librarians with responsibilities for children's services were surveyed regarding their demographic, educational and professional backgrounds, their prior experience in working with children, their career plans, and their professional responsibilities. Particular consideration has been given to issues emerging in this research in relation to diversity and leadership. The results of this study indicate a professional population, characterized by underrepresentation, but with a mix of educational backgrounds. In addition, the respondents have indicated an interest in working with children, even prior to entering the profession and the specialty, and fulfill numerous professional responsibilities related to children's services and reflecting their interest in leadership and career progression. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Adopt-a-Dewey
Affiliations: City Librarian, Ojai Library, 111 Ojai Avenue, Ojai, CA, 93023, United States
Authors with affiliations: Willis, K.K., City Librarian, Ojai Library, 111 Ojai Avenue, Ojai, CA, 93023, United States
Abstract: The Ojai Library, a busy branch of Ventura County Library near Santa Barbara, California, started a program called “Adopt-a-Dewey.” Inspired by the Camden County (NJ) Library's program “Adopt-a-Shelf,” the Ojai Library originated the Adopt-a-Dewey name for the program that enlists volunteers for an hour a week to take a Dewey Decimal section of books to keep in order and lined up neatly. The volunteer-run program filled up in three weeks despite minimal publicity. The implementation of the program at Ojai has boosted the morale of library staff and improved the looks of library shelves, ac-cordingtoKit Willis, City Librarian. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Are Libraries (and Librarians) Kaput?
Affiliations: Library Consultants, 417 East High Street, Milton, WI, 53563, United States
Authors with affiliations: Himmel, E.E., Library Consultants, 417 East High Street, Milton, WI, 53563, United States; Wilson, W.J., Library Consultants, 417 East High Street, Milton, WI, 53563, United States
Abstract: Public, academic, and special libraries-and librarians-and their future are discussed. Public libraries, as vibrant community services and institutions, may have a future. Public libraries will continue to subsidize access to print, to electronic resources, and to the Internet. They will provide increased programs supporting continuing self-education and cultural opportunities. They will add greater meeting and network access space, reduce (but not eliminate) shelving space. Highly trained specialists offering services customized to user needs will be r equir ed. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Helping public library patrons find medical information-the reference interview
Affiliations: Consumer Health Outreach Coordinator, Southeastern Atlantic Region, National Network of Libraries of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Allcock, J.C., Consumer Health Outreach Coordinator, Southeastern Atlantic Region, National Network of Libraries of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States
Abstract: Public libraries are often the first access point for additional information resources on health and medical topics. We, as librarians, must be aware of our role in the information seeking process, and communicate with the patron effectively in order to direct them to appropriate resources. Particular attention must be given in the reference interview, including adequate follow-up support and consideration for protecting confidentiality. This paper discusses elements of the reference interview and describes measures that can be taken to avoid personal liability while directing patrons to health information resources. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Liability; Reference; Reference interview

Title: HealthWeb: Both a resource for public librarians and a prototype for collaboration among libraries

Authors with affiliations: Scherrer, C.S., Information Services, University of Illinois at Chicago, Library of the Health Sciences, 1750 W. Polk (m/c 763), Chicago, IL, 60612, United States
Abstract: Organizing and evaluating information available to library patrons on the Internet is a constant challenge for librarians. Academic health sciences librarians faced this challenge in an innovative and collaborative way when trying to organize and evaluate web sites providing medical information. Their project, called HealthWeb, can serve both as a prototype for public librarians trying to organize sites in other subject areas, and as a resource for patrons looking for high quality medical information available on the Internet. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Collaboration; Health information; HealthWeb; Internet; Reference

Title: HIV/AIDS information in public libraries: A “common ground” approach to service delivery and focus on select resources
Affiliations: Information Services, Arizona Health Sciences Library, The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Perry, G., Information Services, Arizona Health Sciences Library, The University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, United States
Abstract: Despite well-publicized advances in the development of antiretroviral therapies, HIV infection remains an incurable condition. Worldwide, the disease threatens to gravely impact a wide range of developing nations, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa, South and Southeast Asia and South America. In the United States, the poor and particularly women of color are at great, and increasing, risk for infection. Public libraries, as trusted public institutions for the dissemination of information, can continue to play an important role in promoting public health information surrounding HIV/AIDS prevention and education. Public libraries are not immune, however, to the political and value-driven public discourse surrounding HIV infection. Through carefully identifying the issues, taking a nonjudgmental service approach, and building collaborations with community based organizations, public libraries can become common ground for providing proactive prevention-focused information services. This article examines the current state of epidemic HIV/AIDS infection, reviews the literature on public library responses, and identifies highly select consumer health and biomedical monographic, serial, audio-visual and Web-based HIV/AIDS information tools. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Acquired immune deficiency syndrome; AIDS; Collection development; HIV; Human immunodeficiency virus

Title: Are information seekers and users among the general public at a crossroads?: An examination of the quantity of consumer health publications on eating disorders in popular magazines and on the internet in 1998
Affiliations: School of Library and Information, San José State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tu, F., School of Library and Information, San José State University, United States
Abstract: Presently, eating disorders affect millions of people. Today, the media and the Internet are major publishing channels for consumer health information. Much research has found that the media may offer insufficient information on eating disorders. This research examines the quantity of adult consumer health publications on eating disorders in magazine articles and on the Internet in 1998 and investigates the effectiveness of Internet search engines. The results indicate that the resources found in popular magazines and on the Internet are not adequate, and that the Internet search engines are not effective in searching for information. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Consumer health information; Eating disorders; Information needs and uses; Internet; Internet search engines; Popular magazines

Title: NOAH (New York online access to health): Accurate, timely, unbiased, bilingual
Affiliations: The New York Academy of Medicine, United States; Middle Atlantic Region, National Network of Libraries of Medicine, The New York Academy of Medicine, and Spanish Health Topics Content Editor, NOAH, United States; Long Island University, Brooklyn Campus, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gallagher, P.E., The New York Academy of Medicine, United States; Markovich, K., Middle Atlantic Region, National Network of Libraries of Medicine, The New York Academy of Medicine, and Spanish Health Topics Content Editor, NOAH, United States; Neri, R., Long Island University, Brooklyn Campus, United States
Abstract: NOAH (New York Online Access to Health) is a Web site developed by four library partner organizations, in an effort to provide timely, accurate and unbiased health information to the health consumers in New York City in both English and Spanish. Since expanded to include two other partner organizations, NOAH continues, with the help of volunteer librarians, to expand and enhance the site, always with the mission to provide full-text health information in the most user-friendly method possible. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Consumer health; Internet; World Wide Web

Title: Reference librarians' attitudes towards the world wide web
Affiliations: School of Library, Archival, and Information Studies, University of British Columbia, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Curry, A., School of Library, Archival, and Information Studies, University of British Columbia, Canada; Harris, G.J.E., School of Library, Archival, and Information Studies, University of British Columbia, Canada
Abstract: The rapid growth and widespread publicity about the World Wide Web has many implications for public reference librarians, but little is known about this group's attitudes towards the World Wide Web and the impact of the Web on reference work. Using face-to-face interviews, this study gathered data on the attitudes of reference librarians working within a large British Columbia public library consortium, focusing on how these information professionals feel about integrating the Web into their duties. The responses indicate that the librarians believe the Web has had a positive effect on their work with regard to efficiency and answer rates, but they still have serious concerns about accuracy of Web information, technical problems, and demands on them for customer training. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Public libraries; Reference service; World Wide Web

Title: The effect of the economic environment on collection development: Ramat library experience
Affiliations: Deputy University Librarian, Public Services, Ramat Library, University of Maiduguri, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Akinnigbagbe, B.M., Deputy University Librarian, Public Services, Ramat Library, University of Maiduguri, Nigeria
Abstract: About 90% of the academic books published in the world are published outside Africa, therefore African libraries rely on the western world for most of their library materials. This has been a major constraint to collection development in view of the foreign exchange restrictions made worse by the economic depression and the foreign exchange deregulation policy. Blackwells and Heffers in United Kingdom are their major book suppliers. A substantial part of the library materials budget of African libraries should be made available in foreign exchange to enable the libraries to procure the necessary books, periodicals, and other non-print materials from abroad. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Budgeting; Collection development; Economic development; World-wide publishing

Title: Fate of central cities remains precarious
Affiliations: Dallas Morning News, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nagorka, J., Dallas Morning News, United States
Abstract: The future of central cities remains in serious jeopardy, even with a booming economy. Big city populations, for example, are decreasing while suburban America is growing. Part of the solution might be found in how state and federal infrastructure dollars are shared. Yet state and federal reform alone won't solve the decline. The author suggests a number of ways to merge central city resources and government reform to bring about renewal. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Affiliations: Health Learning Center Coordinator, Northwestern Memorial Hospital, Chicago, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gillaspy, M.L., Health Learning Center Coordinator, Northwestern Memorial Hospital, Chicago, IL, United States
Abstract: More people than ever before are seeking information about health topics. Many of them turn to public libraries and librarians to assist them with their inquiries. Since most public librarians do not have a specialty in medical information, actually establishing a consumer health service can be a daunting task. This article outlines a step-by-step guide for planning and implementing such a service. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Partnerships, an important trend in providing library services, introduce the library to new users and build support for the library. “Developing Grassroots Partnerships in Your Community” discusses the process and benefits of proactively building new community linkages and leveraging existing affiliations. Based on the experience of Broward County Library, selected as “Library of the Year” by Gale Research/Library Journal in 1996 (primarily based on its successful partnership initiatives), the article provides 5 recommendations on how other libraries might go about building community alliances. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Title: Suburbs' growing problems may lead to cities' salvation
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Overholser, G., United States
Abstract: It has been said that there must be a breakdown before there can be a breakthrough. If true, America's suburbs might lead the way toward city renewal. Because problems know no boundaries, suburbs are now facing what cities have known for decades. Growth and change eventually cause pain. The author, with insight from a political thinker and worker, suggests that this might bring suburbs and cities together in a joint partnership. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Etiology of blindness: An overview of and selected resources for librarians
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Studies, Texas Woman�s University, Denton, TX, United States; Harris Methodist Health Sciences Library, Fort Worth, TX, United States

Abstract: Focusing on one area of medical concern, blindness, this article serves as a guide for print and electronic resources emphasizing the causes, signs, symptoms, treatment, prognosis, and prevention of specific eye diseases and disorders. Following a bibliography format, the selected resources include: (1) medical dictionaries, (2) medical and consumer health print resources, (3) medical journals, (4) brochures, (5) professional organizations, and (6) Web sites. This paper concludes with the abbreviated definitions of the predominant eye diseases leading to visual impairment and blindness. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors with affiliations: Grosman, M.J., Area-Wide Library Services, St. Joseph Health System, Greater Sonoma County, United States, Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital Cancer Library, Health Resource Center, Santa Rosa, CA, United States
Abstract: The Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital Cancer Library and Health Resource Center was developed to create a community resource for access to cancer information. The Cancer Library provides the means for patients and families to obtain information about diagnosis and treatment, local and electronic support groups and the latest information dealing with the physical and psychological pressures of a cancer diagnosis. This public consumer health library in Northern California not only supports cancer patients and their families, but also supports the medical community that cares for them. The development, staffing, funding, materials, services, and outreach programs of this two-year-old consumer health library are discussed. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors with affiliations: Streeter, M., Lincoln Humanities/Communications Magnet High School, Dallas, TX, United States, School of Library and Information Studies, Texas Woman's University, Denton, TX, United States
Abstract: Organized especially for students, parents, and guardians of Lincoln High School in Dallas, Texas, this pathfinder includes fiction and nonfiction books with helpful information on the research, diagnosis, and treatment of diabetes. Fiction is added for leisurely entertainment and comparison to reality. Care and self-help informational books; low-fat, high-fiber recipe books; and magazines especially for diabetics are given. It provides Internet web sites, periodicals, and organizations targeting diabetic pre-teens, and young adults. Information about diabetes can be used by anyone, but because of the high percentage of non-white's affected by this disease, this publication gives additional information that focuses on diabetes and race/ethnicity. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Title: The order of the public library and the disorder of attention deficit
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Studies, Texas Woman�s University, United States; Emily Fowler Central Public Library, 502 Oakland, Denton, TX, 76201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Akin, L., School of Library and Information Studies, Texas Woman�s University, United States; O�Toole, E., Emily Fowler Central Public Library, 502 Oakland, Denton, TX, 76201, United States
Abstract: While the public library exists to serve a diverse clientele, one group often ignored consists of those with invisible challenges, such as attention deficit disorder (ADD) and attention deficit disorder with hyperactivity (ADHD), in children and adults. This article covers background information on ADD/ADHD, diagnostic criteria, and common characteristics of the disorder. The role of the public library in serving the ADD user is examined through needs assessment, training, programming, collection development, and continuing education for librarians. The public library can and should ensure that those who suffer from disordered attention skills benefit from the ordered knowledge at their local library. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Consumer health materials for lesbians, gay men, bisexual and transgendered people

Schwartz Department of Geriatrics and Adult Development, Box 1070, Mount Sinai Medical Center, One Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY, 10029-6574, United States
Abstract: This article identifies the major health challenges of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgendered (L/G/B/T) communities, pointing out that each is faced with stigma and discrimination in the search for healthcare. Members of these communities are thus more likely to seek out and consult services offered by public libraries which identify and disseminate consumer health and self-care information appropriate to their needs. The article concludes with a bibliography of current sources of information-both print and electronic-that will interest the L/G/B/T health consumer. © 2000 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Information access illiterate
Affiliations: Texas Tech University, United States; University of North Texas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weiner, R.G., Texas Tech University, United States, University of North Texas, United States
Abstract: Traditionally, librarians preserved and protected written records for the politically elite and wealthy classes. The Greeks, Romans, and Egyptians built up great libraries many of which were destroyed throughout history. When Christianity became the political force in Europe, the clergy continued to protect and collect materials. The beginnings of public libraries in Europe during the 1600s and in America during the middle of the nineteenth century, gave rise to a new literacy among the general population. The upsurge in technology threatens to spawn a new class of “information access illiterate.” Public libraries can serve the needs of society by giving access to, and providing educational literacy programs for using new technological tools to access information. © 2000 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Supervisory communication and subordinate job satisfaction: The relationship between superiors’ Self-Disclosure, Offers of help, Offers of cooperation, Frequency of contact, Trust and subordinates’ job satisfaction
Authors with affiliations: Bartlett, C.
Abstract: Five communication behaviors were tested to determine their relationship to subordinates' job satisfaction. Findings indicate that four of the five behaviors (offers of help, offers of cooperation, frequency of contact and trust) were substantially related to subordinates' job satisfaction. Personal self-disclosure was not found to be substantially related, although its task-focused dimension was related to subordinates' job satisfaction. © 2000 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Cooperation; Job satisfaction; Loyalty; Management styles; Trust

Title: A low tech answer to a high tech problem: The time shift plan (TSP)
Authors with affiliations: Lee, S.
Abstract: This article describes how to fairly allocate Internet Access Workstations once a library decides to have them. The various plans used by the San Francisco Main Library are discussed. After many trials and errors, the San Francisco Main Library has developed a low tech, low cost plan for equitably allocating Internet Access Workstations. Any library with one public Internet Terminal to fifty public Internet Terminals can use this plan. This plan benefits both staff and patrons by having a compromise in assuming responsibility for monitoring the stations. Computer programs used for this purpose are expensive and are only available from a handful of companies. The faults in these programs are discussed. © 2000 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Complaints; Internet; Internet use; Patron use of workstations; Staff efficiency

Title: Downsizing the public library: This is only the beginning
Affiliations: Clarion University, Clarion, PA, United States; Information Futures Institute, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vavrek, B., Clarion University, Clarion, PA, United States, Information Futures Institute, United States
Abstract: Now that the Internet has become a universal resource, it should not be a surprise to information specialists that fewer introductory reference questions are being asked in the library. The easy explanation is that, because of the wide variety of documents available on the Net, the average person (with proper connectivity) may be his or her own librarian. The response to this situation is provoking concern in the library community over developing new means of counting reference transactions and alerting staff to expect more detailed questions to be asked in the future. For someone looking for proof to validate the above, one can provide no more than anecdotal evidence. This, however, is really not crucial to the intent of this commentary. As a statement, it serves rather as a metaphor of things to come. The purpose of this essay is to suggest other ways in which library services -particularly those of the public library - are potentially being “downsized” because they are now a part of a networked environment, i.e., of the Internet. In fact, while the reader may find it an irritating question, one would ask whether or not public library provides any unique services that haven't already been snatched away” by the Internet? © 2000 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Information technology; Internet; Readers' advisory services; World Wide Web

Title: In support of public libraries
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, W.N.
Abstract: As the Clinton era draws to a close, it is far past time we realize what public libraries offer. We must reprioritize our short and long term goals to help public libraries flourish. We must dig ourselves out of the trenches. We must charge. The American public library is now more vital than ever. In order for our country not only to keep pace and survive, but to flower and thrive, we must unflinchingly support its endeavors. © 1999 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Public praise; Public support; Public vs. private; Service for children

Title: Changing roles of paraprofessionals in public libraries
Affiliations: National Library Board of Singapore, United States; School of Applied Science, Nanyang Technological University, Blk N4#2A-32, Nanyang Avenue, 639798, Singapore

Abstract: Roles and functions of paraprofessionals working in public libraries are surveyed and issues surrounding paraprofessionals as a result of the role change are reviewed. The effectiveness of handling new responsibilities and acquisition of new skills by paraprofessionals through training and other professional development means are examined. Suggestions are put forward for preparing paraprofessionals for the new responsibilities highlighting the need for more effective training. Further studies of the changing roles of paraprofessionals using more rigorous methodologies are proposed. © 1999 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The public library and the problem of hospital libraries for patients–the case of Israel
Affiliations: Department of Information Studies and Librarianship, Bar-Ilan University, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Baruchson-Arbib, S., Department of Information Studies and Librarianship, Bar-Ilan University, Israel
Abstract: Providing information to the health consumer is one of the main tasks of our modern information society. This information falls into two categories: medical information, and supportive information such as literature and poetry. This article discusses the problematic situation of libraries and of information for patients in Israeli hospitals, and raises the question of the public library being a possible solution to help people in need get the information they are entitled to. The conclusions are based on a survey conducted in 1994. The results are rather disappointing: only 26.3% of the hospitals have library services for patients; most of them are managed by volunteers who have no training in professional librarianship. Also, in terms of book acquisition policy, library activities, and criteria for lending books, most of the results indicate that much needs to be done to improve the situation and help the health consumer receive information and support through the library. As it is clear that the situation in hospitals is not going to change in the near future, it is suggested that the public library serve as a helping resource outside the hospital and by that action it would not only contribute to society but expand its functions and strengthen its position in the community. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Consumer health information; Hospital libraries; Hospitals; Literature; Medical information; Patient services; Poetry; Public library role; Social information

Title: Venturing from the closet: A qualitative study of the information needs of lesbians
Affiliations: University of Alberta, Canada; Library and Information Studies, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stenback, T.L., University of Alberta, Canada; Schrader, A.M., Library and Information Studies, United States
Abstract: Through personal interviews, this qualitative study sought to determine the information needs of a nonrandom sample of lesbian women during the process of coming out, as well as to gauge the effectiveness of the resources to which they turned for information. By exploring the questions and concerns that these women had while developing a lesbian identity, informational needs were identified. Results indicate that while public librarians have the opportunity–and indeed the obligation–to serve this group of potential customers, several barriers inhibit the effectiveness of the services provided. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Effectiveness; Females; Gays; Informational needs; Lesbians; Public library role

Title: Seeing is believing: Disparity of books in two los angeles area public libraries
Affiliations: University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Loyola Marymount University, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Di Loreto, C., University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Tse, L., Loyola Marymount University, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: Considering the abundant research that shows the link between access to books and reading ability, this investigation looks at the availability of books in two public libraries, one located in an upper-class neighborhood and the other in a working-class area, focusing specifically on the resources available to children and adolescents. An examination of the book and magazine holdings, the facilities, the reading programs offered, the staff available, and the funding provided reveal that significant disparities exist. Although Beverly Hills serves a community twice the size of Santa Fe Springs, the Beverly Hills Public Library offers four times as many children and adolescent books and has four times as many reading programs as the Santa Fe Springs Library. In terms of the facilities, staff, and funding, the Santa Fe Springs Library lags far behind Beverly Hills. With these stark differences, students in poor and working-class neighborhoods are unlikely to have access to the books in their community, access necessary to develop high levels of literacy. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Adolescents; Book access; Children; Public library; Reading; Socioeconomic status

Title: Recent views on identifying impacts from public libraries
Affiliations: School of Information Studies, Syracuse University, United States; School of Information Studies, Syracuse University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abend, J., School of Information Studies, Syracuse University, United States; McClure, C.R., School of Information Studies, Syracuse University, United States
Abstract: This paper provides a review and analysis of key topics and issues related to identifying and describing impacts that result from public library services. The paper first describes key terms and explores the notion of a “public good” as it pertains to library services. Based on a number of studies, the paper offers a typology of public library impacts and the importance of those impacts for local communities. Specific types of impact are identified and described with emphasis on the importance of impacts on local economic development. The paper concludes by discussing a number of issues and strategies that should be considered when public librarians wish to promote economic development as an outcome from library services. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Economic impacts; Measuring impacts; Public libraries

Title: Justifying the freedom to read: From democratic right to human right
Affiliations: State University of New York, Albany, United States
Authors with affiliations: Christensen, P.G., State University of New York, Albany, United States
Abstract: In the fourth edition of the American Library Association’s Intellectual Freedom Manual published in 1989, we witness conflicting ideologies in the Universal Right to Freedom of Expression (recently added to the Library Bill of Rights) and the Freedom to Read statement. The former appeals to natural, inalienable rights and the latter to American democracy in the attempt to fight censorship. Erosion of freedom of speech during the Reagan-Bush era suggests that we should try to reconcile the two positions by abandoning the appeal to American democracy. The Freedom to Read statement represents ideas elaborated by Alexander Meiiklejohn and Thomas I. Emerson in the early 1960s. However, later attacks on these positions by Robert H. Bork and Lillian R. BeVier show that the Constitution can be legitimately interpreted in a way that would allow much censorship of expression. Thus an appeal by the ALA to more abstract principles is in order. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Censorship; Community rights; Freedom of speech; Natural law; U.S. constitution; U.S. supreme court

Title: User fees, community goods, and the public library
Affiliations: Union University, Jackson, TN, United States; Master of Library and Information Science, University of Illinois, William Jewell College and Midwestern Baptist Seminary, Urbana-Champaign, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jaeger, J., Union University, Jackson, TN, United States, Master of Library and Information Science, University of Illinois, William Jewell College and Midwestern Baptist Seminary, Urbana-Champaign, United States
Abstract: The recent debate about user fees in public libraries has lasted over twenty-five years and still continues to be an emotional and heated one. Likewise, those from both the pro- and anti-fee camps seem commonly to argue across one another, with little meaningful communication taking place. A close analysis not only of the content, but also the form, of the arguments from the proponents and opponents of fees illuminates the situation. The pro-fee position is based largely on teleol-ogical or pragmatic arguments, while the anti-fee position is centered primarily on a communitarian ethic based on a historical relationship between public libraries and their communities. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Community goods; Public good; Public library; User fees

Title: Information playgrounds: Creating children’s libraries
Affiliations: West Palm Beach Public Library, 100 Clematis Street, West Palm Beach, FL, 33401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sandlian, P., West Palm Beach Public Library, 100 Clematis Street, West Palm Beach, FL, 33401, United States
Abstract: Designing and building new libraries is a monumental responsibility. Perspectives on libraries and education are evolving and affecting our attitudes towards our services and our responsibility towards our community. Technology creates new possibilities for visions and old responsibilities for the human hands-on touch. The design and construction of children’s libraries has all of the requirements for spacing, planning, programs and service design. Children’s space planning is influenced by cognitive development, learning styles and a shift in philosophy about realistic behavior expectations in libraries. Children’s libraries should be designed for the user, who is a unique individual very different from adults. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Architecture; Children’s libraries; Space planning

Authors: ur Rehman S., Majid S., Abu Baker A.B.
Title: Competencies for public library professionals in Malaysia
Affiliations: College of Graduate Studies, Kuwait University, P.O. Box 5969 Safat, 13060, Kuwait; Department of Library and Information Science, International Islamic University, Petaling Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: ur Rehman, S., College of Graduate Studies, Kuwait University, P.O. Box 5969 Safat, 13060, Kuwait; Majid, S., Department of Library and Information Science, International Islamic University, Petaling Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia; Abu Baker, A.B., Department of Library and Information Science, International Islamic University, Petaling Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia
Abstract: Competencies of the entry-level professionals for the Malaysian public libraries were defined and validated for the next five years. The exercise of competency determination was accomplished by focusing on the peculiarities of the Malaysian context by adopting a number of methodological innovations. Each competency statement was an identifiable and measurable performance unit. The top and middle managers of the ten largest Malaysian public library systems were interviewed to validate knowledge and skill competencies by indicating their perceived degree of importance of each statement. The competencies were presented in the categories of foundation core and five operational areas of cataloging, circulation, information services, collection development, and serial control. The primary thrust for the future public library professionals is on the contextual, managerial, technological, and service capabilities. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Competencies; Information professionals; Knowledge competencies; Library professionals; Malaysia; Public libraries; Skill competencies

Title: Present-day attitudes of african American librarians towards their profession and work environment
Affiliations: Sterling C. Evans Library, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, 77843-5000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yang, Z.Y.L., Sterling C. Evans Library, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, 77843-5000, United States
Abstract: The object of this study was to survey African American librarians regarding their careers. A questionnaire was mailed to 300 African American librarians (AALs) who are currently working. Responses to each question were analyzed. The results showed that close to one-half of AALs (47.5%) were employed in public libraries. Seventy-one percent of AALs found their first professional library position in less than six months. Seventy-five percent of the respondents had been promoted at least once since they graduated from library school. Lack of recognition and appreciation by the library was perceived as the number one barrier to job satisfaction experienced by AALs. © 1999 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: African american librarians; Job satisfaction; Job survey; Minority librarians

Title: A brief encounter: Part three-meanwhile in the executive branch
Affiliations: Graduate School of Library and Information Studies, Queens College, CUNY, Flushing, NY, 11367-1597, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blake, V.L.P., Graduate School of Library and Information Studies, Queens College, CUNY, Flushing, NY, 11367-1597, United States
Abstract: In this paper the origins of a Federal role in public libraries is explored. This examination of the roots of this now accepted aspect of the public library landscape is presented in three sections. In the first of these (appearing in edition 16(3) oiPLQ) the background of the twin concepts, a Federal agency and Federal aid for public libraries, was recounted. Outlined as well were the arguments of the leading opponents who were able to delay the A.L.A. Council's final endorsement for a year. The second segment, (which appeared in edition 16(4) oiPLQ) considered the Congressional fate of the twin concepts-the Federal agency easily approved, the concept of Federal aid never attaining the status of serious consideration. Finally, in this third segment, the role of the Federal government in dispensing aid to public libraries as part of the general effort against the Depression is related. In the post-World War II era the A.L.A. would renew its fight for Federal aid with the secure endorsement of the profession's largest organization, a degree of familiarity with the Congress and its ways, and five years actual experience in a Federal aid program. © 1998 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Fees in public libraries
Affiliations: Department of Information Studies and Librarianship, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan, 52900, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shoham, S., Department of Information Studies and Librarianship, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan, 52900, Israel
Abstract: The assumption that the imposition of fees will result in a decline in use of the public library was tested among Israeli public libraries, where it is common to levy fees for borrowing books. Contrary to the assumption, no statistical correlation was found between the size of library fees and library use. In a telephone survey of ex-users of three different libraries, and in a community survey of 165 interviewees, only a few mentioned financial factors as a reason for not using the library. The findings suggested that in decisions as to whether to use the library, fees are only a minor consideration. © 1998 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Language minority students and public library use in the united states
Affiliations: California State University, Fullerton, United States
Authors with affiliations: McQuillan, J., California State University, Fullerton, United States
Abstract: Research has consistently found that school and public library use are positively correlated with reading achievement. This study examines differences in public library use among a nationally representative sample of parents. It was found that children from homes where a language other than English is spoken use the public library significantly less than children in English-only speaking homes, but that these differences are no longer present when parental education is taken into account. © 1998 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Conceptual aspects of bibliothecal communication; Philosophical legacy of the twentieth century american librarianship
Affiliations: School of Information Science and Policy, State University of New York, Albany, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nitecki, J.Z., School of Information Science and Policy, State University of New York, Albany, United States
Abstract: The author briefly reviews the development of the American philosophy of librarianship and identifies issues to be addressed in the next century. The focus of the essay is on the interpretation of bibliothecal communication defined as a dialogue between the reader and selected author within the structured library environment. Bibliothecal communication is considered the basic principle in the newly emerging concept of metalibrarianship which encompasses all aspects of recorded communication. © 1998 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Misty, water-colored images
Affiliations: Library Services, Oklahoma Baptist University, Shawnee, OK, 74801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Herring, M.Y., Library Services, Oklahoma Baptist University, Shawnee, OK, 74801, United States
Abstract: In this evanescent electronic age, all libraries, especially public ones because they host so much of library clientele, need to be concerned about preservation. New developments in preservation, particularly digital imaging, provide not only new means, but exciting new ways of making the old new again to patrons. This piece, a version of it presented before the Oklahoma Library Association Preservation Section (Tom Clareson, Amigos, chair, 4 April 1995) reviews the findings, explains on-going preservation work at Oklahoma Baptist University, and sounds the clarion for preservation activist librarians. © 1997 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Protecting first amendment rights in public libraries
Affiliations: Metropolitan Library System of Oklahoma County, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brawner, L.B., Metropolitan Library System of Oklahoma County, United States
Abstract: Lee B. Brawner, is a professional librarian with over thirty-eight years of experience, including twenty-five years as executive director of the Metropolitan Library System serving Oklahoma County. Last year he and his library system came under attack by two organized groups seeking to determine what materials would and would not be allowed on the shelves of the library. At his own expense and on his own time he wrote and distributed a letter to many persons in the library's service area. He stated that in all of his career “… I have never written a letter like this”. He went on to say in the letter's introduction “1 am writing to advise you of a serious threat to your first amendment rights in your public library and your public school libraries. I want to specifically address the threat to your public library and urge you to voice your opinion before your rights of access to library materials and information are curtailed”. This article is based upon Mr. Brawners letter. © 1997 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Serials usage study in a public library
Affiliations: Broward County’s Main Library, University of South Florida, Florida Library, United States; Broward County’s Main Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: French, C., Broward County’s Main Library, University of South Florida, Florida Library, United States; Pollard, E., Broward County’s Main Library, United States
Abstract: Shrinking budgets and continued yearly increase in the cost of serials affects all libraries. It has become imperative that libraries study the usage of their periodicals collections. It is no longer feasible to hold a title because someone might request it in the far future. Libraries need to critically evaluate the usage of their serials. They should consider dropping expensive titles that are requested only a few times a year and investigate titles that are more popular and used regularly. There seems to be an abundance of published articles concerning periodical usage for academic libraries. It is rare to find articles written by librarians in public libraries. If public librarians are not studying the usage of periodicals/serials it is important that they begin. If they are tracking the usage of their collections they should publish their findings. Publishing is beneficial to them and to public libraries. © 1997 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: An overview of collecting, using, and reporting output statistics in a technical services department
Affiliations: Public Library, United States; University of North Texas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johansson, D.H., Public Library, United States, University of North Texas, United States
Abstract: The collection, use, and reporting of output statistics in a technical services department is one important duty of the department head. The literature is rich with cost-effectiveness and cost-analysis studies. The purpose of this paper is to give an overview of the types of measurements that may be made, how the measurements may be made, and the uses of the resulting data. This article addresses both completely automated and completely non-automated technical services departments, but it focuses on partially automated departments in small libraries. The selection of the measurements to make is a very important decision. The benefits of carefully selecting the measurements to make include better data for report writing, planning, and evaluations of various technical services functions. One example of an actual report using data from these types of measurements is included in the Appendix. © 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The “Self-Help section” in public libraries: The case of Israel
Affiliations: Department of Information Studies and Librarianship, Bar-llan University, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Baruchson-Arbib, S., Department of Information Studies and Librarianship, Bar-llan University, Israel
Abstract: This paper discusses the new self-help section in public libraries in Israel. The author suggests expanding the activities of the public library by building a unique self-help section that will include practical social information as well as belles-lettres for support and encouragement. This new section will be organized by a new Social Information Scientist who will be aware of the social needs of the public as well as new information technologies. A survey conducted in Israel in 1994, made clear that there is an awareness of the need for a self-help section in most libraries. Some librarians (67.5%) have such a section but most of them do not have a special policy for choosing books. Almost 40% of the readers expressed interest in this new section, but there is a lot to be done yet in order to utilize the potential of such a section and meet the needs of the public. © 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Affiliations: Graduate School of Library and Information Studies, Queens College, CUNY, Flushing, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blake, V.L.P., Graduate School of Library and Information Studies, Queens College, CUNY, Flushing, NY, United States

Title: Information access illiterate?
Affiliations: Mahon Public Library in Lubbock, TX, United States; Texas Tech University, United States; Library and Information Science, University of North Texas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weiner, R.G., Mahon Public Library in Lubbock, TX, United States, Texas Tech University, United States, Library and Information Science, University of North Texas, United States
Abstract: Traditionally, librarians preserved and protected written records for the politically elite and wealthy classes. The Greeks, Romans, and Egyptians built up great libraries many of which were destroyed throughout history. When Christianity became the political force in Europe, the clergy continued to collect and protect materials. The beginnings of public libraries in Europe during the 1600s and in America during the middle of the nineteenth century, gave rise to a new literacy among the general population. However, the upsurge in technology threatens to spawn a new class of “information access illiterate” people. Public libraries can serve the needs of society by giving access to, and providing educational literacy programs for using, new technological tools to access information. © 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: First contact: Reaching out to local schools before their students reach your library
Affiliations: Walter W. Stiem Library, California State University, Bakersfield, United States; Document Delivery Department, Library Liaison to the School of Education, Teaches formal courses, Bibliographic Instruction, United States; Covina Public Library in California, United States; California State University, Northridge, United States; University of California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Houdyshell, M.L., Walter W. Stiem Library, California State University, Bakersfield, United States, Document Delivery Department, Library Liaison to the School of Education, Teaches formal courses, Bibliographic Instruction, United States, Covina Public Library in California, United States, California State University, Northridge, United States, University of California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: With the reduction in the number of elementary, middle, and secondary school libraries, more and more students must turn to other resources for assistance in collecting materials for their homework assignments. This can be a challenging experience as cutbacks in funding and hours of operation often limit the resources found at any library. If little or no communication is established between the classroom instructor and the library, what results is confusion and frustration on everyone's part, particularly, the students'. What follows are proposed homework guidelines for library assignments that can be easily implemented by instructors and aid in fostering a positive and communicative working relationship with the library, whether it be your school's or the local public or academic library. © 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: From second class “citizen” to “head of the class”: A new way to fund libraries
Affiliations: PROVIDENCE Associates Inc., Library Planners Consultants, Demon, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waters, R.L., PROVIDENCE Associates Inc., Library Planners Consultants, Demon, TX, United States
Abstract: This concept was initially developed by William Wilson, library consultant, PROVIDENCE Associates Inc. It was modified for a presentation at die 1996 Texas State Library Association Convention. It outlines a different way of thinking about funding libraries, an innovative framework that will interest legislators in the plight of their under-funded library services. Wilson and Waters refer to this new structure as a “Library Authority”. The concept would allow the question of funding to go directly to the voters, who are those most concerned with the quality of libraries. This quality is also addressed by Waters, who considers quantity and volume as a faulty line of reasoning for gathering support. “We make little mention of the long-term impact associated with introducing a four-year old to the world of books… or to the economic impact derived from helping a saleswoman locate a new market for her products”. Mr. Waters hopes others will assist in fleshing out this concept for the good of all libraries. © 1997 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Seizing an instructional and marketing opportunity: Audiocassette tours in public libraries
Affiliations: School of Library and Archival and and Information Studies, University of British Columbia, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Curry, A., School of Library and Archival and and Information Studies, University of British Columbia, Canada
Abstract: Budget cuts, staff shortages, and increasing patron numbers are causing public libraries to give very little educational information to new patrons at registration desks. As well, libraries are failing to promote themselves adequately to ensure that new patrons are library supporters and return customers. Self-tour audiocassette tours have been used successfully in academic libraries, museums, and art galleries for educational and marketing purposes and should be considered for public library use. Audiotapes for public libraries were produced and tested by library school students at The University of British Columbia and the results indicate that this instructional method shows promise and is adaptable to the public environment. © 1997 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: A discussion of knowledge-based systems and librarians: With a selected bibliography from library science and other disciplines
Affiliations: California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, United States; University of Southern California, Occidental College, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hanne, D., California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, United States, University of Southern California, Occidental College, United States
Abstract: Knowledge-Based System(s) (KBS) are computer-based “expert systems” intended for development and use in libraries. Librarians have experimented with KBS to make their expertise available at all times or to answer “routine” questions. In the past, KBS have had limited success in libraries. The increase in computer-based library On-line Public Access Catalog (OPAC) systems and the development of the Internet World Wide Web (WWW) would allow a single KBS to benefit a much larger number of librarians and their clients. Librarians might want to consider again whether to include KBS among their resources. There is a discussion of the special skills of reference librarians and of the questions they might ask in considering a KBS project. This article concludes with a bibliography, with detailed contents notes, of articles and books in disciplines fundamental to Knowledge-Based Systems. © 1997 by The Haworth Ress, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Peer review: A team-building way to evaluate employees
Authors with affiliations: Waters, R.L.
Abstract: Team-building has been prevalent in the private sector for a number of years. It is now beginning to be instituted by the not-so-profit sector, including libraries. This article explains, in outline form, the concept of the Peer Review process which can be an extremely important component of successful team-building. The article draws upon the experience of the private sector. © 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Why you can’t “censorproof” your public library: What research tells us
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Studies, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, T6G 2J4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Schrader, A.M., School of Library and Information Studies, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, T6G 2J4, Canada
Abstract: Because there is considerable pressure on public librarians to censor materials in their collections, it is no wonder that some staff will go to almost any lengths to avoid challenges, criticism, and controversy over which titles and which kinds of materials should be made available to their communities. Nevertheless, while these reactions are quite understandable, a close reading of recent censorship research suggests that they are not solutions. The purpose of this article is to explore the reasons why this kind of avoidance behavior-“censorproofing”-is eventually doomed to failure, and to suggest alternative strategies that might make more effective use of the time, energy, imagination, and resources of public library staff. © 1997 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
