Title: Journal coverage of the european community: Analysis of a decade
Affiliations: Senior Documents and Microtext Librarian, Sterling C. Evans Library, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: da Conturbia, S., Senior Documents and Microtext Librarian, Sterling C. Evans Library, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, United States
Abstract: The information about the European Community (EC) available in the United States seems to be sparse. Since interest toward the EC increases as Western Europe moves toward economic integration, improving bibliographic awareness should be beneficial to both the academic and the business community. Also, determining which journals provide the greatest coverage of the EC could b;? useful information--for library collection development and serials review. To accomplish these goals, Business Periodicals Index and Social Sciences Index were examined for the decade 1983-1992. Records from the two databases were downloaded, analyzed and compared to determine whether the literature follows the European integration and, more specifically, which journals present the greatest coverage. © 1996 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Title: Public perceptions of library use: Benefits and negative benefits
Affiliations: Department of Information Studies, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia; Department of Information Studies, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Edwards, S., Department of Information Studies, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia; Hall, A., Department of Information Studies, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia
Abstract: This study surveyed adults in Sydney, Australia in order to determine their perceptions of the benefits and negative benefits associated with public library use. In the qualitative stage of the investigation, positive and negative consequences were elicited for sixteen library activities. The findings showed that most respondents perceived that they would receive positive consequences if they were to engage in the activities. Results also suggest that there is a limited set of salient consequences for each activity, and some consequences are common across a number of activities. In the second stage, a mail questionnaire was used to quantify perceptions of the "goodness" of the consequences and the likelihood of their occumng. Generally, the results confirmed the qualitative findings and showed that most consequences were perceived to be positive and likely to occur. © 1996 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Your license or your life: Charitable solicitation laws and library fund-raising

Authors with affiliations: McDougal, S.H., Bethesda, MD, 20814, United States; Becher, M.L., Federal Library and Information Network, Washington, DC, United States
Abstract: In view of recent increases in fund-raising activity by public libraries, their Friends groups, and foundations, the authors alert librarians to the existence of state laws regulating it. The development of fund-raising in public libraries is discussed, with the conclusion that they both rely on fund-raising to supplement tax revenue and accept it as a library activity. Many states require registration of non-profit organizations as a prerequisite to charitable solicitation. Annual reporting and registration of professional fundraisers also may be required. Libraries may be able to obtain exemption from these laws as educational institutions. © 1995 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors with affiliations: Tjoumas, R., Graduate School of Library and Information Studies, Queens College-City University of New York, United States
Abstract: Among the five boroughs comprising New York City, Queens has the highest percentage of immigrants. In 1977, Queens Borough Public Library instituted the New Americans Program to serve immigrants whose primary language was not English. Over the years, it has established a wide range of services including the development of foreign language collections, coordinating ESL classes, and scheduling cultural events. The Coping Skills Component is the newest activity to be initiated to assist newcomers' entry into the American mainstream. This article explores the history, function, and organization of the Coping Skills Component. Special attention is focused uoon the role of the oroiect’s Coordinator, the building of external and internal communkadon patterns, and community outreach. The ouroose of this examination is to furnish administrators with a paradigh that can be adapted to other public library settings. © 1995 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Abstract: As part of a technology study for The Free Library of Philadelohia. the consultants (PROVIDENCE Associares IncJ undertook a andview of one of The reLei brary’s older branch libraries lo determine how a building more than seventy years old could be, effectively and efficiently modified to become a model library for technology. Affiliations: Division of Library Services, Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, W., Division of Library Services, Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction, Madison, United States
Abstract: Public libraries have two courses to follow with regard to embracing technology and putting it to its most productive use. They can "Stay the Course," which will lead to a fulfillment of the prophecy of gloom and doom foreseen by some, or they can "Get with the Program," develop a plan for the use of technology, and begin to implement the plan as funds allow. The options are clear, the choice should not be a difficult one to make. © 1994 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors with affiliations: Wan, W.W., Texas Woman’s University Library, Denton, TX, 76204, United States
Abstract: Many libraries have upgraded or are planning to migrate to second or third generation automated systems in recent years. It is said that a computer system gets outdated every five year or so, and with the rapid development in technology, the cycle may even be getting shorter. The migration to a different system involves a complex process. The transfemna of data from traditional librarv technical services functions such k acquisitions, cataloging, seridcheck-in. summary holdinas. etc. is of oarticular imozrtance in lieht that there is no industandwide- standandds in data candstruction, except perhaps, in the MARC bibliographic format. Such new systems will also affect the organization and operation of various technical services areas. This paper is a discussion of the impact of such a process on technical services staff be using one academic library’s experience as an illustration. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Common ground: How liraries and data processing departments can enhance automation systems
Affiliations: City of Garland’s Nicholson Memorial Library System, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brock, J., City of Garland’s Nicholson Memorial Library System, United States
Abstract: Municipal libraries and data processing departments share common technical ground but often are at odds over issues relating to computing and automation. If municipalities are to maximize their library automation investment; then these two departments should establish communications channels and policies that encourage joint participation in the selection, implemenlation, maintenance, and enhancement of the library’s automation system; as well as the library’s base of networked and non-networked personal comouters and workstations. his paper identifies specific conflicts between libraries and data processing departments, and offers practical solutions that will benefit the library and ultimately its patrons. These benefits can be realized in enhanced system productivity and performance, and less drain on the library’s personnel and financial resources. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Providing access to the acquisitions on order file through the local area network
Affiliations: UNT Libraries, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kanost, L.K., UNT Libraries, United States
Abstract: The University of North Texas Libraries' Materials Acsuisitions Department closed its Paper order file in September, 19a. Because ihe order file was usid by librarians outside the department, it was necessary to provide access to the automated version. The in-house acquisitions system uses Paradox, a relational database manager from Borland. Due to the security structure of the Libraries' LAN, a copy of the order file was designed and placed on a shared directory for access by Librarians and staff outside of Acquisitions. Title, author, department and ISBN indexes were included A menu-driven program using the Paradox Application Language (PAL) was written to guide the occasional user in searching the indexes. Training in using the Files was provided through the Libraries' Staff Development Program. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Congressional masterfile on compact disk versus cis paper index: Who is the winner?
Affiliations: Sterling C. Evans Library, Texas A and M University, United States; Patent and Trademark Depository Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: da Conturbia, S., Sterling C. Evans Library, Texas A and M University, United States; Carpenter, B.B., Patent and Trademark Depository Library, United States
Abstract: Congressional Mastefile on CD-ROM has proven to be a good resource for finding information on Congressional hearings, reports, and special publications. In January 1992, new and improved software became available for accessing Congressional Masterfile. To determine if the new software meets user requirements and to find out whether paper indexes are still needed by CIS users, students enrolled in a Political Science class at Texas AandM University were requested to participate in a survey. The students had the same class assignment and were asked either to use the compact disk and to complete a questionnaire or to use the paper indexes and complete a different set of questions. The responses to the survey were compared and analyzed. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: State standards, planning, and public library size
Affiliations: Indiana University School of Lirbary and Information Science, Bloomington, IN, 47405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pungitore, V.L., Indiana University School of Lirbary and Information Science, Bloomington, IN, 47405, United States
Abstract: Data from a 1992 survey of compliance by Ohio public libraries with state standards were used to examine relationships between achievement of a planning standard and each of 22 size variables. Significant but. weak correlations were found between planning scores and population of the service area, volumes per capita, number of ALA/MLS employees per capita, interlibrary loans to the library, and interlibrary loans from the library. Findings suggest that library size as traditionally measured may not have a substantial influence on a library’s capacity to engage in long range planning. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The best in international literature for today’s children: Translated children’s books
Affiliations: University of Houston-Clear Lake, United States
Authors with affiliations: White, M., University of Houston-Clear Lake, United States
Abstract: Children’s librarians can play an important role in combating cultural isolationism through the selection and promotion of translated children’s books from other languages into English. Translations can serve as an important medium for sharing the similarities and differences between various cultures. Although translated books have often been accused of "not traveling well," the number of translations available todav are such that we have an increasing opportunity to include quality translated literature in our collections. Suggestions for promoting translations are given. Also, an annotated bibliography of picture-books from a vaiiety of languages and a list of useful bibliographies are provided. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Towards a preliminary understanding of the social organization of public libraries
Affiliations: Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Higgins, M., Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand
Abstract: Three public libraries were examined to assess their patterns of social interaction as determined by oral communication, with the primary aim of the research being to identify liaisons within the communications network. A subsidiary aim was to determine the 'fit' of the emergent with the formal organizational structure. It was possible to compare the structures of the organizations in two cases, and in both of these cases the emergent (informal) structure matched the formal structure quite closely. Library and Information Center managers need to attach some degree of importance to such knowledge as the informal and formal structural fit may impinge upon organizational effectiveness. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Children’s and young adult librarians: Ready for grants?
Affiliations: Graduate School of Library and Information Science, University of Texas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davis, P.J., Graduate School of Library and Information Science, University of Texas, United States
Abstract: The Yolith Omnibus Bill passed during he WHLIS in July 1991, includes oprovisions for six separate grants for children’s, school, and young adult services in libraries. Funding cuts have made developing alternate sources of revenue vital for the survival of existing librarv services and the develooment of new ones. Are children’s and young adult librarians trained in writing grant proposals? Are children’s and young adult librarians writing grant proposals to receive alternate funding? These two questions were the basis for a research study undertaken at the University of Texas Graduate School of Library and Information Science. A questionnaire was mailed to sixty-two children’s and young adult librarians in public libraries in both small and large library systems in Texas to determine if these librarians were writing grant proposals, and if not, why not. This article reports the results of the questionnaires in detail and begins a discussion of the following questions: Is there a need to create a clearinghouse to supply libraries with information on grant availability? Should instruction in the writing of grant proposals be included in library school curriculum?. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Maximizing access, minimizing cost: A first step toward the information access future
Affiliations: University Libraries, Washington University, St. Louis, MO, 63130, United States; Interlibrary Loan Department, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, 19104, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baker, S.K., University Libraries, Washington University, St. Louis, MO, 63130, United States; Jackson, M.E., Interlibrary Loan Department, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, 19104, United States
Abstract: This white paper is an outgrowth of discussions of the Association of Research Libraries (ARL) Committee on Access to Information Resources. Although initially written for (he research library community, (he issues included in the paper are relevant lo all libraries that share materials. The white paper sets forth a series of assumptions which serve as the basis for a critique of current ILL activities. The weaknesses of the current environment are complimented by several notable successes. An ideal ILL environment is described, with descriptions of ideal automated financial accounting and management systems. The white papcr also sets forth a series of umanked recommendations that would help realize the ideal. The white papcr offers desirable time frames, effort, costs, and suggests who might lead those initiatives. The white paper was witten to stimulate discussions and begin initiatives that would improve interlibrary loan for all types and sized of libraries. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Public librarians as authors in the library science periodical literature: An examination and profile
Affiliations: Business Reference Librarian, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, 35487-0266, United States; Head of Business Library, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, 35487-0266, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chapman, K., Business Reference Librarian, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, 35487-0266, United States; Pike, L.E., Head of Business Library, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, 35487-0266, United States
Abstract: This article examines the level of scholarly contribution made by public librarians to eight national library science periodicals from 1988 through 1990 and to two national library science periodicals specifically targeted for a public library audience for the same period. Contributors are profiled on the bases of gender, geographic location, and collaboration, and, comparisons are made between the authorship characteristics in the general library periodicals and the two public library-oriented periodicals. It is shown that, although public librarians' contributions to the general library science literature is practically negligible, they constitute a significant presence in the public library-oriented periodicals. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Children - our future will be in their hands: Their issues need our attention
Affiliations: Southern Methodist University in Dallas, Dallas, TX, 75275-0113, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seib, P., Southern Methodist University in Dallas, Dallas, TX, 75275-0113, United States
Abstract: This article, slightly modified for currency, was first written just after he last State of the Union address delivered by then President George Bush. The title was "Children’s Issues Need Attention." More than a year has passed since that address, the White House is occupied by a Democrat for the first time in 12 years-and the issues that Philip Seib addressed in January of 1992 remain as valid now as they were then. The needs of children are also, in a sense, the needs of public libraries. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

In the fist Dart of the discussion the author discussed the function of insurance, aefmed risk and its importance, and reviewed the principal categories of insurance coverage for libraries. In this part the author discusses examples of supplemental coverages and costs. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Who plans and how? a profile of one state’s public libraries
Affiliations: Rockingham County Public Library, Eden, NC, 27288, United States; Department of Library and Information Studies, University of North Carolina at Greensboro, Greensboro, NC, 27412-5001, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bolden, B.F., Rockingham County Public Library, Eden, NC, 27288, United States; Smith, K., Department of Library and Information Studies, University of North Carolina at Greensboro, Greensboro, NC, 27412-5001, United States
Abstract: A survey of public library administrators in North Carolina revealed that 85 percent engage in either short or long range planning activities using both formal, written and informal, unwritten policies and procedures. Analysis of the results showed that approximately 58 per cent used the ALAPLA manual, Plnnning and Role Setting for Public Libraries, for suggested planning techniques. Capital budgeting, operational resource strategy, and provision of written long-term objectives for the library were reasons given for planning by the majority of respondents. Most administrators anticipated a need for systematic planning in the future, primarily because of the changing roles of the library in the community, and the increasing need for accountability. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The relationship between quality of goal setting and job satisfaction in a public library setting
Affiliations: University Library, Gardner-Webb College, Boiling Springs, NC, 28017, United States; Kent State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, H.K., University Library, Gardner-Webb College, Boiling Springs, NC, 28017, United States; Kim, M.T., Kent State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Abstract: A survey of branch staff in a large metropolitan public library examined four dimensions of perceived quality of goal setting- specificity, difficulty, feedback and parlicipation-as they related to overall satisfaclion, as well as satisfaction with job, supervisor, and co-workers. The relationships between job satisfaction and gender, education, occupational level, and tenure were also studied. Analysis revealed that a11 four dimensions of goal setting were correlated with overall job satisfaction. The pattern of correlations between subdimensions of both goal setting and job satisfaction varied, however, for professional and support staff. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Characteristics and attitudes of the clientele of a state central branch library - benin city, nigeria
Affiliations: Bendel State University, Ekpoma, Bendel, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Ojo-Igbinoba, M.E., Bendel State University, Ekpoma, Bendel, Nigeria
Abstract: It is assumed that the clientele of this library are students and workers. What are their perceptions of library service? Are the services vital to them? An understanding of the library clientele’s attitudes on such and more matters is vital t the profession and for Ule growth and development of public library servlce. It is postulated that public libraries should assume newer roles with active participation in national development. The results of a user survey are discussed Solutions are suggested for the problems the survey brings out. It is further recommended that the public library should set up information and referral services to enhance the awareness of public library services, especially its in- formational function. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Designing a children’s library: A review
Affiliations: Children’s Library, Denver Central Library, Denver, CO, 80203-2165, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sandlian, P., Children’s Library, Denver Central Library, Denver, CO, 80203-2165, United States
Abstract: The new Central Library of Ule Denver Public Library is scheduled to open mid-year 1995. The design has been guided by a team of architects headed by Michael Graves of Princeton, New Jersey, in collaboration with Klipp Partnership of Denver. The Children’s Library will be one of the focal points of the building. Library staff, children arents,'and architects have worked together to create a remarkable children’s Library. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Insurance and risk management for libraries
Affiliations: Metropolitan Library System, Oklahoma City, OK, 73102, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brawner, L.B., Metropolitan Library System, Oklahoma City, OK, 73102, United States
Abstract: Inswance for libraries is not a matter to take for granted. As explained in this survey article, there are a host of opportunities for the Library to sustain major damage and thus unexpected costs. Insurance is a way to prevent this from happening. Fire inswance, emors and omissions, fidelitity bonds, these matters and much more are discussed. In the fust of a two-part article, the author discusses the function of insurance, defines risk and its importance, and reviews the principal categories of insurance coverage for libraries. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The spirituality of reading
Affiliations: First Presbyterian Church, Texarkana, AR, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waters, B.A., First Presbyterian Church, Texarkana, AR, United States
Abstract: Reading is an activity that can provide persons with the opportunity to experience the transcendent. Reading can become an act of intimacy when the reader is engrossed in a self-forgetrul way. Reading enables us to see the world as others see it. Readingregular reading-is not easy, it takes prepxation. It can enlarge our sensitivity toward others. Spirituality is about what we do with our life, about what we do with our freedom. Reading can engage our spirituality. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Public librarians and continuing education: A motivational study
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Sciences, North Carolina Central University, Durham, NC, 27707, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burgin, R., School of Library and Information Sciences, North Carolina Central University, Durham, NC, 27707, United States
Abstract: The motivations of 395 public librarians to participate in continuing education events were compared with those of 222 respondents from other types of libraries. Public librarians gave three of the four motivators significantly higher mean ratings than did respondents who worked in other types of libraries. However, most of the significant afferences between the respondents appear to be due primarily to the responses of the paraprofessional public librarians, who rated three motivators significantly higher than did the paraprofessional respondents from other types of libraries and who rated all four motivators significantly higher than did the public library respondents who had their master’s degree. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Foundation giving again on the rise
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Waters, R.L., United States
Abstract: Foundations increased their major giving in 1990 over 1989 by 44 percent. Major giving is defined as grants of $2.5 million or more. This article reviews research compiled by The Foundation Center on the patterns of U.S. foundations with respect to major giving. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Here there be sanctuary: The public library as refuge and retreat
Affiliations: Library and Community Servicces, Beverly Hills, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cart, M., Library and Community Servicces, Beverly Hills, CA, United States
Abstract: The author considers the role of the public library as a sanctuary in the context of changing socioeconomic and political conditions. He recalls finding sanctuary as a child in his small hometown public library and his first encounter, in the 1950’s, with the economically disadvantaged as patrons of Ulat library. He notes the economic and social forces which, beginning in the late 1960’s. produced a significant population of homeless Americans. Among these were the de-institutionalization movement, the economic expulsion of the poor from the housing market, the shrinking job market, and the rise of substance abuse. All of these phenomena, he suggests, have transformed the public library from a sanctuary to a shelter. In that context he discusses recent court cases centering around the first amendment guarantees of access for the homeless and disturbed to public libraries and recalls, anecdotally, his own experiences as library director in Beverly Hills, CA, with representatives of this growing population. Though not necessarily economically disadvantaged, both youth (particularly latchkey youth) and Ule elderly are similarly disenfranchised by society and become he special, de faco charges of the public library. Finally, the author discusses the changes in societal structure which revisions to immigration laws have introduced and concludes that the library must serve a new role of social cohesion in a time when much of the rest of society seem to be falling apart He challenges librarians to more pro-actively cooperate with other social and community agencies as advocates for the disadvantaged and to maintain Ule library as neutral enter for increasingly diverse communities, concluding that in Ulis way the public library can confinuc to play a vital role as a sanctuary and a refuge which is truly free (i.e., open) to all. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Larceny in the library: A question of human resource management?
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Science, University of Western Ontario, London, ON, Canada; University of Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wilkinson, M.A., School of Library and Information Science, University of Western Ontario, London, ON, Canada; Wilkinson, J.P., University of Toronto, Canada
Abstract: Administration and management in public libraries has traditionally been approached from an internal perspective-partitularly in the context of human resource management. Even recognizing that the public library operates within the purview of the law, it is possible to underestimate the power of this constraint upon library administrators and managers. This article describes empjrically the case of a seminar conducted to analyze a hypothetical case developed to illustrate legalities in human resource management. After analyzing the central legal problem inherent in the hypothetical case (which almost every seminar participant missed), the authors conclude by emphasizing the importance of breadth of vision to our professional lives in the public library context. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Continuing education for public library trustees: A report on one state’s activities with suggestions for program planners
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Studies, University of Alabama, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stephens, A.K., School of Library and Information Studies, University of Alabama, United States
Abstract: Inspired by the "Year of the Trustee" celebration, the article reviews educational opportunities afforded trusteei during the last decade or so in one state, Alabama, and offers suggestions for those planning educational activities at the local, state, or regional level. Conferences and workshops conducted for Alabama trustees by the state library agency (APLS) during the 1980s am discussed briefly, results of a survey of Alabama trustee’s continuing education preferences am reported, and programs presented for trustees by the Alabama Library Association and the Southeastern Library Association during this period am listed as suggestions for program planners. After offering specific advice for those planning continuing education workshops, the article reports on workshops, videotapes, and speakers' kits available from ALTA, the American Library Trustee Association. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Public library buildings and the american disabilities act: A review of recent publications
Affiliations: HBW Associates Inc, Denton, TX, 76201-5928, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waters, R.L., HBW Associates Inc, Denton, TX, 76201-5928, United States
Abstract: The American with Disabilities Act (ADA) became law in January, 1992. Six publications are reviewed here. The review deals principally with building accessibility issues contained in each publication. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: A bright future for small libraries
Affiliations: Emporia State University, Emporia, KS, 66801-5087, United States
Authors with affiliations: Greer, R.C., Emporia State University, Emporia, KS, 66801-5087, United States; Grover, R., Emporia State University, Emporia, KS, 66801-5087, United States
Abstract: Technology has had a profound impact on the value system of the library and information pmfessiom, on professional service, and on the role of small public libraries. Cumnt applications of information technologies compel a reassessment of the significance of the small library; moreover, the primary focus of professional status must shift from a preoccupation with murces- their scope and quantity-towad library and information system users and the extent of their satisfaction. Quality should be measured, not by the resources owned by a library, but by the degree to which a service provider is responsive to the needs of clientele. Responsiveness requires a careful analysis or diagnosis of information needs and the commitment to exploit networks, technologies end resources to satisfy those needs. Small libraries have a new and much more significant role in supporting the day to day processes of information transfer. Technology has empowered them to be in a position to provide quality service and to assume the role of leader in provision of information service. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Public libraries in the baltic countries: Problems of culture, democratization and technology
Affiliations: F. Mason and Associates, Dallas, TX, 75209, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mason, F.M., F. Mason and Associates, Dallas, TX, 75209, United States
Abstract: The article explores the challenges public libraries in the newly emerging Baltic countries will face in attempting to modernize and change to reflect the mom open and permissive nature of their societies as they abandon the Soviet Union and its laws and culture. Libraries in the Baltic countries will face problems of building adequate library collections, of acquiring new technologies, and of defining their service missions in the presence of dynamic and rapidly changing social structures. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Towards a re-interpretation of public library purpose in africa
Affiliations: Department of Library and Archival Studies, University of Ghana, Legon, Ghana; Abubakar Tafawa Balewa University, Legon, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Alemna, A.A., Department of Library and Archival Studies, University of Ghana, Legon, Ghana; Antwi, I.K., Abubakar Tafawa Balewa University, Legon, Nigeria
Abstract: This paper is of the view that public library services as they are presently, in Africa, have not changed very much from the service introduced by the colonial masters at the inception of these libraries. The libraries do not suit the needs of the people as they are mostly elitist institutions serving just a minority of the people in these countries. It is the view of the writers that this colonial mentality and parochial attitude towards service should change if public libraries have to make any impact in Afiica. New and improved services such as community libraries, cultural preservation and services for the visually handicapped are recommended. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The experience parlour: The next evolutionary step for the american public library?
Affiliations: Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, 48202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shuman, B.A., Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, 48202, United States
Abstract: This is an exercise in library-related imagineering and futuring. Today’s public library confronts an uncertain array of possible fulures. This speculative scenario, presented visually, imagines the public library transformed into an "experience parlour." Through electronically programmed experiences, the patron is laken far beyond reading, vewing, and listening, using new forms of entertainment and instruclional media which permit total sensory involvement. So intense is this involvement that the user doesn't merely witness or observe the experience from the sidelines, but actually and actively lives it. While this scenario may seem unlikely or fanciful, history shows that much the same reception greeted the theoretical concepts of fhe airplane, the submarine, manned space flight, and even television. Of critical moment is not whether experience parlours are possible or feasible, but rather whether such a development is desirable as a future replacement for, or adjunct to, the traditional role of the public library. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Accentuate the positive: Marketing our services, marketing for change
Affiliations: Dallas Public Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: O'Brien, P.M., Dallas Public Library, United States
Abstract: Public libraries must change if they are to be viable forces in the 21st Century. The printed word must cease being the primary informational resource provided by public libraries. Information accessed electronically must come to the forefront of the service delivery system. Marketing of services must be focused, positive, and keyed to the times. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Why books?
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Science, University of Western Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Neill, S.D., School of Library and Information Science, University of Western Ontario, Canada
Abstract: Libraries have always been book-oriented. Even now, as the need for information seems desparate, libraries remain bookoriented. The public library is feeling the pressure from forces who threaten its existence because it will not 'get into the information business and compete with the private sector." Getting people to read books, helping people to find the books they want to read, these remain major roles of the public library. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The future of public library support staff
Affiliations: School of Library Science, Kent State University, Kent, OH, 44242, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rubin, R., School of Library Science, Kent State University, Kent, OH, 44242, United States
Abstract: Despite the importance of support staff to public libraries, as a group they have received relatively little attention in the library press or among library researchers. This article explores the forces within the profession and the forces in the general economy and laborforce that will shape the composition, character and size of this workforce as we reach the year 2000 and beyond. The implications for library management and recruibnent are discussed. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Recruiting for stability
Affiliations: Anaheim Public Library, Anaheim, CA, 92805, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sgritta, V.L., Anaheim Public Library, Anaheim, CA, 92805, United States
Abstract: The high turnover rate for non-professional staff is causing library managers to spend inordinate amounts of time filling and refilling the same posibons. Recruiting efforts need to move beyond the diminishing youlh segment and focus on Lhe burgeoning senior population. In addition to filling the void, older employees are bringing with them slability, consistency, and commitment. Libraries need to ready the workplace for seniors by examining attitudes, accommodating special needs, and actively recruiting. Changing demographics call for changing hiring practices. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Siting of public libraries: A semiotic analysis
Affiliations: School of Information and Library Studies, Curtin University of Technology, Perth, WA, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Wagner, G.S., School of Information and Library Studies, Curtin University of Technology, Perth, WA, Australia
Abstract: The siting of a public library is a non-verbal communication process. Taking the example of Perlh metropolitan region, Western Auslralia, the siting of public libraries was examined by applying semiotic analysis. Semiotics by separating the expression (or the signifiers such as centralily and accessibilily of a site) from the content (or Ule signified-such as solidarity or lack of it) providcd the necessary research tools for this analysis. The findings indicate that the public face of public libraries (e.g., the siting) is constructed in the context of overlapping and contesling macropowers, i.e., the State (including he local government aulhorities) and Ule professional organizations. The conflicting messages of power versus solidarity as present themselves in siting need to be understood for the correction of any unwanted dysfunctional acts of communication in these agents of communication in society. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Public library services to older pennsylvanians: A decade review
Affiliations: College of Library Science, Clarion University of Pennsylvania, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ip, L.L., College of Library Science, Clarion University of Pennsylvania, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to eslablish a profile of public library services to older people in Pennsylvania public libiaries. One hundred (N = 100) Pennsylvania public libraries, which included all (n = 50) Dislrict Library Centers/Headquarters of the state library system and 50 (n = 50) individual public libraries, were chosen to parlicipate in this study. A total of 65 (65%) survey questionnaires were collected by August 30 of 1989. Major findings of the study were the following: (1) Most respondents (66.15%) reported having appointed staff members for services to older people. (2) Only 4.6% of the responding libraries documented policy statements concerning library services for older people. (3) Only 27.69% of the respondenls initiated projects and programs exclusively for older people. (4) More than eighty percent (83.08%) of the respondents had one or more older volunteer workers. (5) Less than one-third (27.69%) of the Dislrict Library Centers/Headquarters of the state library system and individual public libraries received fmancial support from state and local government for services to older people during the past ten years. (6) Only 9.23% of the respondents had trained librarians for services to older people. (7) Most respondents (93.85%) provided facilities and equipment specifically for older people. It is suggested that public libraries in Pennsylvania should (1) actively request additional funds from parent institutions for services. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Collection development tools for media centres
Affiliations: King Abdul Aziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Ahmad, N., King Abdul Aziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Media centres play a creditablc role in promoting the teaching and learning process in schools, colleges and institutes of higher education. Since there is a wide variety of media software available in the market, the knowledge to evaluate and choose the most appropriate one is desirable. This article discusses some of the media selection tools which include media reviewing journals, abstracts and the indexes. It can facilitate the selection of slide sets, videos and educational films as well as tapes. The latest catalogues of both the commercial and professional organisations are also discussed in detail. The media personnel particularly in the English speaking countries or where the languagc of instruction is English must stock all the notable media development tools described in this article. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The ecology of public library reference rooms
Affiliations: Department of Information Studies and Librarianship, Bar-Ilan University, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shoham, S., Department of Information Studies and Librarianship, Bar-Ilan University, Israel
Abstract: A study was done of the effects of the interior physical design on preferences and behavior of public library users. The research was conducted in reference rooms of urban public libraries, whose clients are not as homogenous a population as other libraries' clients, and includes many adolescents. The research tools were questionnaires that were filled in by users studying at the reference rooms, and observations that were made in order to build a behavioral map of these reference rooms users. A clear preference to choose seats in the peripheral parts of the library was revealed. The reasons given for seating preference were quiet, privacy, and ability to concentrate. Most of those who come alone tended to choose seats at an empty desk. Forty-four percent of those who came to study came with a friend(s) -a phenomenon that is common among adolescents. However, those who came accompanied also preferred hidden and peripheral seats. Therefore, there is a need for varied, separated, small study areas scattered through the reference room. Also, the differences between modular and fixed-function libraries were studied. No difference was found in seating preferences. However, differences appeared in the clients' perceptrons of the room space, in problems with noise and movement of people and in greater exposure of the clients in modular hbraries to other activities and services of the library. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The public library: Some alternative futures
Affiliations: Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, 48202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shuman, B.A., Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, 48202, United States
Abstract: Does the public library have a future? Competing social and economic needs may conspire to preclude one. The reader, however, is asked to assume that there is a future. Without the public library, one's ability to.pay would determine one's access to, and use of, records and information, and those lacking the necessary funds would effectively be barred from the information needed to conduct daily life in an effective manner. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: What does a reference librarian do?
Affiliations: DePaul University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lanning, S., DePaul University, United States
Abstract: This brief paper endeavors to answer the title question,. by using three typical questions that reference librarians are asked. The three questions are (1) "Do you have a book on . . .?" (2) "Don't you have a computer you look that up on?" and (3) is the one requiring the psychic librarian, "It was big, red and had information about places. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The invisible hand: Economic reality
Affiliations: Plano Public Library System, Plano, TX, 75086-0356, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davis, M., Plano Public Library System, Plano, TX, 75086-0356, United States
Abstract: The "free" vs. "fee" issue continues to plague American public libraries. This paper contends that since public libraries operate in a market driven economy, the historic approach that librarians have taken on the side of "free" because of professional ethics and morality is the least effective when competing for resources. Adam Smith's notion of the "invisible hand" of capitalism seems to have finally caught on if the number of libraries now charging for online database searching is any indication. Public libraries, if they are to take their place with the avant-garde of the information industry, must make the choice between struggling to maintain the status quo or accepting the new role in the information industry. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Libraries celebrate the western states centennials, 1989-1990
Affiliations: Burlingame Speical Collections/Archives, Montana State University Libraries, United States; Head of Access Services, Montana State University Libraries, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bender, N., Burlingame Speical Collections/Archives, Montana State University Libraries, United States; Sapp, G., Head of Access Services, Montana State University Libraries, United States
Abstract: The years 1989 and 1990 were the statehood centennials for the states of Idaho, Montana, North and South Dakota, Washington, and Wyoming. In each of these states, public libraries and library organizations have sponsored a number of unique and innovative actrvities in celebration, including exhibits, special publications, reading programs, lecture series, and larger, centrally directed projects. This article provides a descriptive, state-by-state survey of library sponsored or library related centennial programs in each state. The conclusion discusses patterns of sponsorship and implementation of these programs. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Book preservation and conservation
Affiliations: Collection Management/Preservation Specialist, Board of Library Commissioners, Boston, MA, 02215, United States
Authors with affiliations: Trinkaus-Randall, G., Collection Management/Preservation Specialist, Board of Library Commissioners, Boston, MA, 02215, United States

Title: Public library directors' opinions about future directions for library services
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Science, University of South Florida, Tampa, United States
Authors with affiliations: McCrossan, J.A., School of Library and Information Science, University of South Florida, Tampa, United States
Abstract: A survey instrument was developed and administered to a sample of 219 public library directors in the United States seying populations of 25,000 or more. The directors were asked to indlcate what degree of emphasis they attached to 21 different services offered by public libraries, e.g., group programs for adults in the library, reference/information servlces utilizing computerbased systems. There were 166 responses. A glimpse into the future results. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: 'one thing leads to another': The impact of a technological innovation in six new south wales public libraries
Affiliations: School of Librarianship, University of New South Wales, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Willard, P., School of Librarianship, University of New South Wales, Australia
Abstract: The introduction of a microcomputer-based inter-libray loans network for New South Wales public libraries in 1987 was a major innovation. Six libraries were investigated to establish the impact of the innovation on inter-library loans and reference service. The results indicated that the five libraries which had adopted the system were using it to streamline inter-library loans. The innovation was also being used to improve reference service as library staff saw the technology’s potential. The value of senior management commitment and of having a staff member who was interested in computers, emerged as important in the take-up of the technology in the libraries. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Personal computers in small libraries
Affiliations: Department of Library and Information Science, King Abdul Aziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Amin Marghalani, M., Department of Library and Information Science, King Abdul Aziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: This article analyses and discusses the microcomputer technology and underlines the scope of microcomputers for the automation of public services, administrative activities and technical operations in libraries with special reference to the application of micros in small public libraries. the reduction in hardware prices has resulted in the rapidly increasing demand for software packages therby making it expedient for libraries to choose economically viable micros. The author lays stress on librarians to become familiar with the latest information technology for the effective functioning of small libraries and equip themselves for active participation in the international communication systems. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Mystery and detective fiction: A qualitative approach
Affiliations: Catalog Librarian, Iowa State University, Ames, IA, 50011-2140, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gerhard, K.H., Catalog Librarian, Iowa State University, Ames, IA, 50011-2140, United States
Abstract: Should public libraries collect detective fiction? On what basis? Demand alone does not seem a useful criterion in building enduring, high quality collections. Yet the quality of mystery fiction has been debated for years. Rather than continuing the debate on its old terms, we need to reframe it. Detective stories must be judged in terms of what they intend to accomplish within their genre. In evaluating a specific title, librarians should consider how well a work meets the requirements of the form, and what unique contribution it makes. These guidelines may be extended to other genres. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Affiliations: Board of Trustees, Free Public Library, Florham Park, NJ, United States

Title: Identifying a professional core collection for the librarian of the small-to medium-sized public library: A national survey
Affiliations: Learning Resources Center, John Brown University, Siloam Springs, AR, United States; Library Services, Tarrant County Junior College, Fort Worth, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vines Henderson, M., Learning Resources Center, John Brown University, Siloam Springs, AR, United States; Heyser, R.G., Library Services, Tarrant County Junior College, Fort Worth, TX, United States
Abstract: Two core collections of professional materials considered helpful in the day-to-day operation of small-to medium-sized public libraries were identified. One core collection was identified through a review of the professional literature and a national survey of public librarians. The second core collection was identified through a comparison of the national study and an earlier study performed in Oklahoma. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Fiction selection in ontario public libraries-how important are reviews?
Affiliations: School of Information and Library Studies, State University of New York, Buffalo, NY, 14260, United States
Authors with affiliations: Palmer, J.W., School of Information and Library Studies, State University of New York, Buffalo, NY, 14260, United States
Abstract: To investigate the influence of reviews on public library fiction selection in a large, diverse geographic region, a study of fiction selection in Ontario public libraries vary greatly in the extent to which they depend on reviews for the selection of hardcover English language fiction. Overall, reviews are less important than non-review sources. This seems due to the existence of reliable pre-publication pre-review selection aids from sources such as the Ontario Library Services Center (OLSC) and the scarcity of pre-publication reviews of Canadian fiction. The study predicts similar diversity in other North American public libraries with considerable regional variation and, since pre-publication reviews of fiction from U.S. publishers are plentiful, with greater reliance on reviews by U.S. libraries. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: How public librarians view latchkey children
Affiliations: Children’s Librarian, Cuyahoga County Public Library System, United States; School of Library Science, Kent State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, D., Children’s Librarian, Cuyahoga County Public Library System, United States; Buttlar, L., School of Library Science, Kent State University, United States
Abstract: This study investigated the attitudes of children’s librarians in public libraries in northeast Ohio toward latchkey children and the quantity and types of programs designed for them. Survey results indiciation that, in most cases, unattended children are using libraries as a safe place to stay while the parent(s) are working. While librarians see them as a problem, they also think that their libraries should do more to accommodate them. The majority feel that programming should be a community effort, but only a small minority report such involvement. Findings also indicate a definite need for policy development regarding latchkey children in public libraries. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Libraries and the new censorship: A postscript
Affiliations: St. Louis University Law Library, St. Louis, MO, 63108, United States
Authors with affiliations: McKenzie, E.M., St. Louis University Law Library, St. Louis, MO, 63108, United States
Abstract: Reports on the feminist attack on pornography which culminated in several ordinances allowing persons injured by pornography to sue the producer and distributors for damages. This article discusses recent developments, including court challenges to the constitutionality of those ordinances. Librarians must address the issues these feminist thinkers have raised. Even if we do not face local laws allowing libraries to be sued for "distributing" pornography we need to reexamine our role in society in light of the feminists' arguments. By supporting pornographers' free speech rights, are we perpetuating a form of propaganda for the oppression and abuse of women?. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: An analysis of the use and effectiveness of various recruitment sources at public libraries
Affiliations: Clarion University, Clarion, PA, United States; College of Business Administration, Clarion University of Pennsylvania, Clarion, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pesek, J.G., Clarion University, Clarion, PA, United States; Grunenwald, J.P., College of Business Administration, Clarion University of Pennsylvania, Clarion, PA, United States
Abstract: This article reports the findings of a survey of public library use of various sources of recruitment for librarians, library administrators, and library support staff. The level of use of particular recruitment sources is discussed as well as the perceived level of effectiveness for each of the sources. Differences in perceptions of effectiveness of recruitment sources between those who use a particular source and those who do not are also analyzed in this article. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Identifying a professional core collection for the librarian of the small-to medium-sized public library
Affiliations: Learning Resources Center, John Brown University, Siloam Springs, AR, United States; Library Services, Tarrant County Junior College, Fort Worth, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vines Henderson, M., Learning Resources Center, John Brown University, Siloam Springs, AR, United States; Heyser, R.G., Library Services, Tarrant County Junior College, Fort Worth, TX, United States
Abstract: A core collection of professional materials considered helpful in the day-to-day operation of small-to medium-sized public libraries was identified through a review of the professional literature and a survey of public library practitioners in Oklahoma. Highly Recommended and Recommended titles are listed in three categories: Administration and Management, Public Services, and Technical Services. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Why public libraries?
Affiliations: The Jean and Alexander Heard Library, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, 37325-1819, United States
Authors with affiliations: Getz, M., The Jean and Alexander Heard Library, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, 37325-1819, United States
Abstract: Why Public Libraries?" was first presented as a booklet in conjunction with "Libraries 2000," a seminar held in Alberta, Canada. The seminar was designed to re-examine the function and future development of libraries in that Canadian province. A second publication, "Why Books?" will appear in a future edition of Public Library Quarterly. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Statistics of renewals in public libraries
Affiliations: Graduate School of Library and Information Science, University of Illinois at Urbana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goldhor, H., Graduate School of Library and Information Science, University of Illinois at Urbana, United States
Abstract: Very little data are available on public library renewals. In a related study of CLSI Daily Logs for 14 Illinois public libraries for 1986/87, it was discovered that the number of renewals was recorded as well as the total daily circulation. The five libraries without renewals served fewer people on the average, had a lower total annual circulation, and used a longer loan period than the nine libraries with renewals. Renewals were about 3% of total circulation-almost 6% for those with two-week loan periods and only 2% for those with four-week loans. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Teen suicide and the library
Affiliations: Science and Technology, Auburn University’s Ralph Brown Draughon Library, Auburn, AL, 36849-5606, United States
Authors with affiliations: Havens, C., Science and Technology, Auburn University’s Ralph Brown Draughon Library, Auburn, AL, 36849-5606, United States
Abstract: Teen suicide is a widespread problem which has recently increased dramatically. Part of the problem relates to the prevalence of anxiety during the teen years. Librarians and the library can help with the problem in direct and indirect ways. Librarians are encouraged to be supportive of young adult patrons. Suggestions are given concerning young adult departments. Public libraries could directly help with the problem by sponsoring programs to help young adults deal with anxiety and depression, to help parents and teachers identify teenagers at a high risk for suicide, and to increase community awareness. Librarians who suspect that a teenage patron or employee may be suicidal should intervene, preferably by referring the young adult to a trained counselor or suicide prevention agency. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Pressure groups and intellectual freedom
Affiliations: Reference Librarian, University of Evansville, Evansville, IN, 47722, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abbott, R.L., Reference Librarian, University of Evansville, Evansville, IN, 47722, United States
Abstract: This article explores the rise of conservatism in the United States during the 1980s and the corresponding increase in reported instances of censorship in public libraries and school media centers. The rise of pressure groups and their impact on intellectual freedom is reviewed. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Occupational users and uses of the public library
Affiliations: Department of Library Science, Indiana State University, Terre Haute, IN, 47809, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, C.H., Department of Library Science, Indiana State University, Terre Haute, IN, 47809, United States
Abstract: Three hypotheses concerning public library users and uses are proposed: the general hypothesis is that the library user’s principal occupation or lack of one has a major bearing on the way one uses the local public library. More specifically, (1) the degree to which any occupational group is dependent on recorded knowledge and information is correlated with its library use; (2) the work related library use increases with the level of independent decision making authority and responsibility in the work; (3) for those employed, work is the most compelling of all reasons for library use. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Does your boss think you've aged on the job like fine wine?
Affiliations: Hour Savers Career Services, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baldwin, E., Hour Savers Career Services, United States
Abstract: A survey of top-level public and private sector decision makers tells us that, in general, by far their best workers are their older employees. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Personnel management in libraries
Affiliations: Miami-Dade Public Library System, Miami, FL, 33130-1504, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cummins, T.R., Miami-Dade Public Library System, Miami, FL, 33130-1504, United States
Abstract: Few topics within the area of public library administration have generated as much print and speculation as the area of personnel evaluation. Over the past 20 years there has been increasing interest in evaluation tools with the resulting development of criteria for evaluating work performance in library settings. In this article, the author reviews the literature over the past several years in an effort to further define the proper role of employee evaluation and how it can improve public library service. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Latchkey children: A community and public library phenomenon
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Studies, Texas Woman’s University, Denton, TX, 76204, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smardo Dowd, F., School of Library and Information Studies, Texas Woman’s University, Denton, TX, 76204, United States
Abstract: This article begins with background information regarding the phenomenon of latchkey children-estimates of their numbers, economic and social implications, contributing factors, and corporate and community responses to this situation. Within this broader context, library latchkey children are discussed. In particular, this describes the dilemma and the difficulties which latchkey children present for librarians, as well as the strategies particular libraries have implemented to deal with this clientele. Highlights of the joint PLA and ALSC position paper, entitled "Latchkey Children" in the Public Library, are presented. A brief case study of San Marino Public Library’s successful approach is given. Lastly, narrative data from the author’s survey research at the national level on the topic are summarized. Specifically, this includes the perceptions of children’s coordinators and children’s librarians in regard to the public library’s role, main challenge, and interaction with community agencies, in serving latchkey children. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Putting knowledge to work
Affiliations: Omaha Public Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jehlik, T., Omaha Public Library, United States
Abstract: The creation of the Business Reference and Services (BRASS) Section of ALA in 1987 is a strong indicator that the needs of the business community are of paramount concern to many libraries. This article presents a historical overview of the relationship between the business community and the public library. Topics convered in this survey include the facilities, staff, and collection needed to provide effective service. Current and desired library services for business patrons are discussed as well as the marketing of such services. Use studies are also examined to discover what types of materials are most frequently used and what kind of information is most desired by business patrons. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The informational value, accessibility, and collection of regional planning publications
Affiliations: Benzak Business Librarian, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zabel, D., Benzak Business Librarian, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, 16802, United States
Abstract: Regional planning agencies produce a wide range of valuable documents that should be accessible to the public through libraries. The bibliographic control of these documents is inadequate, necessitating special efforts by librarians to obtain this information. Regional planning publications should be considered an integral part of any local documents collection. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Bibliographic instruction in the public library: To have or not to have, that is the question
Affiliations: Library Services, Huntington College, 2303 College Ave, Huntington, IN, 46750, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kaehr, R.E., Library Services, Huntington College, 2303 College Ave, Huntington, IN, 46750, United States
Abstract: This article considers whether or not public libraries are meeting the needs of formal bibliographic instruction for out-of-school patrons, with a major emphasis on older adults. Senior adults, it is contended, have specific needs that must be considered before bibliographic instruction programs can be instituted. Suggestions on how to address such as challenges and where to find further information is given. The article closes with a caution to carefully determine, not by intuition, but by empirical evidence, whether of not there is a need for bibliographic instruction. It is felt, however, when the evidence is collected, in most cases, out-of-school adults will be better served with a formal bibliographic instruction program. © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: A self study and evaluation of the children's department of the orange county library system
Affiliations: Children's Department, Orange County Library System, Orlando, FL, 32801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peterson, C.L., Children's Department, Orange County Library System, Orlando, FL, 32801, United States
Abstract: Orange County, Florida, the home of Disney World, Epcot and other major tourist attractions, is one of the fastest growing urban areas in the United States. The growth is no longer-if it ever was-limited to retirees who have moved south to the warmth of the "Sunshine State." Young families are moving to central Florida, and the number of school-age children in the county has increased dramatically over the past several years. The same is true of Osceola County, a county that Orange serves by contract. In this first of a two-part series, the staff of the Children's Department takes a detailed look at the population they are serving-and will be in the years ahead-and the impact on the library materials collection and readers advisory and reference services. The second part (to appear in the next issue of Public Library Quarterly) will look at programming for children and adults, information gaps, staffing and scheduling, and staff development, performance and evaluation. Goals for the next five years are also discussed. © 1989 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: A place of discovery: Urban libraries in the sunbelt; year 2000
Affiliations: County Librarian, Orange County Public Library, 431 city Drive south, Orange, CA, 92668-9990, United States
Authors with affiliations: Martinez Smith, E., County Librarian, Orange County Public Library, 431 city Drive south, Orange, CA, 92668-9990, United States
Abstract: What will the public library of the year 2000 be like? The speculation is exciting and challenging, and necessary. The year 2000 is now but eleven short years away. The Orange County Public Library has prepared for that day by means of a Library Master Plan which details library development for one of the fastest growing urban areas in the country. © 1989 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Politics and the public library
Affiliations: Assistant Dean, College of Library and Information Science, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, 40506-0039, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carrigan, D.P., Assistant Dean, College of Library and Information Science, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, 40506-0039, United States
Abstract: Although often admitted only reluctantly, and at times even denied, nevertheless the inescapable reality is that the public library, as a public agency, functions within a political context. But the external political system within which the public library must operate is not the only political system that bears upon it. There is also a political system at work within the library, as a result of the need that it govern itself, and the inevitability of occasional conflict. It is imperative that the librarian be aware of the existence of the internal political system, and function effectively within it. © 1989 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Oral history and libraries
Affiliations: Latham ' Watkins, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, F., Latham ' Watkins, United States
Abstract: The nature of librarianship has changed. It involves the traditional skills of acquisitions and selection, organization and processing, servicing and dissemination. It also suggests the development of skills, abilities and attitudes which reflect and incorporate the creation and generation of information, often in new, different and usable forms. One area in which this is evident is in oral history. © 1989 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Public library adult learning center renewal
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Studies, University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK, 73019, United States; Graduate student, School of Library and Information Studies, University of Oklahoma, United States
Authors with affiliations: Faibisoff, S., School of Library and Information Studies, University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK, 73019, United States; Willis, D., Graduate student, School of Library and Information Studies, University of Oklahoma, United States
Abstract: The authors explore a module that involves administrative collaboration among public and academic libraries in Oklahoma. Specifically, the paper looks at public libraries and their potential as educational and career centers. The concept of these centers, if carried to fruition, will change the image of public libraries from recreational and referral centers to centers for the delivery of higher education. © 1989 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Children's librarians and bph subregional librarians: Coordinating children's services
Affiliations: Information Management, Emporia State University, United States; Catalog Librarian, William Allen White Library, Emporia State University, Emporia, KS, 66801, United States
Authors with affiliations: DeHart, F.E., Information Management, Emporia State University, United States; Matthews, K., Catalog Librarian, William Allen White Library, Emporia State University, Emporia, KS, 66801, United States
Abstract: Ways are explored in which public library children's librarians can help sighted children increase their understanding of persons with visual impairment and their skills in communicating with them. Interviews were conducted with six children's librarians and six BPH subregional librarians, and searches were made in the public library catalogs and the Regional BPH Library fiche catalog for selected titles. Three areas for discussion emerged: Reader advisory and reference questions, collection development, and programming. Public library children's librarians and BPH subregional librarians can jointly coordinate provision of children's services by identifying and building on present strengths in collection development and programming. © 1989 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The first five years of plq, 1979-1984: A bibliometric analysis
Affiliations: Library Science, University of Alberta, Rutherford South, Edmonton, AB, T6G 2J4, Canada; Stony Plain Library, Stony Plain, AB, T0E 2G0, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Schrader, A.M., Library Science, University of Alberta, Rutherford South, Edmonton, AB, T6G 2J4, Canada; Beswick, L., Stony Plain Library, Stony Plain, AB, T0E 2G0, Canada
Abstract: This study describes and evaluates key bibliometric patterns in the articles published in the first five volumes of Public Library Quarterly (PLQ), from 1979 to 1984. Data were collected from each issue of PLQ and analyzed through SPSSx. PLQ is shown to be a scholarly journal, with two-thirds of its articles containing bibliographic citations. A further indication of the Journal's scholarliness is the high reliance of its authors on journals for their citations. Although a stated aim of PLQ is to publish articles by public library practitioners, this occupational group was not a major contributor to the Journal during the period under study. © 1989 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors with affiliations: Nelms, W., Sheppard Memorial Library, Greenville, NC, 27834, United States; Taylor, D., Technical Services, Sheppard Memorial Library, Greenville, NC, 27858, United States
Abstract: This paper looks at one method in the continuing saga of "The Return of the Overdue Book." The Sheppard Memorial Library, headquartered in Greenville, North Carolina, serves 95,000 persons, with an annual circulation of approximately 300,000. © 1989 by The Haworth Press, Inc.
