Title: The story of the los angeles county public library
Affiliations: County Librarian, Los Angeles Public Library, Downey, CA, 90241-8020, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crismond, L.F., County Librarian, Los Angeles Public Library, Downey, CA, 90241-8020, United States
Abstract: The Los Angeles County Public Library is one of the largest, if not the largest, public library systems in the country. The system now serves three million persons via a network of branch libraries, bookmobiles and other service stations. Last year the library system celebrated its 75th anniversary. This article traces the history of the library from its founding in 1912 to its present development. © 1989 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Planning today for service tomorrow
Affiliations: Metropolitan Library System, Oklahoma City, OK, 73122-7410, United States; Public Library Consultant, Oklahoma Department of Libraries, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brawner, L.B., Metropolitan Library System, Oklahoma City, OK, 73122-7410, United States; Ellison, S., Public Library Consultant, Oklahoma Department of Libraries, United States
Abstract: The public library is under increasing pressure to plan for the future in a manner that will permit it to continue to respond to the needs and demands of local residents while, at the same time, stabilize-if not reduce-expenditures as local tax dollars become more and more difficult to obatin. This article reviews some of the basic planning steps that public libraries can follow, and provides reasons for planning. © 1989 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: The administration of branch libraries in a developing country: A case study
Affiliations: Department of Library Studies, University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Nzotta, B.C., Department of Library Studies, University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria
Abstract: Branch libraries are considered important for effective public library service to large communities. This study was aimed at investigating the administration of branch libraries in a developing country, Nigeria. A pretested mail questionnaire was used for data collection. Usable responses were received from twelve state public library services which had 66 branch libraries. The branch libraries were inadequate for the populations they were meant to serve. They were poorly funded and staffed, and had small collections. Though efforts were made to reflect the interests and needs of the branch libraries in book selection and other aspects, heads of branch libraries had inadequate administrative powers for efficient management of their units. © 1989 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public libraries' adaptation to the environment
Affiliations: Department of Library and Bibliographic Studies, Bar Ilan University, Ramat Gau, 52900, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shoham, S., Department of Library and Bibliographic Studies, Bar Ilan University, Ramat Gau, 52900, Israel
Abstract: The interaction of the public library with the environment is analyzed based on an empirical study of six California public libraries. Two adaptive responses are defined: changes in the organization and attempts to change the environment. Both kinds of techniques are described, followed by an analysis of the factors influencing library behavior. © 1989 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Library services for the blind in west germany
Affiliations: Head Librarian at Indiana University School of Dentistry, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hook, S.A., Head Librarian at Indiana University School of Dentistry, United States
Abstract: This paper presents an overview of library services for the blind in West Germany through studying the Suddeutsche Blindenhor- und Punktschrift- Bucherei in Baden-Wurtternberg. Information is based on an interview with Mario Peterek, Director of the Suddeutsche Blindenhor, which was conducted in August 1985. There are some differences between the German and American systems for library services to the blind; however, they share the mission of integrating blind individuals into the life of the community. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Letters libraries and broadcasting they go back together a long way
Affiliations: The University of Wisconsin Milwaukcc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Berkman, D., The University of Wisconsin Milwaukcc, United States
Abstract: Letters, and the library which reposts them, have been ambivalent in their reactions to the various communications technologies which have emerged in the 20th century. Some have seen them as portending the death of rint. Others have seen in each of these an a ly which can enhance 0th the printed word and the role of the library. This article, based on what the periodical press of the early 1920s reported, looks at how the first of the electronic technologies, radio, was initially perceived in the world of letters and libraries. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public library unions some questions
Affiliations: University of Pennsylvania, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schlessinger Karp, R., University of Pennsylvania, United States
Abstract: A recent survey of 2317 unionized and nonunionized public librarians found that public librarians who were pro-union were most likely to (1) be employed in larger libraries, (2) have worked less years as librarians, (3) command lower salaries, (4) be politically liberal, (5) have had less administrative experience, (6) be employed in libraries without staff associations or in libraries where union representation was nationally affiliated, and (7) be union members. The study also found that public library union members held less favorable attitudes toward service than their colleagues who were not members of the union. The findings indicate that unions may not be the preferred mode of representation for public librarians and [hat they may be causing a decrease in professionalism within the field. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Abstract: County libraries in suburban communities are located throughout the United States. This survey article offers interesting comparative data for those that meet specific criteria. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: On windows in libraries
Affiliations: Department of Anesthesiology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Foregger, R., Department of Anesthesiology, United States
Abstract: Windows in libraries are energy expensive and unnecessary. They transfer heat losses in winter and heat gains in summer and create reading difficulties due to sun glare. Windows are unrcliable sources of library lighting because of variations in daylight intensity. They cannot be used safely for ventilation. These factors outweigh the informational and psychological value of view out. Since some library buildings continue to be constructed with large glassed-in areas, a review of the advantages and disadvantages of windows in libraries is pertinent. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public libraries and political culture
Affiliations: University Librarian, Dalhousie University, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Birdsall, W.F., University Librarian, Dalhousie University, Canada
Abstract: The ambiguity of public library goals arises in part out of the variety of sources of public library ideology. This ideology consists of values derived from conservatism, socialism, and especially, liberalism. While this diversity of sources contributes to contradictory goals and to inherent weaknesses in some library programs, it also can contribute to greater institutional flexibility and vitality, thereby enhancing the chances of institutional survival. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors with affiliations: Roy, H.
Abstract: Public libraries are people's institutions. This article presents the findings of a survey on the views of some neo-Canadian children on the Saint-Laurent Municipal Library in Montreal. The advantages of multicultural iibrary services for children are demon- strated. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Organizing a local history collection in a small public library
Affiliations: Genealogy and Local History Department, Springfield City Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carvalho III, J., Genealogy and Local History Department, Springfield City Library, United States
Abstract: When attempted on a modest scale, local history col- lections can offer a unique component to the library's repertoire of reference services. Establishing a local history collection has both short- and long-term implications concerning library policies, space allocation, staff time, staff training, and budgets. Because of this, -. the small public library should clearly and realistically establish a collection policy which will not place an undue burden on its re- sources. Assessing community needs is a critical part of this pro- cess. Small public libraries should not attempt to duplicate or com- pete with other institutions for local material. Rather, the library should seek to fill the void in public service in cases where there is no extant collection available to the public. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Services offered to preschool children in texas public libraries
Affiliations: Audiovisual Librarian, East Central University, Ada, OK, 74820, United States; Department of English, North Texas State University, Denton, TX, 76203, United States; School of Library and Information Studies, Texas Woman's University, Denton, TX, 76204, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams Bergin, J., Audiovisual Librarian, East Central University, Ada, OK, 74820, United States; Schlessinger, J.H., Department of English, North Texas State University, Denton, TX, 76203, United States; Schlessinger, B.S., School of Library and Information Studies, Texas Woman's University, Denton, TX, 76204, United States
Abstract: Services to preschoolers in public libraries in Texas are offered by the majority of the libraries (87.4%), but the offerings are, for the most part, recent developments, with 62.1% in existence for less than 20 years, and 44.7% in existence for less than 10 years. The services are supported by very small allocations from library budgets (the majority allocated less than 2% of the library budget), and are staffed by primarily nonprofessionals (79.2%) without struc- tured professional education in either librarianship or early child- hood concerns. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public library patrons and selected social issues
Affiliations: School of Information and Library Science, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, 27514, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carpenter, R.L., School of Information and Library Science, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, 27514, United States
Abstract: From 1971 to 1986 the proportion of adult library users grew from 24% to 40%. Users today are better educated and more homogenous in income than in 1971. Much of the growth in user population is due to the new buildings, programs and media made available since 1971. The need for microcomputer support services can be seen to be growing rapidly. Although users are better informed than nonusers, they are fairly alike in their attitudes toward such issues as capital punishment and the effect of alcohol on driv- ing. Some attitudes may indicate need for more information that might be provided by public libraries. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Cooperation in the public service institution: The public library and the local governmental structure
Affiliations: Joseph F. Smith Library, Brigham Young University-Hawaii Campus, Laie, HI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Webb, T.D., Joseph F. Smith Library, Brigham Young University-Hawaii Campus, Laie, HI, United States
Abstract: A recent three-year study of public library reorgani- zations suggests that many of the financial difficulties facing public libraries are due to a general lack of management information about the actual value of library service's to the public. Since char ing fees % for service is not a workable option, an alternative may e to rn- crease intergovernmental cooperation between the library and other governmental agencies. Various agencres often share goals and au- diences with the library or have needs that the library can answer. Capitalizing on these overlaps can strengthen the position of the li- brary within the governmental structure and demonstrate to local government budgetmakers the value of the library to the parent orga- nization, even if its value to the publicremains somewhat uncertain. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Abstract: The author describes the series of projects undertaken by the King County Library System (Seattle, WA) in planning and developing a large public library circulating videocassette service. The projects include paiticipation in a video cooperative, rotating and fixed collections, centralized and dispersed collections. The ar- ticle describes the decision-making processes called upon to solve problems with reserves and booking policies and with staff and pa- tron altitudes. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Affiliations: School of Librarianship, University of New South Wales, Australia

Abstract: The DaDer reDorts a studv of the information seeking behavior of membek bf 52 cummunityr anizations in a suburbai communirv in Svdnev, Australia. It considers the significance of the findings fbr public library information services tosuch organiza- tions, with particular reference lo differences between librarians' and organization members' perceptions of "information"; the irn- portance of networks and mutuality in organizations' information seeking; and the desirability and feasibility of public libraries inter- vening to improve the information processes of community organi- zations. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, 78731, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roy, L., The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, 78731, United States
Abstract: Fifty-two public libraries in Illinois were surveyed to test an instrument measuring volunteer use. Ninety-eight percent of the libraries returned completed questionnaires. Results indicate that volunteers are currently used in (57% (34) of the libraries within this group, an increase in the level reported in earlier studies. Demo- graphic data is used to construct profiles of the libraries using volun- teers and those not using volunteers. Survey findings identify rea- sons for using or not using volunteers, list the types of activities that volunteers perform, and describe charactcristics of existing volun- teer programs. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public library users, nonusers, and type of library use
Affiliations: Social/Environmental Psychology, Claremont Graduate School, Oceanside, CA, 92056, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lange, J.M., Social/Environmental Psychology, Claremont Graduate School, Oceanside, CA, 92056, United States
Abstract: A telephone survey of library users and nonusers was conducted in one county of a Southwestern state. Prediction of li- brary use versus nonuse and three aspects of library use (frequency, diversity, and duration) were each based upon different groups of variables. Five types of library use were defined. Present patterns of library use and emerging library-related opportunities suggest that a more accurate description of public librarians could be opportunity providers rather than information providers. © 1988 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Two public libraries in india: Connemara and kottayam
Affiliations: Reference Department, Brookline Public Library, 361 Washington St, Brookline, MA, 02146, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abraham, D.V.H., Reference Department, Brookline Public Library, 361 Washington St, Brookline, MA, 02146, United States
Abstract: The growth of public libraries in India has paralleled the directions of national interest. Libraries received great attention and support during the social movements which accompanied inde- pendence. Today, libraries must struggle for funds, space and trained staff to serve the multilingual and multicultural needs of their com- munities effectively. Successful examples of two types of public li- braries are examined and described. The Connemara Public Library of Madras is a government-supported library in a large city with responsibilities for regional support and depository status. The Kot- tayam Public Library is a subscription library in a medium-sized commercial center and college town. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Abstract: Online catalogs are more than an extension of the card catalog. They are something entirely new and under continuous de- velopment. Although users are enthusiastic about online catalogs. their ositive attitude may change unless certain problems are cor- rectef The library profession should develop specifications for on- line catalogs that will help eliminate user problems. Online catalogs interact with the user and can give himlher a sense of control if more modes of access for effective retrieval are designed. Online catalogs of the future should be more efficient if librarians have greater input in their design. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Poses ways for libraries to become integral working partners with other professionals in the burgeoning information matrix. Suggests ways of marketing and making more accessible materials in government documents division. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Marketing strategy for children's services
Affiliations: Florida State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koontz Lynch, C., Florida State University, United States; Rockwood, P.E., Florida State University, United States
Abstract: The survey was conducted to further substantiate and extend knowledge of the vital role of children's sewices in ublic library sewice. The findings are compared with two studies ofsimi- lar inquiry. It was determined that frequent childhood use portends adult use. Family interest, school media center access, sex, and education are significantly associated with adult library use. Adult patronage is principally for personal rather than work or other pur- poses. The findings gude the formulation of marketing strategy, par- ticularly market develo ment and promotional policy, designed to live patrons. i increase the use of chi1 ren's services and to develop long-term aclive patrons. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Economic hard times and public library use: A close look at the librarians' axiom
Affiliations: School of Library and Information Studies, Atlanta University, Atlanta, GA, United States
Authors with affiliations: James, S.E., School of Library and Information Studies, Atlanta University, Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: This research examines the librarians' rule of thumb which suggests that public library use increases during economic hard times. A report of British research by Warr and Payne is men- tioned to show that American response to economic stringency does not mirror British behavior regarding similar stimuli. Research find- ings from the American study indicate that a stringent test of the librarians' axiom reveals no significant relationship between library use and the economy. A more relaxed interpretation of the data sug- gests a positive relationship between library cards in force and local unemployment rates but a negative relationship behveen circulation figures and local inflation rates. Overall, the study uncovers no com- pelling data to support the librarians' axiom. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The public library services in nigeria: Need for information and referral (i'r) service
Affiliations: Medical librarian, University of Benin Library, P.M.B. 1191, Benin City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Igbinosa, I.O., Medical librarian, University of Benin Library, P.M.B. 1191, Benin City, United States
Abstract: The article highlights the functions of the public Ii- brary. It acknowledges the contributions of some authors on the pat- tern and development to the literature of public library services in Nigeria and then analyzes the characteristics of the services. The concept and processes of Information and Referral (I ' R) service are explained. There is a recommendation that public library should set up I ' R service to enhance the awareness of public library ser- vices. The problems likely to militate against an efficient I ' R ser- vice are examined. It avers that there are good prospects for an I ' R service in Nigeria and urges the public libraries to embark on the service. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Librarians and the new censorship
Affiliations: Kentucky Department for Environmental Protection, United States
Authors with affiliations: McKenzie, E.M., Kentucky Department for Environmental Protection, United States
Abstract: Most librarians, as well as most feminists, have long held liberal views on most issues, including freedom of information or free speech. Thus, it is assumed that both groups share an antip- athy toward censorship. Theorists of the women's movement have begun redefining the issue of pornography, however, as one of an in- fringement of women's civil rights, rather than one of free speech. One result of this redefinition is a crop of proposed new ordinances giving women the right to bring a civil suit against the producers and distributors of pornography. These ordinances would include li- braries as distributors of pornography. Librarians must familiarize themselves with the feminists' arguments for a new type of censor- ship in order to understand legal developments that may affect them profoundly. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Public library services for young children in day care and their caregivers
Affiliations: Early Childhood Services, Dallas Public Library, 1515 Young Street, Dallas, TX, 75201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smardo, F.A., Early Childhood Services, Dallas Public Library, 1515 Young Street, Dallas, TX, 75201, United States
Abstract: This article deals with the who, what, when, where and'why of public library services to young children in day care and to their adult caregivers. Descriptions are given of several note- worthy public library projects throughout the United States for this particular clientele. A profile of day care at the national level is reported, which includes documentation of current and projected enrollments; the general minimum qualifications and the average wages of staff; stafflchild ratios; and the impact of caregiver train- ing, group size, and childlcaregiver interactions upon the quality of care and the cognitive and social development of young children. The final portion concerns two specific environmental factors which contribute toward the literacy development and the library usage of young children, and contains practical suggestions for the initial planning and implementation of public library services to this special target audience. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Literary criticism of children's books: The significant journals
Affiliations: School of Library Science, The University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, 48103, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weedman, J., School of Library Science, The University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, 48103, United States
Abstract: Members of the Children's Literature Association were surveyed in order to identify journals which publish criticism of children's literature. Ninety journals were listed by respondents; these are categorized by orientation and audience. The 33 most- frequently-named journals are identified, and those devoted primari- ly to criticism of children's literature are distinguished from those which serve as important but occasional sources. Patterns in the cita- tions by respondents are examined. Three conclusions are drawn: The number of journals devoted primarily to the criticism of chil- dren's books is very small, current formal communication channels for scholars in this area are somewhat fragmented, and the criticism is found within a rich mixture of intellectual traditions. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Abstract: Personnel management is the critical issue facing li- brary administrators today. Within personnel management, the ef- fectiveness of supervisors determines how effective the library itself will be. Cumberland County Public Library ' Information Center decided to try a system of performance appraisal of supervisors by the people they supervise in an effort to improve supervisory perfor- mance systemwide. The library is satisfied that the system has re- sulted in improved supervisory performance, and plans to continue using it. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors with affiliations: Saxon, G.D., Oral Historian, Texas/Dallas History and Archives Division, Dallas Public Library, United States; Moltzan, J., Lakewood Community Library, Dallas Public Library, United States
Abstract: Public libraries have long been important reposi- tories for local history materials. In the following article, Ger- ald Saxon and Jan Moltzan discuss how the staff of Dallas Public Library's Lakewood Community Library, working closely with community volunteers, initiated a neighborhood oral history project. The project, labeled the Lakewood Oral History Project, began in 1972, and has led to both the cre- ation of a historically valuable community archives and the publication of a significant local history book. The Lakewood Project is a good example of library staff and neighborhood volunteers cooperating to preserve community history. © 1985 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: The third dimension: Dealing with objects in public library collections

Authors with affiliations: Bierbaum, E.G., School of Library Science, The University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, 52242, United States
Abstract: The results of a survey of three-dimensional ob- ject collections in randomly selected public libraries are re- ported. Over half of the 379 respondents had three-dimen- sional objects in the collections, the most popular categories being toys and games, and tools and household items. Local code or practice was the most frequent basis for cataloging, but AACR2 was cited next most frequently by those libraries cataloging both three-dimensional and audiovisual materials. Staff size was significant negatively: the libraries with 1-5 staff persons were least likely to catalog nonprint materials of any type. The author suggests that increased use of AACR2 and cooperative cataloging of nonprint formats will enhance public library collections both as to quality and accessibility. © 1985 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Title: Reference service in the children's department: A case study
Affiliations: The Urbana Free Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harrington, J., The Urbana Free Library, United States
Abstract: Reference and information requests received b the Children's Services Department of The Urbana (linois Free Library were analyzed according to the types of ques- tions asked and the distribution of adult and childiyoung adult patrons making the requests. It was found that a sub- stantial pro ortion of the re uests were made by adult pa- trons, and tiat adult and chiljren tend to ask different kinds of questions. Children tended to ask for assistance of an es- sentially mechanical nature, such as help in locating items and assistance with audiovisual materials. Adults tended to ask complex reader's advisory questions, reference questions, and questions concerning library policies and programs. It is sug- gested that children's departments need to make greater ef- forts to deliberately serve their adult patrons, that the analy- sis of reference and informational questions can lead to better collection development decisions, and that thorough commu- nity analysis may be essential to the effective functioning of a children's department. © 1985 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Abstract: This paper traces the career options available to children's. school, or young adulr librarians by talking with a number of individuals who were originally youth librarians but who now hold positions in administration and education. The career patterns of t h e interviewed reveal that the communications and leadership skills common in those librarians who work with young people hold them in good stead when they move to other positions. Included are responses concerning the importance of work in professional associations, reasons for changing positions. and career advice for other librarians. © 1985 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Affiliations: Stwkton Stale College Library, Pamona, NJ, 08240, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cohen, D., Stwkton Stale College Library, Pamona, NJ, 08240, United States
Abstract: The medium-sized public library has an important role to play in providing information to local officials. This role can be achieved on a minimal levcl by development of the collections, contacts with municipal leaders. and the use of specialized databases. The provision of such a service to local governments has two primary objectives: First, to heighten the visibility of the public library in the community, particularly among those controuing tax dollars; second, and most importantly, to provide information services to a level of government closest to the people. © 1985 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Abstract: The busincss librarian in a public library whose patrons seek information on R ' D activities, market or industry trends, candidates for executive or teclmical jobs, or candidates for corporate acquisitions or mergers, will find a wealth of information in patent literature. Authors with affiliations: Davis, M., Dimlor of Libraries, Plano Public Library System, Plano, TX, 75074, United States
Abstract: This article discusses the history of corporate philanthropy in the United States. It traces the response of corporations to cutbacks in federal spending initiated by President Ronald Reagan. The author concludes that libraries must learn to approach private corporations for in-kind donations, product donations, and volunteer help, as well as grant funds. Because corporations benefit through publicity, name recognition, and prestige, as well as in reduced taxes, it is to their advantage to assist public institutions such as libraries. © 1985 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The distribution of public library service
Affiliations: Department of Library Science, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shavit, D., Department of Library Science, Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL, United States
Abstract: Research into the distribution of public library service in urban America has made little progress, but some inroads have been made. Significant differences in the distribution of library service among neighborhoods within the same city have been reported. No clear pattern of intentional discrimination against low income and non-white neighborhoods in the provision of library service could be discerned, but inequitable library service was found in all of them. However, such inequitable library service distribution is caused by "unpatterned inequality" and bureaucratic decision rules. Public library directors must incorporate equity considerations into the day-today workings of the public library and guidelines are suggested. © 1984 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Abstract: There is an urgent need to identify potential library managers and prepare them for responsible positions. There is an equally pressing need for programs designed to provide current managers with additional information on new trends and developments in library administration. In order to expand and update the knowledge, skills, and abilities of present library managers and to establish a larger pool of qualified candidates for managerial positions, planned management development programs and/or activities are necessary. This study is an effort to determine the direction in which large public libraries are moving toward planning and establishing management development programs as well as to explore strategies used to attain financial support for such programs. © 1984 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Abstract: Planning for library security and safety encompasses protection against fire, smoke, intrusion, vandalism, and protection for users and staff. It also includes disaster planning, housing and preservation of library materials in all formats, and handling behavioral problems that occur in the library and all types of criminal acts committed against library users, staff, and the library's contents. This article will focus on safety and security in the library and show how criminal acts and behavioral problems impact the library and its operations and will suggest some practical steps to help prevent or minimize the incidence of such problems. © 1984 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Abstract: The benefits for libraries of establishing trust funds to receive monies donated by public and private donors are discussed. Included are steps for establishing a legal, tax-exempt foundation and foundation board to administer the trust fund and assist in fund raising. The advantages for libraries of a source of funds separate from the jurisdiction of city or county government are pointed out. In conclusion, the author provides a survey of a number of library foundations in communities of various sizes throughout the United States. © 1984 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The texas public library trustee
Affiliations: Texas Woman s University, P.O. Box 22905, Denton, TX, 76204, United States

Abstract: Public Library trustees in Texas resemble trustees nationally in that they are appointed primarily by a public official or governing body; they see their major duties connected with decisions on policies, funding, and librarian employment; their tenures are short (the majority five years or less); and they attend monthly meetings. Differences from the national scene exist in the areas of sex distribution (the majority are women); membership in national and state trustee organizations (very low for Texas); presence of formal bylaws (94-5 percent of libraries); and education (lightly regarded for both new and continuing trustees). © 1984 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Educational and informational needs of public library users in nigeria
Affiliations: Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Onadiran, G.T., Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria; Onadiran, R.W., Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to examine the educational and informational needs of public library users in Nigeria. The data was obtained from the answers to an inquiry form handed to persons entering the library during a typical six days of operation in seven public libraries in Nigeria. It was discovered that a large number of users used the library as "study hall" (69.1 percent) and seek library materials for their school work (72.3 percent). It is recommended that public libraries should gear their collections to the needs of the people. Focused collection rather than balanced collection is recommended. Normal library functions should be expanded to include education, literacy, and health care. © 1984 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors with affiliations: Valentine, P.M., Cumberland County Public Library, 328 Gillespie Street, Fayetteville, NC, 28301, United States
Abstract: The North Carolina Foreign Language Center is a centralized multilingual public library which serves all residents of North Carolina. Local library patrons have direct access to its materials and services. Residents elsewhere can borrow materials and use its reference capabilities via InterLibrary Loan. The NCFLC is funded by the North Carolina State Library using L.S.C.A. funds. The NCFLC can serve as a model for other states with a low population density of non-English or limited-English speaking people. By making foreign language resources available through one library, North Carolina provides a wide selection of such materials and can afford the services of a full-time librarian to manage the collection. © 1984 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Volunteers in public libraries: Issues and viewpoints
Affiliations: University of Illinois, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roy, L., University of Illinois, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States
Abstract: A review of the American Library Association's 1971 Guidelines For Using Volunteers in Libraries is given as background to a discussion of public library volunteers. Opposing and supporting viewpoints towards volunteer use as expressed in the library literature are presented. The nature of the literature is examined, with special emphasis afforded to the purpose, methodology, and conclusions of research studies. The author concludes that, while the literature on public library volunteers has increased in volume over the past decade, little useful research-oriented reporting has been undertaken. The author suggests that the topic merits further investigation and research. © 1984 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Information transfer in city government

Authors with affiliations: Grover, R., Emporia State University, Emporia, KS, 66801, United States; Glazier, J., Emporia State University, United States
Abstract: Innovative research addressing information use patterns is needed to test theory which can serve as a conceptual framework for planning and evaluating information delivery systems. The research project reported here uses structured observation to examine information transfer patterns in city government. Resultsand implications for public libraries are reported. © 1984 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Does the use of a demand-oriented selection policy reduce overall collection quality? a review of the evidence
Affiliations: Fisher Court, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baker, S.L., Fisher Court, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States
Abstract: The author briefly describes arguments used in the quality versus demand debate, discusses how a number of public librarians have compromised between the two in their selection practices, and shows how battle lines are being redrawn with the rise of public libraries which claim to be exclusively demand-oriented. The bulk of the paper, however, reviews research done during the last quarter-century in public libraries to determine whether any evidence has been found to support claims that demand-oriented public libraries are filled with materials of dubious quality. While a great deal has been written on the quality versus demand issue, the author notes that much of it is rhetoric only; the research itself is scanty, in part due to the complexities of defining and measuring quality. However, three factors are identified which have been assumed to affect collection quality: the financial resources the library devotes to book purchases, the educational background of individual selectors, and the degree of contact such selectors have with the public. The author reviews studies relating to these factors and concludes that to date, there is no evidence to corroborate the belief that the quality of books in demand-oriented libraries is less than that of their qualityoriented counterparts. Suggestions for future research needed are included. © 1984 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Abstract: In 1975, administrators of Houston Independent School District, Houston Public Library and several other City of Houston departments met to discuss the cooperative planning of an educational complex. The complex involved the Carnegie Branch Library, John Marshall High School, Jefferson Davis High School, Houston Community College and a park site. After successful bond elections in 1976 by both the School District and the City, a master plan for the complex was developed. This resulted in the renovation of Davis, a new Marshall, and a new Carnegie serving both schools under contract and leasing space to the Community College. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Affiliations: State University of New York, United States

Abstract: Increasingly public libraries are recognizing their responsibilities in the areas of collecting and making available local history resources. Recently, a number of libraries have been involved with projects that collected oral history interviews and reprocessed them into illustrated publications, slide-tapes, videotapes, exhibitions, radio plays, and other products that made the raw materials of oral history accessible and meaningful to the general public. Examples of successful projects are described. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Abstract: For the first tutorial in 1983 the author has chosen to summarize the current status of the public library in relationship to the several technologies heralded as powering the new Information Age and to suggest ways in which the public library might participate. Turock, who teaches services and administration at Rutgers newly merged School of Communication, Information and Library Studies (SCILS) and who coordinates the new concentration in public librarianship, was, until 1980, Assistant Director of the Rochester and Monroe County (NY) Library System. Formerly she served as Assistant Director, then Director of the Montclair (NJ) Public Library. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Nice but peripheral some australian teacher librarians attitudes to cooperation between school and public libraries
Affiliations: University of New South Wale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vincent, I.D., University of New South Wale, United States
Abstract: The paper discusses the attitudes of teacher librarians in government schools in Sydney towards cooperation with public libraries and towards a sensible delineation of school and public library roles. Six case studies, based upon interviews conducted by the author, are presented. II is suggested that teacher librarians would like to cooperate, particularly with other school libraries, but that they need greater administrative support and leadership in order to do so. They regard cooperation with public libraries as a low priority, and see it mainly in terms of the public library supplementing the school library's collections. They rarely regard public librarians as colleagues sharing common professional goals. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Affiliations: Urban information Center, United States

Abstract: While other major business functions have been incorporated in the management of public libraries, marketing has been largely regarded as having only commercial applications. Dallas Public Library has experienced some success with the promotion and merchandising aspects of marketing. These experiences are detailed, and plans for developing a system-wide marketing strategy are outlined. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: The marriage of true minds towards a syllabus on public administration for public librarianship
Affiliations: North Texas State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Albertson, C., North Texas State University, United States
Abstract: In order to be more successful in carrying out their responsibilities, public librarians should become more aware of the larger field of public administration within which they practice their profession. A syllabus for a twelve-clock-hourunit on public administration for public librarianship is presented. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Some economies of online searching experience at houston public library
Affiliations: University of Texas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rollins, G., University of Texas, United States
Abstract: Describes how online retrieval is integrated into the Houston Public Librarys overall reference service. Examines the cost of manual versus online information retrieval at Houston Public Library, and describes additional benefits provided by online retrieval technology to the librarys reference service program. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: The varied uses of computer automation in british libraries
Affiliations: OxfordlOklahoma Library Seminar entitled, Libraries and Librarianship in England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Schoch, R., OxfordlOklahoma Library Seminar entitled, Libraries and Librarianship in England, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes automated systems and processes at various British libraries Including two public libraries Oxford shire County Central Library and Henley County Library two academic libraries, Bristol University Library and the Bodleian Library, Oxford a special library, the Rutherford Laboratory Library; a special library department of Oxford University, the Forestry Library; and Britain's National Library. The author observed automated processes and interviewed librarians and systems technicians at these libraries during the Oxford/Oklahoma Library Seminar, Libraries and Librarianship in England, held in Oxford from May 23-June11, 1982. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: New fiction, adult education, and the library
Affiliations: Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL, 60115, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hawking, J., Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL, 60115, United States
Abstract: Although sales of popular fiction are increasing steadily, the number of serious novelists able to support themselves by writing is decreasing. Because early library emphasis on raising popular taste has lessened and adult education efforts within libraries have diminished, libraries are often held responsible for the novelists' plight. In addition, adult education in general has moved from an emphasis on the liberal arts to a concentration on practical, "how-to" courses. The Great Book Discussion Program was the last major liberal arts adult education effort sponsored by a library. A program for discussion of subsidized quality new fiction is pro- posed. Novelists would be subsidized by library purchases. Such discussion groups would sometimes appear on a related public television show. The plan would provide fiction with a springboard other than publishers' promotions and literary establishment endorsements. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: A comparison of the impact of three methods of story hour presentation upon childrens listening skills
Affiliations: NIE Grant Project, 1515 Young Street, Dallas, TX, 75201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smardo, F.A., NIE Grant Project, 1515 Young Street, Dallas, TX, 75201, United States
Abstract: Weekly story hour programs were presented for 24 weeks to 437 children from daycare centers located in varying socioeconomic areas. The main purpose was to determine the effectiveness of three types of public library story hour programs in the acquisition of receptive language (listening skills) of children three, four, and five years of age. Subjects were randomly assigned to a "live" story hour; a 16mm commercially-produced film story hour: a video-taped story hour produced during the "live"; or to a control group. One-way analysis of covariance with two covariates (age in months and pretest Test of Basic Experiences, (TOBE) 2, Language) indicated significant differences existed among treatment groups. Both the "live" and the film treatments were significantly more effective than no story hour; and the "live" was significantly more effective than the video treatment. A second rest-i.e.-a story protocol-was not sensitive to differences between treatment groups. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Libraries and the political process: An opportunity for developing partnerships
Affiliations: Texas Womans University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sheldon, B.E., Texas Womans University, United States
Abstract: Given the uncertain state of the economy and the changing role of the federal government in solving social problems, librarians must work to become more effective politically. The author suggests that in 1983-1984 the ALA focus efforts on training members to seek legislation that strengthens library and information services. In addition, it emphasizes that librarians must become politically visible on state and local levels and must learn to actively seek financial support from the public and private sectors. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Some economic, and demographic realities facing library education
Affiliations: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, 48109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bidlack, R.E., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, 48109, United States
Abstract: The economic and demographic realities of library education and employment are discussed: I) Too many library schools, unevenly spread across the United States, vie for a dwindling number of students, training them for inadequately paid, scarce jobs as library professionals. 2) The shrinking enrollment in U.S. library schools has led to reductions in faculty and staff-in some cases, even school closings. 3) The "critical mass," the minimum number of students and faculty necessary for adequate preparation for a library career, often does not exist in the nation's library schools. 4) The role the ALA Committee on Accreditation should take in managing the current crisis in library education is questioned, and a need for revision of the current standards is suggested.5) Salaries of library professionals are compared un-favorably with pay scales in the information industry and math and science-related fields. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Denver public librarys nonresident fee policy
Affiliations: Denver Public Library, 3840 York Street, Denver, CO, 80205, United States
Authors with affiliations: Akeroyd, R.G., Jr., Denver Public Library, 3840 York Street, Denver, CO, 80205, United States
Abstract: This article describes the various events which led to imposition of cost-based nonresident fees at the Denver Public Library on October 1, 1981. The fee schedule is summarized along with an overview of the implementation process, response to the fees, and results after one year. Some implications for the future are also discussed. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: The browser and the library
Affiliations: University of New South Wales, Kensington, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Willard, P., University of New South Wales, Kensington, Australia; Teece, V., University of New South Wales, Kensington, Australia
Abstract: The frequency of browsing as a method of choosing material in public libraries, and the failure of most libraries to organize material in a way likely to appeal to browsers is discussed. The concern with the browser emerged from a needs survey of the users of one suburban Sydney library. The users were classified ac- cording to the specificity of their requirements. Almost 50 percent of those interviewed stated that they had come to the library to browse. In light of this finding, the investigators suggest possible changes in public libraries that would make library collections more "browser friendly. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Marketing and the public library
Affiliations: School of Communication, Information and Library Studies (SCILS), Rutgers-The State University of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, 08903, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dragon, A., School of Communication, Information and Library Studies (SCILS), Rutgers-The State University of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, 08903, United States
Abstract: This is the first in a series of articles exploring fundamental issues concerning the application of marketing concepts and skills to public libraries. Subsequent articles will discuss positioning, communication, and pricing. The series will conclude with an examination of the professional and ethical problems associated with marketing in libraries. © 1983 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The private public libraries of taiwan
Affiliations: Acquisitions Librarian, Southern Oregon State College Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Otness, H.M., Acquisitions Librarian, Southern Oregon State College Library, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Affiliations: Graduate Student, Library Science, Texas Woman's University, Denton, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, M.S.-L., Graduate Student, Library Science, Texas Woman's University, Denton, TX, United States

Affiliations: United States

Title: Dynamic dallas: A building critique
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Holt, R.M., United States
