Title: The sunbelt's public libraries: 1972-1982
Affiliations: School of Library Science, Institute for Research in Social Science, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carpenter, R.L., School of Library Science, Institute for Research in Social Science, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, United States
Abstract: During the 1970s, the population of the Sunbelt states grew more than that of the nation as a whole. However, the question is whether this region's growth in public library expenditures and circulation kept pace with the rate of inflation for the period. Based on analysis of survey data compiled by the Memphis, Tennessee, Public Library, marked improvements in budgets and circulation are noted, while losses in the purchasing power of salaries were experienced and imbalances in gender distribution among directors continued. © 1983 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The public librarian and the group process
Affiliations: School of Communication, Information and Library Studies, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turock, B., School of Communication, Information and Library Studies, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Selecting materials for children: A skills refresher workshop
Affiliations: Dallas Public Library System, Pleasant Grove Community Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pottle, C., Dallas Public Library System, Pleasant Grove Community Library, United States
Abstract: In January, 1983, the Dallas Public Library held the second of two skills refresher workshops for youth librarians. The first workshop was of a practical nature, dealing with programming; the second was designed as a philosophical discussion of materials selection. The workshop began with four librarians presenting their views on materials selection for children. Following the presentations, there was a general discussion among youth librarians from all 18 libraries in the system of the use of reviews in selection. The following article contains the four presentations and a summary of the discussion. © 1983 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Editorial
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Waters, R.L., United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Multilingual library services: Why bother?
Affiliations: North Carolina Language Center, United States
Authors with affiliations: Valentine, P.M., North Carolina Language Center, United States
Abstract: The North Carolina Foreign Language Center has four objectives. They are to provide recreational and educational readings in non-English languages, to provide resources for ESL, to provide materials for learning other languages, and to provide bilingual information resources. © 1983 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Editorial
Authors with affiliations: Waters, R.L.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Winning more library dollars: Take no for an answer
Affiliations: Metropolitan Library System, Oklahoma City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyers, D.H., Metropolitan Library System, Oklahoma City, United States
Abstract: Gaining voter approval for a local tax increase is never easy. Winning by a three to one margin. when an affirmative vote would result in a $6.00 per year per property owner tax in- crease, is far from easy. When such a victory takes place in conservative Oklahoma, it is almost beyond belief. But, believe. The story of how the Metropolitan Library System passed a referendum that resulted in the largest tax increase in the history of the state is a lesson for all. Read about it here. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: The preservation and maintenance of special research collections in public libraries: A review of related literature and a call for community analysis
Affiliations: University of Southern California, Columbia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nemchek, L.R., University of Southern California, Columbia, United States
Abstract: Whether or not, or under what circumstances, public libraries should house special-subject research collections is examined with respect to: (I) feasibility of community participation in administrative decision making and allocation of Funds: (2) reliability of library/collection use statistics as measures of performance: (3) rationales for and costs of maintaining special collections. Literature on local history and performing arts research collections is discussed to illustrate practical administrative considerations. Creation of community participation opportunities, either through formal analyses of library communities or other methods, is advocated as essential with respect to the preservation and maintenance of special-subject research collections in public libraries. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Some hazards and non hazards of mailed questionnaire surveys
Affiliations: University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, 90089, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bennion, B.C., University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, 90089, United States
Abstract: Libraries have utilized the mailed questionnaire as a principal source of data collection for many years. The opportunities to introduce bias is great, but can be overcome. Using as an example a 1980 test in Southern California, the author illustrates how question wording bias can be avoided, and how survey results can be misleading if the bias is present. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Outreach services for public library i&r: Measuring effectiveness
Affiliations: Cumberland County Public Library, Fayetteville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Beagle, D., Cumberland County Public Library, Fayetteville, United States; Lacy, D., Cumberland County Public Library, Fayetteville, United States
Abstract: This study demonstrates that public library Information and Referral services can reach a greater number of disadvantaged persons through outreach. A project was designed to determine which outreach methods were effective in motivating lower in-come persons to use I&R. Methods evaluated were: personal contact, publicity, advertising, informative pamphlets, and workshops. Results indicate that personal contact with agencies and community groups is effective in motivating target populations. as measured by a large increase in agency referrals as the users' source of information about I&R. Although traditional publicity techniques have little effect, workshops and informative pamphlets were useful in reaching subgroups of the target population. By using a good mix of outreach methods, low income calls as a percent of total inquiries in- creased twofold. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: School library participation in regional multi type networks: Myth and reality
Affiliations: Rochester Regional Research Library Council, United States
Authors with affiliations: Welch, J., Rochester Regional Research Library Council, United States
Abstract: The results of the first two years of a pilot project in the Rochester, New York area provide new data on school library participation as full partners in multi type cooperative activities. Research findings demonstrate that school libraries hold unique materials. are able to fill many of the interlibrary loan requests of other libraries and utilize their computer terminals to enhance communication between libraries. Additional sources of current information in the area of multi type library cooperation are also de- scribed. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Reading interests, life interests, and life-style
Affiliations: University of South Carolina, Columbia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lucas, L., University of South Carolina, Columbia, United States
Abstract: This paper is based on the results of dissertation research into the relationship of the variety of life interests to the variety of reading interests among adult users of public libraries in communities of various sizes. Results indicated that a direct relationship does exist regardless of community size or level of education at- tained. The relationship was weaker where the level of education at- tained by the respondents was higher. Results of previous studies which showed the influence of life-style on reading habits and reading interests were confirmed. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Authors: Dilemma A., Prokop M., McClure C.R.
Title: The public librarian and service ethics
Affiliations: University Of Oktehomi She now resides in Savannah, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dilemma, A., University Of Oktehomi She now resides in Savannah, United States; Prokop, M., University Of Oktehomi She now resides in Savannah, United States; McClure, C.R., University Of Oktehomi She now resides in Savannah, United States
Abstract: The relationship between personal and professional ethics is examined from the standpoint of the public librarian. Personal attitudes and the service philosophy implicit in public librarianship often suggest contradictory responses to information or service requests which are personally offensive 111 the librarian. Resulting in ethical dilemmas. Examples of such diletnmas are given: reasons live their occurrence and different t opinions regarding ethical behavior arc discussed. This type of conflict is itself neither gnome nor bad, but must be acknowledged by librarians and dealt with by the profession. Existing ethics of service guidelines are reviewed. and recornmendations for resolving ethical conflict are offered. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: Information brokers friend and foe
Affiliations: City Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Laforte, S.R., City Library, United States
Abstract: In recent years a number of organizations have appeared which offer a variety of information services for a fee. The bulk of their clientele is industry and government. A few former librarians have gone into business because of the retractable nature of the libraries in which they worked. Many information brokers have library backgrounds, but complain that their library school training did not prepare them to deal with the business world. Brokers are criticized for charging for free information, but they contend that their charges are for the service involved in providing the information. Librarianship is approaching a place that other professions reached long ago: the place where self-employment is normal and valuable. © 1978 by The Haworth Press, All rights reserved.

Title: The muse in the stacks: A survey of poetry in public libraries
Affiliations: Department of Mental Hygiene, Albany, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Penney, D., Department of Mental Hygiene, Albany, NY, United States
Abstract: Twelve years ago, in a nationwide survey of public libraries it was found that modern American poetry collections were generally meager, unevenly developed, and of low priority to public libraries.' The nature of poetry publication in the United States present3 unique problems for the library trying to develop a collection of modem American poetry, and for the evaluator of such a collection. © 1982 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Pdq-professional development quarterly
Affiliations: Rutgers University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turock, B., Rutgers University, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Editorial
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Prentice, A.E., United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Libraries and multi-cultural understanding
Affiliations: State University of New York at Buffalo, Amherst, NY, 14260, United States; Oakland University, Rochester, MI, 48063, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ellison, J.W., State University of New York at Buffalo, Amherst, NY, 14260, United States; DiFelice, C., Oakland University, Rochester, MI, 48063, United States
Abstract: The library in a community serves as a primary source of information for and about that community. Usually, the community is composed of mixes of racial, ethnic, and cultural groups. There is a need to understand the varied make-up of the community in order to provide equal and unrestricted access to information for all members of that community. © 1982 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The public library's role in providing consumer health information
Affiliations: State University of New York at Albany, Albany, NY, 12222, United States; Latham, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vaillancourt, P.M., State University of New York at Albany, Albany, NY, 12222, United States; Bobka, M., Latham, NY, United States
Abstract: Positive and negative factors in providing medical information in a public library are discussed, with guidelines and examples. Sources of authoritative lists are provided. The role of the public library in patient education is reviewed. © 1982 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Bundy M.L., Bridgman A., Keltie L.
Title: Public library reference service: Myth and reality
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Bundy, M.L., United States; Bridgman, A., United States; Keltie, L., United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Bridging the professional gap: The alabama experience
Affiliations: Montgomery, AL, 36130, United States; United States
Authors with affiliations: Miele, A.W., Montgomery, AL, 36130, United States; Crowley, B., United States
Abstract: This article describes the response of one state library agency - the Alabama Public Library Service-to the problems arising from the conflict between the growing professionalism of public librarianship and the reality of large numbers of untrained but dedicated librarians resulting from local control of librarian qualifications. The authors analyse the causes of the discord within their state and relate the past and present efforts of the state library agency to take a leadership role in involving all Alabama public librarians in the ongoing work to upgrade library service to their communities. In particular the evolution of the Intensive Library Seminar and its effect in stimulatingpublic librarydevelopment isdiscussed. A short analysis of the concerns yet remaining and the possible methods of achieving a successful resolution is also presented. © 1982 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Editorial
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Prentice, A.E., United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Pdq -professional development quarterly
Affiliations: Rutgers University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turock, B., Rutgers University, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Four guidelines for public librarianship
Affiliations: Plainfield, NJ, 07060, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ballard, T.H., Plainfield, NJ, 07060, United States
Abstract: Four guidelines for choosing an appropriate servcset rategy for public libraries are offered. (1) The individual, not the group, is the appropriate point of focus for services. (2) There is no virtue in predictable failure, no matter how worthy the motives that inspired the attempt, and this is particularly true when the program is being financed with other people's money. (3) The educational supporting role is primary. (4) Failure in other professions should not be considered opportunities for librarians. © 1982 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The use of standard statistics in an on-line library management system
Affiliations: Colorado Springs, CO, 80901, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dowlin, K.E., Colorado Springs, CO, 80901, United States
Abstract: At the Pikes Peak Lbraryin Colorado Springs most ot'tht. functions of the library have been automated and it is now feasible to provide statistical indicators on most functions. The traditional service statistics. such as the number of books checked out. the number of people that enter Ihcilities. and the number of' questions answered have been incorporated into the management information svstem. The production statistics Rom materials processingand other areas are also being incav porated into a decision support system. It has been the goal to be able to analyze the use of librarv resources by the public in sufficient detail ro provide a basis for daily decision making. © 1982 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The local public works program: Impact on public, school, and academic libraries
Affiliations: Western Illinois University Libraries, Macomb, IL, 61455, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goudy, F.W., Western Illinois University Libraries, Macomb, IL, 61455, United States
Abstract: The Local Public Works Program of the Public Works Employment Act of 19i6 and 1977 was allocated nearly 36 billion with the expressed purpose of reducing unemployment, by providing federal funding for construction porjects. An analysis of 10.617 project descriptors. as well as questionnaires sent to certain government units. revealed that approximately $153 million were received by public. school. and academic libraries. With LSCA funds for public library construction last appropriated in 19T:L LPW coupled with general revenue sharing has provided.the major stimulus for library capital projects in the 1970s. However. due to subsequent attempts to restrain the growth of the federal budget thelocal Public Works Propram was fundedonly in 1977 and has not been renewed. © 1982 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Public libraries and networking: A bibliographic essay
Affiliations: Carolina State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davis, J.Y., Carolina State University, United States
Abstract: Most of the literature on the participation of public libraries in cooperative activities deals with their expansion from local entities to multi type systems. Within the framework of this evolution, topics of special interest have been: (1) appropriate units of service; (2) legal and political considerations; (3) stimulus of legislation; (4) role of states and state library agencies; (5) financial aspects; (6) human factors; and (7) automation in networking. The literature reviewed was vast but was deficient in comprehensive syntheses, in rigorous, large-scale evaluations of networking, and in studies focusing solely on public libraries. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Of networks and vendors and public library automation
Affiliations: Austin Public Library, United States
Authors with affiliations: Juergens, B., Austin Public Library, United States
Abstract: A brief review of the status of automation in public libraries is presented, stressing the dependence upon networks and vendors for on-line systems. The characteristics of a library network are described. OCLC's current role as a network rather than as a utility is defended. A descriptive reference to other library networks is included. Finally, a comparison of networks to vendors in a service relationship to the library is presented, followed by a short list of public library automation predictions. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public libraries in local cooperative systems
Affiliations: Nassau Library System, United States
Authors with affiliations: Geddes, A., Nassau Library System, United States
Abstract: This article deals with networking and its implications for member libraries of a cooperative system in New York State. After describing briefly library developments in the state, the article discusses the history, organization, and financing of the Nassau Library System. The service program of the system is outlined, and these activities are then related to statewide, regional, bicounty, and local activities which have an impact on local library service. The problems of New York system development are mentioned, and the benefits of participation in a system program are discussed. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Politics of local interlibrary cooperation
Affiliations: Champaign Public Library and Information Center, United States
Authors with affiliations: Drescher, J.A., Champaign Public Library and Information Center, United States
Abstract: Social and political issues are key factors in developing cooperation among public libraries. Experiences in public library cooperation have shown that the acceptance of cooperation as an ideal, patron reaction and acceptance, local pride and control, and the education and cooperation of the library board, local government officials, and funding agencies are all important in providing the best possible framework for cooperation. The commitment to and understanding of the implications, changes, and modifications that cooperation requires are also important. Realization that interpretation of what cooperation means and that unequal contributions can be expected are necessary steps in developing effective arrangements among public libraries. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public library networking viewed from a state library agency
Affiliations: Department of Public Instruction, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eberhart, W.L., Department of Public Instruction, United States
Abstract: Especially over the past 30 years, state library agencies have played a major role in the planning and development of cooperative and networking activities among public libraries and between public libraries and other types of libraries. These activities have been carried out in a great variety of ways, with each state reacting to its own demographic, governmental, and library realities. The federal Library Services and Construction Act has been a major constructive force enabling state library agencies to be effective leaders in cooperative and networking activities. State library agencies and public libraries working together can continue to extend library services by taking leadership in networking activities. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public library cooperation and cooperatives an historical overview
Affiliations: North Suburban Library System, United States
Authors with affiliations: McClarren, R.R., North Suburban Library System, United States
Abstract: This paper traces the development of interlibrary cooperation in the United States during the twentieth century. Unstructured cooperation, indicated by such activities as the National Union Catalog at the Library of Congress (1901) and the first interlibrary loan code (1917), continues today. Since World War Il, structured cooperation, including regional networks, special activities, and multipurpose cooperatives, has become more prominent. A definition of library cooperation is offered, and differences between the terms system, network, and consortium are explored. Probable future developments in library cooperation are mentioned, including applications of computer technology and potential political benefits of multi type library cooperation. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: A view of the future of library networking
Affiliations: State University of New York Central Administration, United States
Authors with affiliations: Evans, G.T., State University of New York Central Administration, United States
Abstract: Future developments in library networks will include growth of computer-based networks in number and variety of libraries, in use of various subsystems, and in size of databases used. Services provided by on-line systems will expand to include improved subject access, on-line catalogs, serials lists and inventory control, acquisitions functions, interlibrary lending, circulation, and reference services. Additional services will include home delivery of information, text transmission, home-computing support, library management systems, and interface between bibliographi cutilities. Increasing interaction is breaking open the artifical compartments in which libraries and librarians have seen themselves. The demands placed on library personnel in network development will need continued exercise of skill, knowledge, and integrity as the collective common sense works for the common good. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public library cooperation as seen from a multistate network
Affiliations: University of Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dejohn, W., University of Washington, United States
Abstract: Cooperation among libraries in the Pacific Northwest is of long standing and is an example of regional cooperation among public libraries and other libraries through interlibrary loan, union catalogs, union lists, cooperative cataloging, and telecommunications networks between two countries and over a large and sparsely populated region. Networking has resulted in increased services to library users and in increased efficiencies in library operations. It has also introduced a whole set of new problems that must be discussed in the forum provided as a result of the cooperative arrangements and the need to extend them into the future. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Financial impacts of networking and resource sharing
Affiliations: Public Library of Columbus, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sweeney, R.T., Public Library of Columbus, United States
Abstract: Library cooperatives will evolve more into automated library networks which are generally more cost-effective, less labor-intensive, and provide more and better service. The more successful networks are those where the member libraries have a significant commitment with funds from their local libraries operating budgets and which view the services as an integral part of their essential operations. Cost-effective networks are characterized by greater competition, less state and federal control, and more research and development. The network's economic revolution for public libraries is beginning to occur where automated networks have extended services directly to the users in their homes. © 1981 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Milwaukee public library, 1942-1980: A pioneer in data processing
Affiliations: Milwaukee, WI, 53233, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bates, H.E., Jr., Milwaukee, WI, 53233, United States
Abstract: The Milwaukee Public Library, with its present system of 50 automatic circulation control terminals, 17 CRTs, four mini-computers. 105 billion characters of on-line disc storage, seven tape drives, as well as the use of the City Hall main frames, has had a long history of data processing starting back in 1942. The disappointments, problems, and successes, especially with major control of its data processing operations, are spelled out. Also, a brief overview is offered of other system developments. © 1980 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Editorial
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Prentice, A.E., United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Privatization: A new arrangement for library management
Affiliations: Indiana University, Indianapolis, IN, 46204, United States; Indianapolis, IN, 46204, United States
Authors with affiliations: DeCoster, T.A., Indiana University, Indianapolis, IN, 46204, United States; Logsdon, R.L., Indianapolis, IN, 46204, United States
Abstract: Library administrators, confronted with the realities of managhg with less, should consider privatization as a cost-cutting arrangement for the delivery of library services. Management decision making which separates the roles of provider and producer offers the potential for reducing costs through competitive bidding by private firms offering to produce library services. This article examines the privatization arrangement, reviews its advantages and disadvantages, and critiques its application to three areas of library operations: Reference services, security, and cataloging. © 1980 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Methods of evaluation of public library systems
Affiliations: Toronto, M4P 2HI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Campbell, H.C., Toronto, M4P 2HI, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Wood J.B., Bremer J., Saraidaridis S.A.
Title: Measurement of service at a public library
Affiliations: Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, 44106, United States; Cleveland, OH, 44114, United States; Waltham, MA, 02154, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wood, J.B., Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, 44106, United States; Bremer, J., Cleveland, OH, 44114, United States; Saraidaridis, S.A., Waltham, MA, 02154, United States
Abstract: Simple, efficient, unobtrusive data collection and analysis techniques were applied to study volume of use, user activity, and availability of items sought by users in a public library. Stratified sampling methods employed to measure volume of use and user activity showed that this medium-sized public library provided approximately 4, 000 user service hours per week. The average visit lasted 34 minutes with 32% of all visit time spent reading library materials. Overall availability of items sought by users in the adult section was approximately 38%. The application of these measurement techniques, which can be carried out by relatively untrained staff or volunteers, to pinpoint possible improvements in library service is discussed. © 1980 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The agent and the learner: Interactions in assisted adult library learning
Affiliations: Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ, 08903, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carr, D., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ, 08903, United States
Abstract: Relationships between adult independent learners and assisting tibrarians were examined using the critical incident technique, a means for eliciting narrative data. Thirty-nine learner's advisors-participants in a project of the College Board-provided descriptions of important effective and ineffective encounters with adults who sought new skills or knowledge through systematic library assistance. Eight critical themes were found: Individuation, mutuality, support, information, expectation, motivation, learning from practice, and clarification. These themes are dynamic, interpenetrative, and mutually supportive. The agent and the learner create complex encounters in which the information given is less important to learning than the quality of the giving. © 1980 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The programmer/analyst
Affiliations: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: D'Amico, A., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: The attorney
Affiliations: Knoxville, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Randolph, L., Knoxville, TN, United States

Title: The veterans advisor
Affiliations: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Collins, N., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States

Title: Pricing objectives for public library services
Affiliations: Department of Recreation, Texas A'M University, College Station, TX, 77843, United States; State University of New York at Albany, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crompton, J.L., Department of Recreation, Texas A'M University, College Station, TX, 77843, United States; Bonk, S., State University of New York at Albany, United States
Abstract: The opportunities and problems confronting a public library in its pricing decisions are related to its pricing objectives. This paper examines six objectives of price and identifies the likely outcomes associated with each objective. These objectives are market equity, social equity, maximum opportunity for participation, maximizing revenue, rationing, and commercial sector encouragement. It is unlikely that a library will have one overall pricing objective which is applicable to all of the services it delivers. The price which is ultimately adopted for any particular service will depend upon which objectives are uppermost in priority and will represent the best compromise among conflicting objectives. © 1980 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The availability and use of experimental films
Affiliations: State University of New York at Buffalo, Amherst, NY, 14260, United States
Authors with affiliations: Palmer, J.W., State University of New York at Buffalo, Amherst, NY, 14260, United States
Abstract: There are audiences for experimental films among the clients of public library film collections, the audiences are not presently large for certain titles and in certain communities. There is, however, some indication that audiences can be developed if administrators are knowledgeable about and committed to promoting their kind of film. One must also consider whether there might not be potential users among segments of the community that do not presently use film services and also among present users who have not had exposure to experimental films or who need guidance in their use. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Library services to handicapped people and the role of the advisory committee
Affiliations: Columbus, OH, 43215, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lovejoy, E., Columbus, OH, 43215, United States
Abstract: Title IVB of the Library Services and Construction Act of 1966 stimulated the growth of library services to people with handicaps in Ohio, as in other states. The IVB Advisory Council was instrumental in setting the direction of service for more than a decade, and encouraged the involvement of public libraries in promoting the braille and talking book service, state and regional workshops for librarians, a state consultant for library services to the handicapped, improvement of services at the two regional libraries to the blind and physically handicapped, and model projects funded by L.S.C.A. The successor to the IVB Advisory Council, and Advisory Committee for Library Outreach Services, continues to advise the State Library Board and State Library staff and Ohio's experience can serve as a model to other states as they implement TITLE IVB. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The problem patron: Toward a comprehensive response
Affiliations: History-Travel-Biography Department, Toledo, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clyde Grotophorst, W., History-Travel-Biography Department, Toledo, OH, United States
Abstract: The problem patron poses a dilemma for many librarians, one which deserves a more reasoned examination. Based on an informal survey of 40 large, urban public libraries, a set of guidelines for managing the problem patron is offered. Further, there is a discussion of an overall strategy for increasing the competence of library staff members vis a vis the problem patron, using as an example, a program developed by the Hartford Public Library. Increased communication among librarians, the exploitation of professional expertise within each library's community, and the adherence to coherent guidelines are stressed as essentials for success. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: The effect on public library circulation of advertising via cable television
Affiliations: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lawrence Auld, W.S., University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL, United States
Abstract: The hypothesis that public library circulation of individual titles would be significantly greater when publicized via CATV than when not so publicized was tested by an experiment in which older public library titles were publicized using low-intensity cablecast advertisements. Circulation of the advertised titles was not significantly altered when compared with either previous rates of circulation or control titles. Low-intensity cablecast advertisement for older public library titles was judged not to be an effective means for increasing circulation. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Cooperative cataloging and automated bibliographic networks; considerations for public libraries
Affiliations: Indiana University Libraries, Bloomington, IN, 47405, United States; University of Illinois, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, D., Indiana University Libraries, Bloomington, IN, 47405, United States; Davis, C.H., University of Illinois, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States
Abstract: Collection overlap between public library collections in the United States and Canada is examined from both the general user's and the bibliographer's viewpoint. Random samples of monographs published since 1970 were taken from eight public libraries and searched in the OCLC data base. The consistently high find rate on OCLC and the large percentage of Library of Congress MARC cataloging are discussed. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Assessing performance in libraries
Affiliations: Department of Economics, University of Queensland, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Karunaratne, N.D., Department of Economics, University of Queensland, Australia
Abstract: This article examines the potential of the use of cost benefit analysis in evaluating the performance of public libraries. The author describes an application in an Australian setting. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Packaging programs: New mode of library service to older adults
Affiliations: United States; TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rubin, R.J., United States; Bostic, L., TX, United States
Abstract: Packaged programs for older adults allow a wide range of topics and a greater availability of materials than is possible with the one time program. Savings in staff time are substantial while service is increased. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Contributions of small libraries to state-wide resource sharing: A study of collection overlap through the incolsa processing center
Affiliations: Indiana University Libraries, Bloomington, IN, United States; Indiana State Library, Indianapolis, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, D., Indiana University Libraries, Bloomington, IN, United States; Stockey, E.A., Indiana State Library, Indianapolis, IN, United States
Abstract: A random sample of 100 titles was taken of monographs cataloged by the Indiana Cooperative Library Services Authority (INCOLSA) Processing Center from 1975 through 1978. The cataloging, done using the OCLC system, reflected a 95% find rate in the OCLC data base; the 5% original input remaining is not unusual for public libraries using this system. An investigation of the overlap of the sample with five public library collections showed a positive correlation between target library size and find rate. However, because 75% of the sample was nonfiction (higher than expected for small and medium sized public libraries, which make up the bulk of the processing center users), the processing center collection file may not be typical of the total collections of such libraries. To gain an indication of the value of the processing center file in resource sharing, a furfher study was made of the 18% of the sample not found in any of the five public libraries searched. An additional 7% of the sample was located in Indiana using the OCLC data base; the remaining 11% was not easily located in the state. This is taken as evidence of the importance of small and medium sized public libraries in providing access to specialized or uncommon materials. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Reference service in local public libraries: A view from down under
Affiliations: School of Librarianship, University of New South Wales, Kensington, 2033, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Willard, P., School of Librarianship, University of New South Wales, Kensington, 2033, Australia
Abstract: The study investigated staff deployment at the reference service points of two large and two small local public libraries in the Sydney metropolitan area. Hypotheses investigated concerned expected differences between large and small libraries. The method used involved identification of the levels of staff employed and observation of tasks performed by staff. The results revealed significant differences between types of activities performed in the large and small libraries with the staff in the former performing more reference related tasks. The combined reference/circulation desk is seen as a problem in developing reference service. Staff attitudes are also considered to play an important part in the development of reference service. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Money from within the library
Affiliations: University of Maryland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Prentice, A.E., University of Maryland, United States
Abstract: The economist the politician the librarian view the question of charging for public library services from differing perspectives. The two types of service most often considered candidates for fees are interlibrary loan and the use of on line bibliography bases. Decisions on whether or not lo charge for services cannot be made solely on the basis of any one perspective. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Women in public library management how do they measure up
Affiliations: College of the Atlantic, Maine, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dworak, M., College of the Atlantic, Maine, United States
Abstract: During the spring of 1977, a study was undertaken to analyze the administrative responsibilities, competencies and educational experiences of public library directors in the state of Illinois. Data gathered from the study was used to determine the educational and training needs of these directors so that continuing education opportunities could be planned accordingly. A further objective of the study was to the women surveyed differ in a significant way from the men to see if their needs are in any way Separator special. The intent here is to summarize those findings so as to provide current profile of women in public library administration in the state of Illinois. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Public library programs for young children a review of the research and descriptive literature
Affiliations: Dallas Public Library, TX, 75202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smardo, F.A., Dallas Public Library, TX, 75202, United States
Abstract: A review was made of The recent research studies and descriptive articles which pertained to public library programs for young children. This review indicated, first of very little significant empirical research or careful statically studies exist which accurately measure and analyze either the validity of providing such services, their desired objectives, or their effect upon participants. Documentations of this situation is presented. Secondly, the review of the literature revealed that despite this scarcity of research, great variedly of public library programs for the youngest clientele are presently being offered. This article examines the few research efforts which have been undertaken which focus upon the evaluation of library programs for preschool children. Pertinent research from the related disciplines of reading and education are also included, with implications for the field of librarian ship. In particular, the Findings from the analytical search of this author which concerned the recommendations of early childhood education authorities regarding public library programs or children from infancy to six years of age, are presented. Lastly, this article contains guide lines And a philosophy statement for public libraries in serving preschool patrons and their care givers which were developed based upon the conclusions of the research. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Combining two subject headings lists in one catalog problems for patrons
Affiliations: Fisk University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walker, V., Fisk University, United States
Abstract: A study was made of the differences bet wean Sears and LC subject headings in a random sample of 663 book titles held by a public library using both subject headings systems in its card catalog. Over 68 percent of the assigned headings disagreed. Discrepancies were primarily. differences in terminology, but other serious differences were noted. The problems acting a user of a catalog containing a combination of two subjects headings lists were discussed. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Relative percentages of fiction and non fiction in selected canadian and american public libraries
Affiliations: Graduate School of Library Science, university of Illinois, United States; Indiana University Libraries, Bloomington, IN, 47401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davis, C.H., Graduate School of Library Science, university of Illinois, United States; Shaw, D., Indiana University Libraries, Bloomington, IN, 47401, United States
Abstract: A preliminary examination of American and Canadian public library acquisitions published during the 197O suggests model in which The percentage Of non fiction increases with collection size. Random samples token from the see particular Canadian libraries have a significantly higher percentage of fiction than the sample stoke from their American counterparts; however, the observed difference can be explained by the aforementioned model, in which the variation is a function of collection size rather than nationality. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Finding the librarys role in an information society
Affiliations: State University of New York, Albany, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wolff, B.H., State University of New York, Albany, NY, United States
Abstract: Emergence of the information society requires reassessment of the role of libraries and increased understanding of the meaning and economic manifestations of information. It is urged that widespread professional attention be directed to emerging public information policy and to clarifying o library role in prevailing economic terms. A tentative role for libraries is outlined. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: News stand magazines and the public library
Affiliations: Colorado State University Libraries, CO, 80523, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lupton, D.W., Colorado State University Libraries, CO, 80523, United States
Abstract: Between November 1977 and February 1978sixty three major American public libraries we resurveyed concerning their holdings of the fifty Five leading mass consumer magazines sold on the newsstand. The 97percentresponse is discussed and tabulated as is the coverage of the titles in eight popular magazine indexes. For ease of discussion the fifty five titles surveyed are grouped into fourteen subject categories and the results of the survey summarized. It is concluded that the major public libraries in the United States adequately represent the current stole of the nations popular culture as rejected in news stand sales of popular magazines. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Information for fee and information for free the information broker and the public librarian
Affiliations: Info motion, 214 West Mountain Road, MA, 01240, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whyte Felicetti, B., Info motion, 214 West Mountain Road, MA, 01240, United States
Abstract: Information Brokering has grown in response to The enormous proliferation of available information and to the needs Of segments of the population requiring complete and accurate information. The need is so overwhelming, the clients so diverse, and the constrains on libraries and librarians so great, that there is ample room for both the public librarian and the fee-based information service to operate together. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. Title: Attitudes of school and public librarians toward combined facilities
Affiliations: School of Library Science, University of Iowa, IA, 52242, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weech, T.L., School of Library Science, University of Iowa, IA, 52242, United States
Abstract: A stratified random sample of Iowa school and public librarians were surveyed to determine their attitude to ward combination school public library facilities. The survey instrument was based on one developed by L. J. Amey and R. J. Smith for a survey of Toronto school and public librarians. Theosophy determined that there was little difference in attitude of Iowa elementary and secondary school librarians to ward combined facilities, nor was there much difference in attitude Of Iowa public librarians serving populations under 2,500 and these serving more than 2,500 to ward combined facilities. School and public librarians did demonstrate statistically significant differences in responses to fifteen of the twenty six state menstruating to combined facilities. Compared10 respondents in the Toronto study, a larger percentage of Iowa public librarians were less concerned about the geographic inconvenience of combined facilities and perceived less duplication resuming from combination. Although a larger percentage of Iowa librarians seemed to see some advantages in combined facilities, both groups indicated some important concerns relating to combined school public libraries. © 1979 by The Haworth Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
